GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 52.01  CERTAIN USES OF WATER PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to use, or to aid or abet in the
use of, city water obtained in any manner not authorized by the provisions of
this chapter.



('75 Code, § 18-15)  (Ord. 70, passed 10-21-54) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.02  PERMIT REQUIRED TO CONNECT TO WATER SYSTEM.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause a connection to
be made to any city water main of any type without a permit to do so issued
by the Public Works Department.  Each application for a permit for any such
connection shall be made by the owner of the premises to be served by such
connec-tion, or his duly authorized agent, upon blanks furnished by the city,
and upon the payment of the required tapping fees.  A written permit shall
be issued for the connection.



   (B)   The tapping fees mentioned in division (A) of this section
shall be as prescribed by the City Council from time to time, and a copy of
each schedule of fees so prescribed shall be placed on file in the office of
the Director of Public Works.  Until such time as the City Council
prescribes water tapping fees pursuant to this section, the water tapping
fees in force immediately prior to the effective date of this code shall
continue in full force and effect.



   (C)   The officer issuing a water tap permit pursuant to division
(A) of this section may prescribe in such permit the size and specifications
of pipe to be laid, the manner of installation thereof and connection to the
city main, and such other conditions as may be appropriate and in accord with
this chapter and the policies of the City Council.



('75 Code, § 18-3)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.03  SUPERVISION OF CONNECTIONS.



   All connections to the city water mains of any type, which are not made
by city employees, shall be made by plumbers licensed by the city and their
work shall be subject to the supervision and approval of the Director of
Public Works.



('75 Code, § 18-4)



§ 52.04  PROHIBITED CONNECTIONS.



   No plumbing, plumbing fixture, construction or valve, fitting or
device, apparatus, or connection shall be installed which will provide a
cross connection between a distributing system of water supply for drinking
and domestic purposes, and a drainage system, soil or waste pipe, so as to
permit or make possible the back flow of sewage or wastewater into the water
supply system.



('75 Code, § 18-5)  (Ord. 40, passed 2-3-54) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.05  SERVICE CHARGES.



   (A)   Schedules authorized.



      (1)   The City Council may from time to time, by resolution
not in conflict with state law, this code, or other ordinance, promulgate
schedules of charges for:



         (a)   City water furnished to customers;



         (b)   The installation of meters; and



         (c)   Other services, materials, and equipment furnished
by the city to customers of the city water services.



      (2)   Any such schedule may provide for the dates on which
bills are to be mailed to customers; the due date for the payment of such
bills; and civil penalties for the nonpayment of such bills when due. A copy
of each such schedule, while in effect, shall be maintained on file in the
office of the City Clerk and another copy shall be maintained on file in the
office of the appropriate city department, and in each such office such
schedule shall be available to the public for inspection and use during all
regular business hours.



   (B)   Changes in effect.  Until such time as the City Council
adopts a schedule of charges pursuant to division (A) of this section, the
charges in force immediately preceding the effective date of this code are
hereby continued in full force and effect.



   (C)   Establishment of rate category.  There is hereby established
for the purpose of determining the proper rate to charge customers receiving
services as defined herein, a category of customer who owns property both
inside and outside the city limits, where such property is one parcel or
tract of land, or two or more adjacent tracts, any portion of which lies
inside the city limits (hereinafter referred to as the “property”).



   (D)   Method for determining rates.  The rates for the category of
customer described in division (C) of this section shall be determined as
follows:



      (1)   The customer shall pay that current rate for water
services of the city being charged similar customers (for example,
residential or industrial) whose property being served lies wholly inside the
city limits (hereinafter referred to as the “inside rate”), if the
customer has no facility located on the property receiving services of the
city and lying outside the city limits.



      (2)   The customer shall pay that current rate for water
services of the city being charged similar customers whose property being
served lies wholly outside the city limits (hereinafter referred to as the
“outside rate”), if the customer has no facility located on the property
receiving services of the city and lying inside the city limits.



      (3)   If the customer has facilities located on the property
which lie both inside and outside the city limits and which receive water,
the customer may elect either of the following:



         (a)   To pay the current outside rate for water for all
facilities located on the property regard- less of whether the facilities are
located inside or outside the city limits.



         (b)   To petition the city for annexation of the entire
portion of customer's property lying  outside the city limits and receiving
services.  During the pendency of any such petition and until the effec-
tive date of the annexation, the cost of services for the customer shall be
computed at the outside rate; provided, however, if the ordinance annexing
the property is adopted and the property of the customer receiving services
is annexed, the customer shall receive a credit in an amount equal to the
difference between the inside rate and the outside rate from the date the
petition is filed until the effective date of the annexation for consumption
during the period. Provided further, however, the credit referred to in this
division shall apply to the consumption of any customer filing a petition for
annexation in proper form on or before May 13, 1985 for the period beginning
April 1, 1985 until the effective date of the annexation.



         (c)   To pay the current inside rate for  water for
those facilities located on the property lying wholly within the city limits
and to pay the current outside rate for water services for those facilities
located on the property lying wholly outside the city limits.  In the event
a facility located on the property lies both inside and outside the city
limits, the customer will pay the current inside rate for services provided
to the facility, only if the customer pays ad valorem taxes to the city on
the facility.  Provided, however, the option provided hereunder shall not
apply until the customer has fully complied with the provisions of division
(E) of this section.



   (E)   Separate meters required.  In the event the customer makes
the election under division (D)(3)(c) of this section, the customer shall
install to the satisfaction of the city two separate water systems to provide
service to the facilities located inside the city limits and outside the city
limits as well as separate meters or other appropriate measuring devices to
measure the amount of service provided to the facilities inside and outside
the city limits.



('75 Code, § 18-6) (Am. Ord. passed 4- -85)



§ 52.06  RATES AND FEES.



   (A)   Water rates and fees shall be determined from time to time by
ordinance by the City Council.



   (B)   Every person who owns improved property within the corporate
limits of the city shall be required to pay a service availability fee with
respect to such improved property equal to the then current minimum charge
for water and sewer service to residential customers unless such service is
not avail-able.  This availability charge shall not apply to owners who
maintain connections to both the water and sewer systems of the city for such
improved property.  Owners maintaining connections to one system but not the
other system shall pay an avail-ability charge equal to the minimum charge
for the available service to which the owner does not maintain a connection.



§ 52.07  REGULATIONS GOVERNING ARROWOOD LAKE RESERVE WATER SUPPLY.



   (A)   No fishing, boating, swimming, bathing, or wading in the
city's reserve water supply lake on Arrowood Lake shall be permissible at any
time and is hereby prohibited.



   (B)   All occupied dwelling houses and business establishments
situated on the watershed of the Arrowood Lake shall be provided with
approved systems of sewage disposal constructed and main- tained in
accordance with the requirements of this chapter and of the State Board of
Health.



   (C)   No human excrement or urine shall be voided or deposited on
the surface of the ground within a distance of 300 feet of the Arrowood Lake
or reservoir or streams, branches, springs or other tributaries thereto.



   (D)   No carcass of any animal shall be thrown into the Arrowood
Lake or the streams furnishing water thereto nor deposited on the surface of
the ground within the area of the watershed of the lake.



   (E)   No parks or other places of resort for the use and
entertainment of the public shall be established or maintained on the
watershed and no picnicking or camping shall be permitted thereon unless they
are provided with adequate sanitary facilities for the collection and
disposal of garbage and sewage.



   (F)   No child under 14 years-of-age shall be permitted within 300
feet of the Arrowood Lake unless accompanied by some adult person responsible
for his care and supervision.



   (G)   (1)   This section is not intended as a substitute for the
rules and regulations of the State Board of Health governing watersheds but
is to be construed as a supplement thereto.



      (2)   For the purpose of enforcing this section and the rules
and regulations of the State Board of Health governing the protection of the
city's reserve supply of water, the Director of Treatment Operations is
hereby designated as the official custodian of such water supply and its
watershed and, as such, he is hereby authorized to do all things necessary
and proper to enforce compliance with this section and the rules and
regulations of the State Board of Health; and he is further authorized and
directed to inspect and examine the watershed to ascertain if the premises of
the watershed are being maintained in accordance with this section and the
rules and regulations aforesaid and report his findings to the City Council,
and thereafter make such inspec- tions and examinations of the water supply
and the watershed as the circumstances may require; and he is further
authorized to do all things necessary to prevent the water supply from being
contaminated or rendered less wholesome for drinking purposes.



   (H)   It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision
of this section or to violate or fail to comply with any rule or regulation
of the State Board of Health applicable to the Arrowood Lake watershed or its
tributaries.



('75 Code, § 18-7)  (Ord. 72, passed 10-21-54) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.08  METERS REQUIRED FOR DWELLINGS AND BUSINESS BUILDINGS.



   (A)   A meter shall be installed at each dwelling house and at each
building occupied and used for business purposes, in which the occupants
thereof are using city water; provided, that the occupants of any dwelling
house who also operate a business in a building situated on the same premises
shall not be required to have a separate meter at both the dwelling house and
place of business when the occupants of the dwelling house actually operate
the business.



   (B)   Such meter shall serve to measure the water used by the
occupants of such dwelling house, or the occupants of such building used for
business purposes, anywhere on the premises irrespective of whether any of
the outlets are in other buildings or structures on the premises if the water
is for the use of the occupants of the dwelling house or the occupants of the
building used for business purposes.



('75 Code, § 18-8) (Ord. 70, passed 10-21-54)



§ 52.09  EACH STRUCTURE TO HAVE SEPARATE METER; EXCEPTIONS.



   The owner of any two or more structures furnished city water is
required to have installed a meter at each of such structures occupied by
different tenants, irrespective of how many outlets there may be on the
premises and irrespective of whether the outlets are inside such premises;
provided, that the Director of Public Works may, in his discretion, authorize
water service to be provided through a single meter to two or more structures
under single ownership when the owner of such premises will agree to become
the customer of the city liable for the payment of all water charges
furnished to each structure through such meter, and any such agreement shall
be in writing and subject to the approval of the City Attorney.



('75 Code, § 18-9) (Ord. 70, passed 10-21-54)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.10  METERED CUSTOMERS NOT TO PROVIDE WATER TO OTHER PERSONS;
EXCEPTIONS.



   The occupants of one building which has a meter shall not furnish water
to the occupants of another building which has no meter, and the occupants of
such building which has no meter shall not obtain water from the occupants of
another building which has a meter, except when any such person is
unavoidably deprived of water and then only for a period of 30 consecutive
days.



('75 Code, § 18-10) (Ord. 70, passed 10-21-54)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.11 PROHIBITED TAKING OF WATER BY PERSONS NOT LIABLE FOR WATER BILLS.



   No person other than the owner of the property served by a meter, or
the tenant of such property who is jointly and severally liable with such
owner for the payment of water bills, shall take city water running through
such meter.



('75 Code, § 18-11) (Ord. 70, passed 10-21-54)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.12  SIZE OF SERVICE PIPES.



   The size of water pipes shall be as specified by the Director of Public
Works.



('75 Code, § 18-12) (Ord. 40, passed 2-3-54)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.13  RESPONSIBILITY OF CUSTOMERS; SPECIAL EQUIPMENT.



   Customers to whom water service is supplied at any location which
requires a special pump or other appliance to provide sufficient pressure to
obtain sufficient water shall be entirely responsible for furnishing such
equipment as aforesaid and shall bear all expenses in connection therewith,
including the purchase thereof and its installation, maintenance, repairs,
operation and power bills.



('75 Code, § 18-13)  (Ord. passed 7-16-64)



§ 52.14  TAKING WATER FROM FIRE HYDRANTS.



   No person, other than a member of the Fire Department or other city
officer or employee acting in line of duty, shall take water from any city
fire hydrant, plug, street washer, draw cock, hose pipe, or fountain; nor
shall anyone in any way use or take water from any city fire hydrant for
private use, unless such person shall first obtain a permit from the City
Manager or his designee and pay such permit fee as may be established by the
City Council.



('75 Code, § 18-14) (Ord. 66, passed  - - )  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.15  REGULATIONS ON USE OF PRIVATE WELLS.



   (A)   No well shall be installed within the city limits without the
owner of the property on which the well is to be located first obtaining a
permit to be issued by the Director of Public Works or the City Manager.



   (B)   The Director of Public Works or the City Manager shall be
authorized to issue a permit for the installation of a well upon a showing
satisfactory to the Director of Public Works or the City Manager that the
following criteria have been met:



      (1)   That municipal water is not available to the property
pursuant to the extension policies of the city then in force.



      (2)   That the well to be installed is to be used only for
commercial or farming operations.



      (3)   That the proposed well meets the minimum public health
standards of the county and the state.



      (4)   Any well that serves a property connected to the sewer
shall pay for sewer service at a rate set by City Council from time to time.



(Ord. passed 9-9-85)  Penalty, see § 10.99



WATER SHORTAGE
CONSERVATION PROVISIONS



§ 52.30  PURPOSE.



   A water shortage shall be deemed to exist when water demand by
customers connected to the city water system reaches the point where
continued or increased demand will equal or exceed the system supply and
transmission capabilities.  When demand results in the condition whereby
customers cannot be supplied with water to protect their health and safety
then the demand must be substantially curtailed to relieve the water
shortage.  For the purpose of this subchapter, the term WATER SYSTEM shall
mean the water system of the city both inside and outside the city limits.



(Ord. passed 8-8-88)



§ 52.31  DECLARATION OF WATER SHORTAGE.



   In the event it appears that water demand on the city water system may
exceed supply and transmission capabilities, the Water Superintendent may
recommend to the City Manager that voluntary water conservation measures be
implemented. The City Manager, following consultation with the City Council,
may declare a Stage I Water Shortage Condition Advisory requesting voluntary
water conservation by consumers. In the event that voluntary conservation
measures fail to relieve the demand on the system, the city may advance to a
Stage II or Stage III Water Shortage Condition. The City Manager, following
consultation with the City Council, may, with or without the recommendation
of the Water Superintendent, declare that a Stage II or Stage III Water
Shortage Condition exists.



(Ord. passed 8-8-88; Am. Ord. passed 5-14-18)



§ 52.32  STAGE I WATER SHORTAGE CONDITIONS; GUIDELINES.



   (A)   In the event a Stage I Water Shortage Condition is declared,
the following guidelines apply:



      (1)   An extensive publicity campaign will be initiated using
public media and specialized methods to inform the public of an impending or
existing water shortage.



      (2)   Conservation measures will be encouraged and recommended.



   (B)   In the event a Stage I water shortage condition is declared,
the following guidelines shall apply and the public shall be encouraged to
adhere to the following:



      (1)   Limit car washing to the minimum.



      (2)   Limit lawn and garden watering to that which is
necessary for plants to survive.



      (3)   Cease washing down outside areas such as sidewalks,
patios, parking lots, service bays or aprons, and the like.



      (4)   Cease leaving faucets running while shaving or rinsing
dishes.



      (5)   Limit watering shrubbery to the minimum required,
reusing household water when possible.



      (6)   Limit use of clothes washers and dish washers and when
used, operate fully loaded.



      (7)   Use showers rather than bathtubs for bathing, and limit
showers to no more than four minutes.



      (8)   Limit flushing of toilets by multiple usage.



      (9)   Use disposable and biodegradable dishes as much as
possible.



      (10)   Use flow restrictive and water saving devices.



      (11)   Limit hours of operation of water cooled air
conditioners.



      (12)   Temporarily delay new landscape work by all residents,
businesses, and institutions until the water shortage has ended.



(Ord. passed 8-8-88; Am. Ord. passed 5-14-18)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.33  STAGE II WATER SHORTAGE CONDITIONS; UNLAWFUL USES OF WATER.



   (A)   In the event a Stage II Water Shortage Condition is in effect
and the raw water storage facilities drop to 60% or less of storage then the
City Manager may declare a Stage II Water Shortage. In exercising the
authority for declaring a water shortage condition consideration shall be
given to water shortage levels and available sources of supply, available
usable storage on hand, drawdown rates, the projected supply capability,
outlook for precipitation, daily water use patterns and availability of water
from other sources.



   (B)   In the event the City Manager issues a declaration of a Stage
II Water Shortage Condition, then it shall be unlawful for any person, firm,
or corporation to use or permit the use of water from the water system for
any purpose hereinafter set forth until such time as the declaration of water
shortage has been rescinded. In addition to the voluntary guidelines already
in effect, it shall be unlawful to use water supplied by the city water
system in the following manner:



      (1)   To water lawns, grass, shrubbery, trees, flowers, and
vegetable gardens except in accordance with the following schedule set forth
below for specific areas of the city. Such watering shall be done by
hand-held hose or container or drip irrigation system only. All areas north
of the tracks of the Southern Railroad on Sundays and Thursdays between 6:00
a.m. and 9:00 a.m. All areas south of the tracks of the Southern Railroad on
Saturdays and Wednesdays between 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m.



      (2)   To fill newly constructed swimming and/or wading pools
or to add water or to refill private swimming and/or wading pools which have
been drained.



      (3)   To wash automobiles, trucks, trailers, boats, airplanes,
or any other type of mobile equipment, including commercial washing.



      (4)   To wash down outside areas such as streets, driveways,
service station aprons, parking lots, office buildings, exterior of existing
or newly constructed homes or apartments, sidewalks, or patios, or to use
water for other similar purposes.



      (5)   To use water from public or private fire hydrants for
any purpose other than fire suppression or other public emergency.



      (6)   To operate or induce water into any ornamental fountain,
pool, or pond, or other structure for similar use of water.



      (7)   To serve drinking water in restaurant cafeterias, or
other food establishments, except upon request.



      (8)   To operate water-cooled air conditioners or other
equipment that does not recycle cooling water, except when health and safety
are adversely affected.



      (9)   To use water for any unnecessary purpose or to
intentionally waste water.



(Ord. passed 8-8-88; Am. Ord. passed 5-14-18)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.34  STAGE III WATER SHORTAGE CONDITIONS; RESTRICTIONS.



   (A)   In the event a Stage II Water Shortage Condition exists and
city raw water storage facilities drop to 40% or less of storage, then the
City Manager may declare a Stage III Water Shortage. In exercising the
authority for declaring a water shortage condition consideration shall be
given to water storage levels and available sources of supply, available
usable storage on hand, drawdown rates, the projected supply capability,
outlook for precipitation, daily water use patterns and availability of water
from other sources.



   (B)   In the event the City Manager issues a declaration of Stage
III Water Shortage Condition then it shall be unlawful for any person, firm,
or corporation to use or permit the use of water from the city water system
for any purpose hereinafter set forth until such time as the declaration of
water shortage has been rescinded. In addition to the restrictions for Stage
I and Stage II Water Shortage Conditions, the following restrictions shall
also apply:



      (1)   To fill or add any water into any pool.



      (2)   Use water outside a structure for any use other than an
emergency involving a fire.



      (3)   Fire protection to be maintained by the drafting of
ponds, rivers, and the like, wherever possible.



      (4)   The use of throw-away utensils and plates is encouraged
and recommended at all eating establishments.



      (5)   To operate an evaporative air conditioner which recycles
water except during operating hours of business.



(Ord. passed 8-8-88; Am. Ord. passed 5-14-18)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 52.35  LIFTING OF WATER SHORTAGE RESTRICTIONS.



   (A)   Water shortage conditions will expire when the City Manager,
after consultation with the City Council and upon recommendation of the Water
Superintendent, deems that the condition which caused the alert was abated.



   (B)   The expiration or cancellation of a water shortage declaration
shall be promptly and extensively publicized.



(Ord. passed 8-8-88; Am. Ord. passed 5-14-18)



§ 52.36  PENALTIES AND DISCONNECTION FOR NONCOMPLIANCE.



   Any person who violates any provision of this subchapter shall be
subject to the following civil penalties:



   (A)   Any residential water customer who violates any provisions of
this subchapter shall be subject to civil penalties. Civil penalties for a
residential violation of Stage II or III mandatory restrictions shall be as
follows:



      (1)   A written warning for the first offense.



      (2)   A civil penalty in the amount of $100 for the second
offense.



      (3)   A civil penalty in the amount of $200 for the third
offense.



      (4)   Disconnection of service for the fourth and successive
offenses.



   (B)   Any nonresidential water customer who violates any provision
of this subchapter shall be subject to civil penalties double in amount to
the above penalties.



   (C)   Violations shall be accumulated by all persons so long as the
restrictions contained in this subchapter, in any of its stages, are
continuously in effect, and until no stage of this subchapter has been in
effect for a period of one calendar year.



      (1)   Violations of any of the mandatory restrictions of any
stage shall accumulate with violations of other stages.



      (2)   Should a person move, or cease and renew service during
the period described herein, the person's violations shall continue to
accumulate as if such move or cessation had not occurred.



   (D)   Each day's continuing violation shall be a separate and
distinct criminal and civil offense. Each violation of the subchapter shall
be a separate offense even if occurring on the same day.



   (E)   Notwithstanding the above penalty structure, pursuant to the
provisions of G.S. § 162A-88, service may be temporarily discontinued for
willful disregard of this subchapter, and fees may be imposed before
restoration of service.



      (1)   For non-potable uses, this disconnection may be without
prior notice.



      (2)   In the event of such discontinuation, the meter may be
removed and all tap fees and deposits forfeited.



      (3)   Reconnection will only be made by payment of current due
amounts, penalties as set forth above, and new tap fees.



      (4)   It shall be unlawful for customers to reconnect water
service discontinued for noncompliance.



         (a)   Any customer reconnecting such services shall be
guilty of meter tampering.



         (b)   A fine of $500 will be assessed for such violation.



(Ord. passed 8-8-88; Am. Ord. passed 1-14-08; Am. Ord. passed 5-14-18)



CHAPTER 53:  NATURAL GAS



Section



   53.01   Authority to establish rules and regulations



   53.02   Natural gas incentive rates



   53.03   Charge for new taps



   53.04   Construction of new taps



§ 53.01  AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH RULES AND REGULATIONS.



   (A)   The City Council may from time to time establish rules and
regulations regarding the opera- tion, maintenance, and use of the natural
gas system.



   (B)   Such rules, regulations, and policies shall be in form readily
available to the public.



§ 53.02  NATURAL GAS INCENTIVE RATES.



   (A)   The city will rebate to the developer, contractor or homeowner
“all or a portion of” the actual charge for the natural gas tap as an
incentive to the natural gas system customer. The amount of the rebate will
depend on the number of “connections” (gas fired appliances) installed
within the residence. The amount of the rebate shall be set forth in the
annual budget ordinance.



   (B)   The house or apartment must connect to the city's natural gas
distribution system.



   (C)   The customer or developer must enter into a written agreement
with the city to use the city's natural gas to fuel all of the gas fired
appliances for which the rebate has been given for a period of at least ten
years.



      (1)   Any customer who subsequently wants to use a different
fuel must first refund the rebate to the city.  If a developer received the
rebate, the current homeowner wishing to switch fuels must refund the
rebate.  This refund shall not apply if the appliance has been utilized for
which a customer or a developer received the rebate, for a period of at least
ten years.



      (2)   The refund required under division (C)(1) of this
section shall not be prorated for any reason.



   (D)   The rebates will be given for the initial installation in new
houses or apartments and for change-outs in existing houses or apartments
from electric or fuel oil to natural gas water heaters and/or space heating
units or the first time installation or change-outs from electric to gas
units for the other appliances named.



   (E)   A customer may qualify for either rebate, or both.



   (F)   The rebates will be given after installation, and passing
inspection by the city's Natural Gas Department.



   (G)   In the case of retrofitting an electric or fuel oil unit to a
natural gas unit, the city will give a rebate for the actual cost of the
retrofit, or the normal rebate amount, whichever is less.



   (H)   Dual-fuel source units shall not qualify for either rebate.



(Ord. 93-9-2, passed 9- -93; Am. Ord. 94-8-3, passed 8-8-94; Am. Ord. 96-1-1,
passed 1-8-96; Am. Ord. passed 2-9-04)



§ 53.03  CHARGE FOR NEW TAPS.



   (A)   All gas tap fees, or charges will be set forth as adopted in
the city’s annual budget ordinance.  This change shall not modify the
current extension policy and it shall remain in effect.



   (B)   (1)   The natural gas tap fee will be waived for
residential customers with a minimum of gas hot water heater or gas furnace
for a period of two years.



      (2)   The waiver is available only for standard AC250 and
AL425 meters and excess flow valve fees will still be applicable.



(Ord. 93-9-2, passed 9- -93; Am. Ord. passed 2-9-04; Am. Res. passed 12-12-11)



§ 53.04  CONSTRUCTION OF NEW TAPS.



   The city will no longer make natural gas taps for residential or
commercial customers until there is evidence submitted to the Gas
Superintendent's satisfaction that the applicant intends to immediately
connect to the gas system and become an active customer. The City Manager and
the Gas Superintendent shall develop procedures for the implementation of
this policy.



(Ord. passed 8-8-94)



CHAPTER 54:  SOLID WASTE

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 54.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ANIMAL and AGRICULTURAL WASTES. Principally, the manure and crop
residue from various agricultural pursuits including dairying and raising of
livestock and poultry.  Animal waste also includes, in addition to items
mentioned above, wastes from stables, kennels, pet pens, chicken coops,
veterinary establishments, and the like.



   ASHES.  The residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, and other
combustible material in homes, stores, institutions, and small industrial
establishments for the purposes of heating, cooking, and disposing of
combustible waste material.  Ashes are usually com- posed of a mixture of
fine powdery residue, cinders, clinkers, and small portions of unburned or
partially burned fuel or other materials.  Ashes shall contain no live
embers or other burning materials.



   BUILDING RUBBISH.  Any materials or other substances accumulated as a
result of repairs or additions to existing buildings, construction of new
buildings, demolition of existing buildings, or moving of buildings,
including but not limited to bricks, stone, concrete, wood, lumber, siding,
shingles of any type, and the like.



   CONTRACTED SERVICES (BRUSH).  Any tree or shrubbery trimming resulting
from work performed by landscaping or tree service contractors or other
commercial workers, including, but not limited to land clearing work.  This
shall also apply to any job performed by anyone, including the owner or
resident of the property, that is of such scale that heavy equipment as used
by contractors is needed to complete the work.



   DECLARED NUISANCE.  Anything that causes injury or damage to the
health or life of any person or that causes an offensive odor.



   DEAD ANIMALS.  Those animals that die naturally or from disease or are
killed accidentally. Condemned animals or parts from slaughterhouses or
similar places are not included in this item.



      (1)   SMALL DEAD ANIMALS.  Dogs, cats, rabbits, squirrels,
chickens, rats, and other similar animals.



      (2)   LARGE DEAD ANIMALS.  Horses, cows, goats, sheep, hogs,
and other similar animals.



   GARBAGE.  The byproduct of animal or vegetable foodstuffs, resulting
from the handling, preparation, cooking, and serving of food, or other matter
which is subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction, or the generation of
noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay may serve
as breeding or feeding material for flies, other insects, or animals.



   HAZARDOUS REFUSE.  Materials such as paint, poison, acids, caustics,
chemicals, infected materials, offal, fecal matter, and explosives and any
other material declared hazardous by the U.S. EPA or any other responsible
agency.



   HOUSEHOLD TRASH.  Any waste accumulation of paper, sweepings, dust,
rags, bottles, cans, or other matter of any kind, other than garbage, which
is usually attendant to housekeeping.



   INDUSTRIAL WASTE.  All waste, including solids, semi-solids, sludges
and liquids, created by factories, processing plants, or manufacturing
enterprises.



   JUNK.  Any item, including but not limited to, dilapidated furniture,
appliances, machinery, equipment, building materials, automobile parts,
tires, or other items which are either in a wholly or partially rusted,
wrecked, junked, dismantled, or inoperative condition.



   LITTER.  Any garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse, can, bottle, box,
container, wrapper, paper, paper product, tire, appliance, mechanical
equipment or part, building or construction material, tool, machinery, wood,
motor vehicle or equipment, sludge from a waste treatment facility, water
supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility, from domestic,
industrial, commercial, mining, agricultural, or governmental operations. 
LITTER does not include political pamphlets, handbills, religious tracts,
newspapers, and other such printed materials the unsolicited distribution of
which is protected by the Constitution of the United States or the
Constitution of North Carolina.



   MULTI-RESIDENTIAL UNIT.  Any duplex, apartment, group of apartments or
condominiums, or housing units designed for or occupied by more than one
family.



   NORMAL USE (ROLL OUT CONTAINER), RESIDENTIAL.  Placement of any
variety of both combustible and noncombustible solid waste materials from
households, including such items as plastic, waste paper, rags, sweepings,
and similar waste materials ordinarily accumulated around a house.



   NORMAL USE (ROLL OUT CONTAINER), BUSINESS.  Placement of any variety
of both combustible and noncombustible solid waste materials from businesses,
including such items as plastic, waste paper, rags, sweepings, and similar
waste materials ordinarily accumulated in general business operations.  This
list shall not include oil, oil cans, paint/paint thinners, and the like.



   PRIVATE PROPERTY.  Property owned by any person, not a political
entity, including but not limited to, yards, grounds, driveways, entrances of
passage- ways, parking areas, storage areas, vacant land, bodies of water and
including sidewalks, grass strips, one-half of alleys, curbs, or
right-of-ways up to the edge of the pavement of any public street.



   RECYCLABLE MATERIAL.  Newspapers, magazines, glass bottles, steel and
aluminum cans and plastic drink bottles or other such material as designated
by the state Public Works Director.



   REFUSE.  Solid waste consisting of garbage, household trash, or
business trash.



   ROLLCART.  A plastic, mobile, top-loading, residential refuse
container of 90-gallon capacity compatible to the city collection equipment.



   SINGLE RESIDENTIAL UNIT.  Any dwelling place designed for or occupied
by one family.



   WEEDS AND GRASS.  Weeds and grass in excess of 12 inches in height. 
Weeds and grass on heavily wooded lots where equipment cannot maneuver on the
lot because of the density are not included in this definition.



   YARD TRASH.  Accumulation of lawn, grass, or shrubbery cuttings or
clippings, bushes, limbs, and dry leaf rakings free of dirt, rocks, large
branches, and bulky or noncombustible material.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)



§ 54.02  DISPOSAL OF REFUSE IN CITY LIMITS BY NONRESIDENTS PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation not
a resident of the city to bring trash, refuse, rubbish, or other forms of
waste into the city and to discard it or to deposit it for collection by the
city.  An example of a violation of this section is a person who owns or is
employed by a business within the city limits, but who lives outside the city
limits, bringing his household garbage into the city and depositing it or
otherwise leaving it for collection by the city.



   (B)   Ownership of trash, refuse, rubbish, or other forms of waste,
including designated recyclable materials, set out or placed in receptacles
for collection by the city shall be vested in the city.



(Ord. 88-1, passed 12-12-88)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.03  PROHIBITED DISPOSAL OF WASTES. 



   (A)   Prohibited disposal of wastes generally.



      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, throw, or
otherwise deposit upon any city street or sidewalk, or in any public place
not designated for such purpose, any scrap paper, bottles, cans, glass, rags,
feathers, building material scraps, tree and shrubbery trimmings, liquid
wastes, lubricating or fuel oil, flammable or combustible wastes or any other
trash, refuse, or debris.



      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or cause
to be obstructed the free flow of water in, over, along, upon, or through any
drainage way in any public street or other public way, or in any creek,
stream, or other natural drainage course within the city limits by depositing
any trash, refuse, tree or shrubbery trimmings, building material scraps, or
other matter therein.



      (3)   It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit, or
cause any gasoline, fuel oil, Nephro, or other flammable liquid, or any
wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance, or any lubricating oil,
grease or detergent, to drain into any drainage ditch, street gutter,
culvert, or other drainage way in any public street or other public way or in
any creek, stream, or other natural drainage course within the city limits. 
It shall also be illegal to place any type of lubricating oil, or other
above- named materials in any container provided by the city for garbage pick
up.  All lubricating oils should be taken to recycling centers.



      (4)   No person, including but not limited to, any firm,
organization, private corporation, or governing body, agents or employees of
any municipal corporation shall intentionally or recklessly throw, scatter,
spill or place or intentionally or recklessly throw, scatter, spill or placed
or otherwise dispose of any litter upon any public property or private
property not owned by him within this State or in any waters under the
jurisdiction of city, including, but not limited to, any public street,
highway, public park, lake, river, campground, forest land, recreational
area, trailer park, highway, road, street or alley except as the same shall
be deposited into a litter receptacle in such a manner that the litter will
be prevented from being carried away or deposited by the elements upon any
part of such private or public property or waters.  When litter is blown,
scattered, spilled, thrown or placed from a vehicle or water craft, the
operator thereof shall be presumed to have committed such offense.  This
presumption, however does not apply to a vehicle transporting agricultural
products or supplies when the litter from that vehicle is a nontoxic,
biodegradable agricultural product or supply.



   (B)   Waste matter subject to scattering.  Except as provided in
§§ 54.20 through 54.28 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person
to deposit or permit to accumulate any waste matter or refuse of any
description which is subject to scattering by animals or the elements of
nature on that part of any property which is adjacent to a street or public
place. This section shall not prohibit the burning of yard trash on one's own
property when approved and permits issued as per § 91.40 of this code.  Any
burning other than that permitted in § 91.40 shall be prohibited.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.04  TRANSPORTATION OF REFUSE.



   No swill, slops, garbage, bones, offal, kitchen waste, or refuse shall
be transported through the city streets except in watertight metal containers
with tight- fitting covers.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.05  DEPOSITING DEBRIS IN CATCH BASINS, MANHOLES, OR DRAINS.



   No person shall throw, drop, or deposit leaves, shrubs, or any other
debris into any catch basin, manhole, or drainage ditch or structure in the
city.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.06  MAINTENANCE OF PREMISES; DUTY OF OCCUPANT.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every owner, occupant, and persons in
charge of any premises within the city to maintain such premises free of any
accumulation of garbage, rubbish, appliances, discarded household items and
other similar items. The unscreened storage of materials not customarily
stored outdoors in residential neighborhoods is prohibited, including but not
limited to: tires, construction materials, household items, broken toys and
other miscellaneous house/yard debris.



   (B)   It shall be the duty of every owner, occupant, and person in
charge of any premises within the city to maintain such premises free of
noxious weeds and grass, undergrowth, and other vegetation which affords a
harboring or breeding place for vermin, insects, rodents, or reptiles, and
grass which is 12 inches or more in height, not grown for agricultural
purposes, shall be deemed undergrowth within the meaning of this section.



   (C)   The existence of any of the following conditions on any vacant
or occupied parcel of land within the corporate limits of the city is hereby
declared to be dangerous or prejudicial to the public health or safety and to
constitute a public nuisance:



      (1)   The uncontrolled growth of weeds or grass to a height of
18 inches or more within 100 feet of any residential structure or any
occupied nonresidential structure except in the downtown business district in
which all weeds or grass must be maintained.  This division shall not apply
to areas that are not accessible or controllable by reasonable means, or to
natural areas which customarily exist in a natural condition as determined by
the Code Enforcement Officer.



      (2)   Any accumulation of animal or vegetable matter that is
offensive by virtue of odors or vapors or which is inhabited by rats, mice,
snakes, or vermin of any kind which may be dangerous to public health.



      (3)   Any accumulation of solid wastes not in compliance with
this chapter including litter, garbage, trash and other refuse.



      (4)   Open wells.



      (5)   An accumulation of stagnant water causing or threatening
to cause the inhabitation thereof by mosquitos.



      (6)   Any automobile part, including but not limited to tires,
motors, batteries, and the like.



      (7)   Any piles of wood, furniture, clothes, building
materials, and the like.



      (8)   Any other condition detrimental to the public health
which violates the rules and regulations of the Gaston County Health
Department.



      (9)   Junk, trash and litter. It shall be unlawful for any
person to have on their premises materials that would create a littered
condition, such as dilapidated and/or broken furniture, appliances,
machinery, building materials, automobile parts, tires or any other items
which are in a wholly or partially rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled or
inoperative condition. Such items may be stored on the premises when they are
placed in a completely enclosed building or dwelling.



   (D)   Keeping upholstered furniture which is not manufactured for
outdoor use in outdoor areas where such furniture is visible to neighbors and
passersby in the public right-of-way is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
Accordingly, no person shall place, use, keep, store or maintain any
upholstered furniture not manufactured for outdoor use, including, without
limitation, upholstered chairs, upholstered couches and mattresses, in or on
any porch, patio or other unenclosed structure where such furniture is
visible from a public right-of-way or from the ground level of adjacent
property, and no property owner or property manager shall knowingly permit
any such activity to occur on property owned or managed by such person.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Ord. passed 11-8-10; Am. Res. passed 4-11-11; Am.
Res. passed 7-9-12)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.07  NOTICE TO ABATE VIOLATION.



   Upon investigation and finding by any city officer that there exists on
any city property conditions constituting a public nuisance as described in
this subchapter, the Code Enforcement Officer shall notify the respondent of
such conditions. The respondent is the person in possession of the property
where a public nuisance is located, as well as the owner of such property, if
different from the former. The notice shall be by first class mail and
certified mail or by first class mail and in person by a sworn officer of the
city or county. Service shall be deemed sufficient if the certified mail is
unclaimed or refused, but the regular mail is not returned by the post office
within ten days after mailing. The notice shall order the abatement of the
premises within 15 days of the receipt of such notice except for the public
nuisance described in § 54.06(B). The notice of such conditions as described
in § 54.06(B) shall order the abatement of the premises within ten days of
receipt of such notice.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Res. passed 4-11-11)



§ 54.08  APPEAL OF ORDER OF ABATEMENT.



   At any time before the expiration of the 15-day abatement period
specified in § 54.07 of this chapter, the respondent may request a hearing
before the City Council to appeal the finding of the Code Enforcement Officer
that a public nuisance exists on the premises.  The request for hearing must
be in writing and must be filed in the office of the City Manager.  The City
Manager shall set a time for the hearing, being the next scheduled Council
meeting. The initial abatement order shall be temporarily suspended pending
such hearing.  At the hearing, the individual shall be given the opportunity
to present evidence to refute the findings which supported the abatement
order.  Upon completion of the hearing, the Council shall consider the
evidence before it and shall either revoke the initial order, issue a final
order which differs from the initial order, or reinstate the initial order as
a final abatement order. No delay or postponement of decision will be made
concerning matters that have been deemed public nuisances.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)



§ 54.09  ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE BY CITY.



   Upon the occurrence of either of the following conditions the Code
Enforcement Officer shall cause the condition to be removed or otherwise
remedied by having employees of the city and/or private contractors go upon
the premises and remove or otherwise abate such nuisance under the
supervision of an officer or employee designated by the Code Enforcement
Officer when:



   (A)   A hearing is requested and held under § 54.08 of this chapter
resulting in either a final order with modifications or the reinstatement of
the initial order as a final order, and such order is not complied with
within five days from adjournment of the hearing.



   (B)   No hearing is requested or held, and the respondent, having
been ordered to abate such public nuisance fails, neglects, or refuses to
abate or remove the condition constituting the nuisance within 15 days from
receipt of the order.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)



§ 54.10  REQUEST BY OWNER FOR ABATEMENT BY CITY; CHARGES; LIENS.



   (A)   The owner of property where a public nuisance has been found
to exist may request the city, in writing, to remove such condition, and the
city may remove the offending condition pursuant to such request.  The full
cost of said removal shall be borne by the requesting owner.



   (B)   (1)   The actual cost incurred by the city in removing or
otherwise remedying a public nuisance pursuant to this section shall be
charged to the owner of the offending property, and the owner shall pay these
charges within 30 days after receiving from the city a statement of charges.



      (2)   In the event charges for the removal or abatement of a
public nuisance are not paid within 30 days after receipt of a statement of
charges under division (B)(1) of this section, such charges shall become a
lien upon the land where the public nuisance existed and shall be collected
as unpaid taxes, as provided in G.S. § 160A-193.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)



§ 54.11  GASTON COUNTY LANDFILL FEES.



   The City Council may establish and fix from time to time such landfill
charges and other fees as necessary.



§ 54.12  RECYCLING.



   The City Council may establish and fix from time to time such fees to
provide recycling collection service and add said fees to customer utility
bills.



REFUSE COLLECTION SERVICE



§ 54.20  PERMIT REQUIRED TO ENGAGE IN BUSINESS OF WASTE COLLECTION OR BRUSH
CLEARING.



   (A)   Waste collection business.  No person shall engage in the
business of collecting, hauling, or transporting in the city, any waste
without first obtaining a permit from the City Manager.



   (B)   Brush/land clearing.  A permit will be required for land
clearing or brush clearing that meets the definition of contracted services
as defined in § 54.01 of this chapter.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.21  COLLECTION PRACTICES.



   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, and except in
the case of emergency arising from an act of God or under circumstances over
which the Public Works Department has no control, the Public Works Department
or its agents shall collect, remove, and dispose of certain refuse in
residential and general business sections of the city once per week. In
business districts, twice per week collection may be offered when deemed
necessary by the city.



   (B)   Industrial waste shall be collected, removed, and disposed of
by the operator of the factory, plant, or enterprise creating or causing the
same in accordance with the provisions of this code.



   (C)   Construction debris. The city does not collect construction
debris. Landfill regulations pertaining to construction materials prohibit
the city from picking up any type of construction debris. Disposal of all
debris from do-it-yourself homeowner projects and independent contractor work
shall be the responsibility of the person doing the work. This includes, but
is not limited to, lumber, shingles, roofing, ceilings, flooring, brick, and
other construction materials. Fines and other charges may be levied for
collection of unauthorized debris.



   (D)   No refuse shall be collected where refuse receptacles cannot
be serviced by sanitation personnel without unlocking, opening, or reaching
over a door, gate, or similar obstacle, encountering a porch, carport or
garage, encountering a dog, or otherwise being denied reasonable access by
parked vehicles, yard tools, equipment, or similar objects.



   (E)   Once an established collection route is established, any
changes shall be advertised in the local newspaper once at least 15 days
before such changes become effective; provided, that such notice may be given
by other means and within a lesser period of time in cases of emergency.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Res. passed 9-12-11)



§ 54.22  CONTAINERS FOR REFUSE; REGULATIONS.



   (A)   Every person owning or occupying a single- and/or multi-family
residential unit shall store all garbage and refuse in containers, as
specified herein, so as to eliminate wind driven debris and unsightly litter
in and about their premises.



   (B)   (1)   Each residential unit, not using dumpster service,
shall use at least one 96-gallon roll- out container provided by the city or
the city’s agent. Additional containers, if needed, may be obtained for
additional fees. Containers remain the property of the city or its agent.
Solid waste containers shall not be removed from the residence where
assigned. The maximum number or roll-out containers allowed per residence
shall be two.



      (2)   Each residential unit, not using dumpster service, shall
have at least one recycling container provided by the city or the city’s
agent. Additional containers, if needed, may be obtained for additional fees.
Containers remain the property of the city or its agent. Recycling containers
shall not be removed from the residence where assigned. The maximum number of
recycling containers allowed shall be two.



   (C)   All persons doing business within the city limits shall use
containers as outlined in this section if dumpster service is not utilized. A
96-gallon container may be provided, when feasible and in accordance with
city code regulations. The maximum number of containers will be determined by
staff.



   (D)   Containers shall be used for the purpose of holding regular
household refuse.  No items such as sticks, yard clippings, leaves, and the
like may be placed in roll-out containers.



   (E)   Stones, bricks, iron items, and the like shall not be placed
in the containers.



   (F)   Damaged or missing containers shall be reported to the city.
If a container is stolen, a police report shall be filed by the resident.
Malicious damage may be assessed against property owners and/or tenants of
the property.



   (G)   Residents are required to clean roll-out containers when
needed to keep down odor and insects.



   (H)   The city may refuse to collect the following types of solid
wastes and it shall be unlawful for any person to place any of the following
in any container or receptacle for collection by the city:



      (1)   Hazardous refuse and industrial waste. All such refuse
shall be stored in suitable leakproof containers that will ensure that no
such refuse or wastes leak or spill onto any public or private property.  It
shall be the responsibility of the person in possession of the premises to
see that it is disposed of properly.



      (2)   Oils, lubricants or any other type matter that may
damage the container, cause it to leak, or erode wheel parts.



      (3)   Contagious disease refuse.  The removal of clothing,
bedding, or other refuse from homes or the places where highly infectious
diseases have occurred shall be performed under the supervision and direction
of the County Health Department.



      (4)   Human tissues or wastes resulting from operation,
autopsy, or obstetrical procedures or any other material of similar nature.



      (5)   Materials of any kind or nature, including ashes, which
may contain any hot or live coals or fire.



      (6)   Raw or uncooked seafood waste (fish heads, and the like).



      (7)   Dead animals of any sort.



      (8)   Hypodermic needles and/or any other sharp object.



      (9)   Any other items that are prohibited from disposal in the
Gaston County Landfill.



   (I)   Violations of this section shall be punished as spelled out in
G.S. § 14-4.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Res. passed 9-12-11)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.23  [RESERVED].



§ 54.24  PRE-COLLECTION PRACTICES.



   The occupant, whether owner or tenant of single- and multi-family
residential units requiring a roll-out cart to store refuse shall adhere to
the following pre- collection practices:



   (A)   Garbage and general rubbish shall be stored only in
receptacles approved by § 54.22 of this chapter and such receptacles shall
be covered at all times.



   (B)   All dangerous items, such as broken glass, and the like, shall
be securely wrapped to avoid injury to collection crews.



   (C)   Any refuse shall have liquid drained from it prior to being
placed in the container for collection.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Res. passed 9-12-11)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.25  POINT OF COLLECTION.



   (A)   Time of collection.  All solid waste and recycling containers
shall be placed at a location designated by the city not more than 24 hours
before the time set for collection. Containers shall be removed from the
street and stored away from the front of the property prior to 9:00 p.m. on
the day of collection.



   (B)   Handicapped provisions.  In the event a resident is
physically unable to place the cart at the curbside and there is no one
living in the household that will place it at curbside for him or her, the
resident may request special pick-up consideration.  All requests are to be
made to the city and will require a doctor’s certification prior to
approval.



   (C)   Receptacles.  Receptacles or containers other than those
allowed in § 54.22 of this chapter may be considered solid waste and may be
disposed of by the city or its agent.



   (D)   Business building collection.  Business building collection
areas shall be from the rear, side, or  in  certain  cases, front. 
Where  front  collection points are used, empty containers shall not be
left on the street after sundown of collection day.  The best collection
location for businesses shall be determined by the city.



   (E)   Street litter containers.  Businesses shall not use street
litter containers for the disposal of business- generated trash.



   (F)   Bulk collection. The city may collect minimal bulk items, such
as furniture and the like. Items for bulk collection shall be placed at
curbside. This service shall be available to residential units only. This
does not include construction or building materials. Fines and other charges
may be levied for collection of unauthorized debris.



   (G)   Appliances.  Appliances will be picked up on a bi-monthly
schedule. 



   (H)   Yard waste.  Yard clippings, leaves, and the like shall be
placed in plastic bags at curbside for pickup. These shall not be placed in
roll-out containers. The city will remove leaves using a leaf vacuum machine
between the dates of October 1 and April 1.



   (I)   The owner or owner’s agent for multi-family units shall
provide a central location area for placement of roll-out containers for
pick-up.  This location shall be one that meets the standards set forth in
this chapter and it will be subject to approval of the city.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Ord. 94-9-3, passed 9-12-94; Am. Ord. 97-4-1,
passed 4- -97; Am. Res. passed 9-12-11)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.26  MULTI-FAMILY SANITATION SERVICES.



   (A)   The city, either itself or through its agents, will provide
residential garbage collection services on the same basis as single-family
residences to any multi-family complex that the service was being provided to
prior to the adoption of this section (all except Park Terrace and Baytree
Apartments).



   (B)   For all multi-family facilities built or brought into the city
after the effective date of this section containing five or more units on a
single site, the owner shall provide tenants with garbage and trash
collection service at his or her expense.



   (C)   All multi-family facilities at which the city provides garbage
collection service under this section shall also participate in the city’s
recycling program, if an when offered to multi-family sites, and shall pay
the required fees for recycling on the same basis that the water and landfill
fees are charged, such fees to be adjusted by City Council from time to time.



(Ord. 93-10-1, passed 10-11-93; Am. Res. passed 9-12-11)



§ 54.27  YARD WASTE AND LEAF COLLECTION PRACTICES.



   Tree, hedge, and shrubbery trimmings shall be placed at the curb for
collection in accordance with the following guidelines:



   (A)   No tree trunks, branches, limbs, and the like, larger than six
inches in diameter, longer than five feet in length, shall be collected by
the city.



   (B)   Tree and shrubbery limbs shall have protruding branches or
limbs of a size not to be blown about and scattered by the elements, they
shall be effectively tied so as to avoid wind driven debris and unsightly
litter conditions.  Thorny vegetation shall be placed near the curb in
small, neat piles.



   (C)   Collection of tree and shrubbery trimmings shall be limited to
six yards, uncompacted per week, per residence, but additional service may be
approved by the Public Works Director upon request.



   (D)   Tree limbs shall be separated from smaller shrubbery trimmings
to allow for chipping. All brush shall be put in separate piles from other
general debris.



   (E)   Limbs and cuttings must be placed with butt or cut end toward
the street or public alley and must be of the size that can be handled by one
person.



   (F)   The city shall not collect tree and shrubbery trimmings
resulting from contracted work, as defined in § 54.01 of this chapter, nor
shall the city collect, remove, or assist in the removal of tree stumps,
small rocks, tree trunks, heavy grass, or dirt resulting from the clearing of
any property of any kind.  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or
deposit any such item at curbside at any time.



   (G)   The city shall remove leaves through the use of a leaf vacuum
machine beginning October 1 until March 1. Please rake early and frequently.
Leaves should be raked to the edge of the road, not into the street or onto
the sidewalk. Leaf pickup is for leaves only. Do not mix other debris such as
trash, limbs, brush, rocks, flowers, roots or garbage in the leaf pile.  Do
not allow children or animals to play in the leaf pile. Leaves should be
bagged for pickup at times not covered above.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Ord. passed 7-8-02; Am. Res. passed 9-12-11) 
Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.28  WASTES THE CITY WILL NOT COLLECT.



   (A)   The city will not collect the following types of solid and/or
liquid wastes and it shall be illegal for any person to place any of the
following in any container or receptacle or along the city right-of-way or
curbside for collection:



      (1)   Hazardous refuse and industrial wastes.



      (2)   Contagious disease refuse.



      (3)   Building materials (incidental amounts not associated
with repairs, alterations, construction, or demolition may be picked up).



      (4)   Any materials, including ashes, containing hot or live
coals.



      (5)   Large dead animals.



      (6)   Barrels and/or drums with any liquid substance in same.



      (7)   Motor oils, lubricants, anti-freeze, and the like.



   (B)   It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to
legally and properly dispose of these items.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92; Am. Res. passed 9-12-11)  Penalty, see § 54.99



HAZARDOUS AND INDUSTRIAL WASTES



§ 54.35  HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to place any hazardous refuse, as defined
in § 54.01 of this chapter, in any receptacle used for collection by the
city.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to place in any container, at curbside,
or in any catch basin, manhole, or drainage ditch, or structure, any
materials considered to be hazardous refuse by the U.S. EPA or any other
responsible agency.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.36  INDUSTRIAL WASTES.



   The city shall not collect any type industrial wastes, solid, liquid,
hazardous, or highly combustible.  It shall be unlawful to place industrial
waste in any container or receptacle for collection by the city. Industrial
waste shall be collected, removed, and disposed of by the operator of the
factory or industry creating the same.



(Ord. passed 2-10-92)  Penalty, see § 54.99



§ 54.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter for
which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be subject to the penalty
provided in § 10.99.



   (B)   A civil penalty in the amount of $10 may be assessed for the
violations of § 54.25(A) and collected as provided in § 10.99 of this code.



   (C)   Any person who violates § 54.03(A) is guilty of a misdemeanor
punishable by a fine of not less than $50 nor more than $100 for the first
offense is punishable by a fine of not less than $100.  In addition, the
court may require the violator to pick up litter or perform other labor
commensurate with the offense committed.



   (D)   Civil remedy for violation.  If the city or any person
sustains damages arising out of a violation of § 54.03, a court in a civil
action may order the person to pay the city or the injured party up to three
times the actual damages or $100, whichever is greater.  In addition, the
court shall order the person to pay the city's or the injured party's court
costs and attorney's fees.



(Ord. 94-9-3, passed 9-12-94  Am. Ord. passed 9-14-98)



CHAPTER 55:  STREETS; SIDEWALKS; PUBLIC PLACES
