GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 55.01  DAMAGING OF PUBLIC STREETS, SIDEWALKS, AND THE LIKE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to in any manner damage any city
street or sidewalk, or any easement or right-of-way of the city which has
been dedicated or otherwise established for public use.



('75 Code, § 13-1)  (Ord. 38, passed 9-4-39) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.02  OBSTRUCTING VIEW NEAR INTERSECTIONS. 



   No person shall plant, install, or maintain any tree, bush, or other
obstruction or screen which is more than 30 inches above the ground in
height, between the curb and sidewalk along any street or other right-of-way
at any place within 50 feet of an intersection of streets or other
rights-of-way.



('75 Code, § 13-2)  (Ord. passed 1-10-72)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.03  USE OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS DURING CONSTRUCTION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to walk on, ride or lead any
animal, or drive any vehicle, over, across, or along any sidewalk or street
while such street or sidewalk is under construction or is being repaired and
barricades or signs have been posted to give notice of such prohibition; and
it shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person knowingly to tamper with or
molest any such construction or repair work or any such sign or barricade.



('75 Code, § 13-3) (Ord. 50, passed  - - ) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.04  REMOVAL OR DISTURBANCE OF COMPONENTS OF STREETS OR SIDEWALKS.



   No person shall, without proper authority, disturb or remove any sand,
dirt, or other component of any street, sidewalk, or public place within the
city.



('75 Code, § 13-4)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.05  STRUCTURES AND OVERGROWTH AS PUBLIC NUISANCE.



   (A)   No person shall allow to be erected or maintain any building,
fence, or other structure so as to encroach upon or obstruct any street,
sidewalk, or public place within the city.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow from
property which he owns, occupies or which is under his control, any bushes,
shrubs, or other growth, to obstruct or encroach the paved portion of a
public street at a height of less than 14 feet, or to cause or allow any such
bushes, shrubs, or growth, or other obstructions to obstruct or encroach a
public sidewalk at a height of less than nine feet above such sidewalk.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow grass,
vines, weeds, or other vegetation to grow from property which he owns or
occupies under his control, over, onto, or across any public street or
sidewalk, or to cause, or allow the area between the owner's property and the
curb or street pavement to become overgrown with weeds or other plants, or to
allow any dirt, or other debris to build up on any sidewalk.



   (D)   Any violation of this section or any of its divisions is
hereby declared a public nuisance, and if not corrected by the responsible
person within ten days after being given written notice of the violation by
the city, the city may summarily abate the nuisance.



   (E)   The actual cost incurred by the city in removing or otherwise
remedying a public nuisance pursuant to this section shall be charged to the
record owner of the offending property; provided however, if the violation
arises out of dirt or debris covering a sidewalk, the owner of the offending
property shall not be charged with the costs of abatement unless the city
shall have first cleared the sidewalk once since February 1, 1993, or the
sidewalk was constructed after February 1, 1993.  Otherwise, the owner shall
pay these charges within 30 days after receiving from the city a statement of
charges under this division. Such charges shall become and remain a lien upon
the land or premises where the public nuisance existed until paid, and shall
be collected as unpaid taxes as provided in G.S. § 160A-193.



('75 Code, § 13-5) (Am. Ord. passed 3-8-93; Am. Ord. passed 8-9-93) 
Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.06  OBSTRUCTION PROHIBITED EXCEPT PURSUANT TO PERMIT.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to place anything on any public
street, sidewalk, or public place, or in any gutter, which will impede travel
or traffic or annoy pedestrians.  This prohibition shall not be applicable
to the use of sidewalks by merchants for the display of merchandise or
storage of materials, nor to the erection in streets and upon sidewalks of
booths or stands, nor to the use of streets and sidewalks by contractors for
temporary storage of lumber, and the like, during the course of any
construction project, when so authorized by permit granted by the City
Manager.



('75 Code, § 13-6)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.07  PLACES OF BUSINESS TO KEEP SIDEWALKS CLEAR.



   Every occupant of a store or other place of business in front of which
the sidewalk is paved with stone, brick, asphalt, or concrete shall remove
any accumulation of snow, ice, or other such obstruction from the sidewalk
within four hours of the end of a storm event or within four hours after
sunrise following a night storm.  Any violation of this section is hereby
declared to be public nuisance and the city may abate such nuisance
immediately pursuant to § 55.05(E) of this chapter.



(Ord. passed 3-8-93; Am. Ord. passed 8-9-93)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.08  MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR.



   It is the responsibility of the abutting property owner to maintain any
property, driveway, steps or walkway servicing the premises between the
property line and the curb of a paved street including any property located
between a sidewalk and the abutting street. The City Council may exercise any
reasonable amount of enforcement necessary to maintain such areas at the
expense of the property owner should it be necessary.



SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS



§ 55.15  SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS.



   In making special assessments, the City may employ the following
procedures:



   (A)   Petition. Upon receipt of a petition from one or more owners
of abutting property which 50% or more of the total street frontage is in one
ownership, the Council may order the making of any local improvement. The
Council may assess the cost thereof against the abutting property in the same
manner and following the same procedures set out in the general laws of the
State for making special assessments against property benefited by local
improvements.



   (B)   Limited Assessment Permitted.  The Council may order the
making of any local improvement and assess the cost thereof, except the
City's portion, if any, against only a limited number of abutting properties
if the owners of those properties submit a petition asking that the
improvement be made and that the total amount to be assessed for the
improvement be assessed only against their properties.



   (C)   Assessment by Council without Petition. If, in the Council's
judgment, which shall be conclusive, the abutting property to be assessed
will be benefited in an amount at least equal to the assessment, no petition
for local improvements shall be necessary and the Council may order the
making of any such local improvement and assess the cost thereof against
abutting properties in the following cases:



      (1)   Streets.



         (a)   When any street or part of a street is unsafe.



         (b)   The improvement of a street or part of a street
not more than 1,500 linear feet in length is necessary to connect a street
already paved; or the improvement of a street or part of a street is
necessary to connect a paved street, or portion thereof, with a paved
highway; or the improvement of a street or part of a street is necessary to
provide a paved approach to a railroad, street grade, separation, or bridge;
or the widening of any street or part of a street is necessary to accommodate
present and antici- pated volumes of traffic.



      (2)   Storm Drains.  When any street or part of a street, or
any property, is without storm sewer or other surface drainage improvements
and storm sewer or other surface drainage should be provided in the public
interest.



      (3)   Sidewalks.  When any street or part of a street is
without sidewalks and sidewalks should be provided in the public interest.



      (4)   Water and Sewer. When any property is without water and
sewer lines and water and sewer lines should be provided in the public
interest.



   (D)   Repair of Sidewalks and Driveways. If the Council determines
that the public interest requires repair of a sidewalk or portion of a
driveway within the public right-of-way, the Council may order the making of
the repair and assess the total cost against the property abutting the
sidewalk or driveway repaired. Before an assessment may be made for the
repair, at least 30 days written notice shall be given to the abutting
property owner personally or by registered or certified mail to his last
known address or his address as shown on the tax records. The notice shall
state that he is required to make the repair at his own expense in conformity
with the sidewalk standards adopted by the City, and that if he shall fail to
make the repair thereupon the City may make the repair and assess the cost.
If the Council finds that any sidewalk or driveway is in need of immediate
repair, the Council may adopt a resolution setting out its finding and
directing that the repair be made immediately and that the cost be assessed
against the abutting property without prior notice to the property owner
affected.



PAVING STREETS



§ 55.20  EXPENSE OF STREET PAVING; COST.



   (A)   The paving of all streets by the city shall be done at the
expense of the city and the property owners of the lots or tracts of land
abutting on the street to be paved, in the manner as hereinafter provided in
this subchapter.  ('75 Code, § 13-8)



   (B)   Two-thirds of the cost of any street paving, including curbing
and guttering, exclusive of the cost incurred at street intersections, shall
be specifically assessed upon the lots of land abutting directly upon such
improvements, according to the extent of their respective frontages thereon,
by an equal rate per foot of such frontage.  The city shall pay 1/3 of the
costs and in addition shall pay total cost incurred at street
intersections.  ('75 Code, § 13-9)



(Ord. passed 12-9-63)



§ 55.21  PETITION TO CITY COUNCIL; DETERMINING PRIORITIES.



   (A)   Before paving any street, the persons owning a majority of the
front footage of property abutting directly on the street to be improved
shall petition the City Council to pave such street, and as soon as
practicable thereafter the City Council, in its discretion, will order such
street to be paved.  ('75 Code, § 13-10)



   (B)   In the event that more than one petition requesting the
pavement of any street or avenue is filed with the City Council at the same
time, the Council, in its discretion, will determine which street or avenue
shall be paved first, with due consideration being given to any street or
avenue wherein the property owners propose to pay cash for their share of the
cost.  ('75 Code, § 13-11)



(Ord. passed 12-9-63)



§ 55.22  CONFLICT WITH SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS.



   In any case involving a street or other public way or any proposed
street or other public way in any subdivision, if any provision of this
section is in conflict or inconsistent with any provision of the subdivision
regulations set forth in Chapter 154 of this code, then such provision of the
subdivision regulations shall prevail.



('75 Code, § 13-13)



EXCAVATIONS



§ 55.35  PERMIT REQUIRED; BOND.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to dig any hole, ditch, or
excavation in or under any street, sidewalk, or public place owned or
maintained by the city without first having procured a permit so to do from
the Director of Public Works.  ('75 Code, § 13-14)



   (B)   Each applicant for a permit required by this chapter may, as a
prerequisite to the issuance thereof, file with the Director of Public Works
a bond, payable to the city and in such amount as the Director shall consider
adequate, conditioned upon restoration of the surface of the place to be
excavated in compliance with the requirements of this sub-chapter; provided,
that in lieu of such bond, a cash deposit may be made with the Treasurer. 



('75 Code, § 13-15)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.36  DUTY TO RESTORE SURFACE.



   It shall be the duty of every holder of a permit issued pursuant to
this subchapter to put such street, sidewalk, or public place in as good
condition in all respects as it was prior to the beginning of work under such
permit, and every day of failure so to do shall constitute a separate offense.



('75 Code, § 13-16)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.37  SAFETY PRECAUTIONS.



   Every holder of a permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall take
such precautions as may be necessary for the protection of persons, animals,
and property from injury.  Such precautions shall include the erection and
maintenance of barriers and lights, and the Director of Public Works may
prescribe in the permit such other precautions as he may deem necessary or
prudent.



('75 Code, § 13-17)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 55.38  WORK TO BE PROSECUTED DILIGENTLY.



   Permit holders under this subchapter shall prosecute their work with
due diligence, to the end that the work may be completed and the surface
restored without undue delay.



('75 Code, § 13-18)  Penalty, see § 10.99



DRIVEWAYS



§ 55.50  DRIVEWAYS; GENERAL.



   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person may
open, construct, alter, or relocate any driveway across any public sidewalk
or into any street, or cut any curb for such purpose without having obtained
a written permit from the Public Works Director.



   (B)   Any person who receives a permit under this section shall be
responsible for repairing any damage to the sidewalk or street (including
curb and gutter) caused by the driveway construction.



   (C)   The Public Works Director shall review the driveway
construction and design plans and shall issue the permit unless he finds the
driveway, if constructed as proposed, will substantially interfere with or
pose a danger to persons using the street or sidewalk inter- sected by the
driveway, or public facilities (including utility poles, traffic signal
standards, etc.), or will fail to comply with the specifications of the city
or any of the provisions of this section.



   (D)   No driveway may be constructed closer than three feet to a
fire hydrant or catchbasin or closer than 20 feet to the right-of-way line of
a street that intersects with the street the driveway opens onto, unless
specifically approved by the City Manager.



   (E)   No driveway may be constructed closer than two feet to a
property line at the point where the property line intersects with the
right-of-way line of a street that the driveway opens onto.



   (F)   If the driveway crosses a drainage ditch on a lot that abuts a
street without curb or gutter, then piping of sufficient size and strength
(as approved by the Public Works Director shall be installed beneath the
driveway surface so that the drainage ditch is not materially impaired.



   (G)   If the driveway crosses a drainage swale on a lot that abuts a
street without curb or gutter, the driveway may conform to the contours of
the drain- age swale without compliance with subsection (F) (upon approval of
the administrator) so long as the drainage capability of the drainage swale
is not materially impaired.



   (H)   Any paved private or public driveway that intersects with or
opens onto a public street shall make the pavement of such driveway connect
with and conform to the street and sidewalk cross sections in accordance with
the specifications of the administrator. Any driveway that slopes downwards
towards the public street shall pave a minimum of 15 feet from the public
street.



(Ord. 95-4-2, passed 4-10-95; Am. Res. passed 5-9-11)



§ 55.51  DRIVEWAYS FOR BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS.



   (A)   No driveway shall exceed 30 feet in width at the outer or
street edge of the driveway.



   (B)   Not more than two driveways shall be permitted to service one
business or commercial installation from one street, and then only if the two
driveways are at least 30 feet apart.



   (C)   Any business or commercial establishment located at the
intersection of two or more streets and which desires a driveway into two
intersecting streets shall construct said driveways so as to comply with the
minimum requirements of this subchapter.



   (D) No driveway apron shall extend out into the street further than the
face of the curb and under no circumstances shall such driveway apron extend
into the gutter area.



   (E)   The city shall retain the right to deny any driveway permit
when solely in the opinion of the city that traffic flow and safety will be
compromised or if the business is adequately served by other driveway access
points.



(Ord. 95-4-2, passed 4-10-95)



§ 55.52  CITY INDEMNIFIED.



   Any person obtaining a permit authorized by this subchapter agrees as a
condition of the permit to indemnify the city for and hold the city harmless
from any expense (including but not limited to attorney's fees, litigation
costs and judgments) incurred as a result of claims made for damages arising
out of operations conducted by the permit recipient pursuant to the permit.



(Ord. 95-4-2, passed 4-10-95)



CHAPTER 56:  CEMETERIES



Section



   56.01   Title



   56.02   Definitions



   56.03   Authority of the Director



   56.04   Duties of the Director



   56.05   Rules for interment



   56.06   Lot valuation



   56.07   Records of ownership; cemetery accounts



   56.08   Reports



   56.09   Perpetual Care Trust Fund



   56.10   Cost of cemetery lots



   56.11   Clean-up days



   Appendix: Rules and regulations



Cross-reference:



   Fee Schedule, see § 33.01



§ 56.01  TITLE.



   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Bessemer City
Cemetery chapter.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)



§ 56.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DIRECTOR.  The City Manager, or such person to whom he may delegate
the duties described in this chapter.



   MUNICIPAL CEMETERY or CEMETERY.  Any municipal cemetery of the city.



   PERSON.  Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company, or organization of any kind.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)



§ 56.03  AUTHORITY OF THE DIRECTOR.



   The Director shall manage, operate, and maintain the municipal cemetery
subject to any limitations and restrictions set forth herein or contained in
any applicable law.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)



§ 56.04  DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR.



   (A)   Establishment of rules.  The Director shall establish rules
and regulations for the use of the cemetery relating to:



      (1)   Subdividing the cemetery into lots;



      (2)   Capacity of each lot;



      (3)   Location of graves;



      (4)   Types of plantings, monuments, and markers that will be
permitted for the proper and most attractive development of the cemetery.



   (B)   Direct the cemetery. The Director shall oversee and take
proper care of the cemetery and see that no lot therein is used or occupied
in violation of this chapter or of any rule or regulation promulgated by the
division.



   (C)   Collect and turn over fees.  All fees and charges collected
by the Director for duties and services performed in connection with the
cemetery shall be for the use of the city and shall immediately be turned
over to the city.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)



§ 56.05  RULES FOR INTERMENT.



   No deceased person shall be interred in the cemetery until the Director
has found:



   (A)   That the lot in which burial is to be made has been fully paid
for or guaranteed arrangements have been made;



   (B)   That the person arranging for such burial has the right to the
use of such lot;



   (C)   That such lot is not used beyond its capacity;



   (D)   That proper record is made of the name and age of the deceased
person and of the exact location of the grave.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)



§ 56.06  LOT VALUATION.



   (A)   Valuation of lots. The Director shall, with approval of
Council, place a value upon all unsold lots in the cemetery, and shall record
such valuations on an official map or plan of such cemetery that shall be
kept on file, open to public inspection, in the City Hall.  Such valuations
shall be then fixed and estab- lished value of such lots and the price at
which such lots shall be sold.  There shall be no discrimination in the sale
of lots, on any basis; provided however, in cases of extreme poverty or no
assets, the Director, with approval of Council, may reduce the cost of a
burial lot.



   (B)   Method of purchase.  Any person desiring to purchase a
particular lot or lots, for the purpose for which it is intended, shall be
permitted to do so upon payment of the price fixed for such lot or upon
making arrangements, according to rules and regulations that may be
established by the Director.



   (C)   Repurchase policy.  The city shall have the first option on
the repurchase of any lots in the Bessemer City Cemeteries. Any person
desiring to sell lots owned in Bessemer City Cemeteries shall contact the
City Manager. The option to repurchase and the repurchase price shall be at
the discretion of the City Manager.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84; Am. Ord. passed 1-10-00)



§ 56.07  RECORDS OF OWNERSHIP; CEMETERY ACCOUNTS.



   (A)   Records of ownership.  The Director shall keep full and
complete records of the ownership of all lots in the cemetery, of the burial
capacity of each lot, sold and unsold, of the location of each grave, of the
names of the persons buried in each grave that has been or shall hereafter be
used, and of the date of burial of each.



   (B)   Cemetery accounts.  The Director shall keep full and detailed
accounts of the receipts and expenditures on account of the cemetery, and
shall immediately upon receipt turn over to the city all monies collected on
such account.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)



§ 56.08  REPORTS.



   Prior to May 1 of each year, the Director shall furnish an annual
report to the City Council on the condition of the cemetery, together with
all informa- tion necessary for the Council to decide what sums, if any,
should be appropriated for proper maintenance and operation of the cemetery
in the budget.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)



§ 56.09  PERPETUAL CARE TRUST FUND.



   (A)   Pursuant to the authority conferred upon the city by G.S. §
160A-347 there is hereby established a perpetual care trust fund, hereinafter
known as the “Trust Fund.”



   (B)   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to
establish an appropriate account with a local banking institution, which
account shall be named “City of Bessemer City Cemetery Trust Fund,” and
is further hereby authorized to accept gifts, grants, bequests, and devises
made to or on behalf of the Trust Fund; and to deposit any such funds so
received together with all revenues realized from the sale of lots in or the
operation of city cemeteries into the Trust Fund.



   (C)   The principal of the Trust Fund shall be held intact and the
income from the Trust Fund shall be perpetually used to care for and maintain
the city's cemeteries, and shall be kept separate and apart from all other
city funds.  The Trust Fund shall in no case be appropriated by, lent to, or
in any manner used by the city for any purpose other than the perpetual care
of city cemeteries.



(Ord. passed 8-10-87)



§ 56.10  COST OF CEMETERY LOTS.



   (A)   Until otherwise determined by the City Council, the purchase
price for any cemetery lot or single grave portion shall in no event be less
than $400 for each cemetery lot or single grave portion.



   (B)   Cemetery lots or single grave openings in any city cemetery
shall not be sold except to individuals who are residents of the city and
their immediate family.  Immediate family is to be limited to parents,
children, siblings, and spouses.



('75 Code, § 11-3.1) (Ord. passed 6-9-75; Am. Ord. passed 11-13-78; Am. Ord.
passed 7-1-87; Am. Ord. passed 8-9-94; Am. Ord. passed 1-10-00)



§ 56.11  CLEAN-UP DAYS.



   The Public Works Director may establish up to three general clean-up
days per year for the removal of all arrangements and other materials. 
Prior to any such clean-up days, the Public Works Director shall  publish
notice in the City Newsletter, the Bessemer City Record, and the Gaston
Gazette, and shall also post signs at the cemeteries stating the days of
clean- up.  Any person desiring to retain their arrangements shall remove
them prior to the established date.



(Ord. passed 12-12-94)



APPENDIX:  RULES AND REGULATIONS



Section



   1.   Application of rules; lots sold



   2.   Interment regulations



   3.   Funeral processions



   4.   Digging graves; removal or transfer of bodies



   5.   Entrance to cemetery; open hours



   6.   Firearms prohibited



   7.   Enclosures around lots prohibited



   8.   Trees, shrubs, and plants; decorations



   9.   Foundations on cemetery lots



   10.   Numbered lots required



   11.   Stone markers; headstones and monuments



   12.   Vaults



   13.   Maintenance of cemetery; cost; property injury; pets



   14.   Supplemental rules and regulations for Sections 9 and 10,
Bessemer City Memorial Cemetery



   15.   Certain cemetery portions closed to sale of future gravesites



§ 1.  APPLICATION OF RULES; LOTS SOLD.



   (A)   The rules that follow in §§ 2 through 13 of this appendix
shall apply to the public cemeteries of the city being:



      (1)   Bessemer City Memorial Cemetery located at the end of
13th Street.



      (2)   Vantine Cemetery located at the end of D Street.



      (3)   Any other lands designated or developed by the City
Council for the burial of the dead.



   (B)   All lots are sold subject to the rules and regulations of this
cemetery now in force, or which may hereafter be adopted, and they shall be
used for no other purpose than for the burial of the human dead.  The City
Clerk shall keep a record of all lots sold in this cemetery, showing dates,
lot numbers, purchasers names, and prices.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85)



§ 2.  INTERMENT REGULATIONS.



   (A)   All interments in lots shall be restricted to the members of
the family or relations of the lot owner.  The transfer of interest in any
lot shall not be valid except by the written consent of the Director endorsed
upon such transfer or assignment.



   (B)   No interment will be permitted, nor body be received, until
the name and residence of the deceased, the name of the nearest relative and
other such information as the Public Works Director shall require is
furnished, and after all state laws relating thereto have been complied with,
and eight hours daylight notice must be given before interment.  The
Director shall cause a record to be kept of all interments and disinterments.



   (C)   Only one interment shall be made in a grave, except a mother
and infant, or two children in one coffin, or in the case of cremation urns,
in which case two cremation urns may be placed in the same grave, but urns
and caskets may not be placed in the same grave space.



   (D)   Grave liners.  Outer burial containers shall be required for
all burials in both city owned cemeteries. The minimum requirement shall be a
concrete grave liner. This requirement shall not be waived in any situation.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85; Am. Ord. passed 5-13-02)



§ 3.  FUNERAL PROCESSIONS.



   Funeral processions, upon entering the cemetery, shall be under the
control and subject to the directions of the Director, or his representative.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85)



§ 4.  DIGGING GRAVES; REMOVAL OR  TRANSFER OF BODIES.



   (A)   No grave shall be opened in any cemetery owned by the city
until the Cemetery Director has issued a permit for opening. All openings
shall be done by the city or its agent.



   (B)   Price for opening shall be $100 above the contract price as
agreed upon by the city and contractor, with the $100 being applied to
Perpetual Care Fund for cemetery maintenance.



   (C)   No material shall be allowed to remain longer than is
reasonably necessary for any construction work. No work shall be started on
Saturday which cannot be completed on that day. No heavy equipment will be
allowed in wet weather.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85; Am. Ord. passed 1-10-00)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 5.  ENTRANCE TO CEMETERY; OPEN  HOURS.



   No person shall enter the cemetery except through the gates or provided
entrances, which shall be open such hours as may be fixed by the Council. No
person shall enter the cemetery after hours and such person in violation of
this rule may be charged with trespassing.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 6.  FIREARMS PROHIBITED.



   No persons with firearms shall be permitted within the cemetery
grounds, without city approval.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 7.  ENCLOSURES AROUND LOTS  PROHIBITED.



   (A)   No enclosures of any nature, such as fences, copings, hedges,
or ditches, shall be allowed around any lot.  The boundaries of the lots may
be marked by corner-posts, which will be set as needed by and at the expense
of the cemetery, with the centers of the lines bounding the lot. Corner
markers may be set by the owner at his expense, but these must be set flush
with the ground level. Corner-posts and markers must not be altered or
removed. All such enclosures constructed in violation of this rule shall be
removed by the cemetery.  All existing enclosures as they need repair may be
repaired or removed as the Director may see fit.



   (B)   Grave mounds shall not be allowed, nor shall stone or other
enclosures around graves be permitted.  No lots shall be raised above nor
lowered below the established grade.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 8.  TREES, SHRUBS, AND PLANTS;  DECORATIONS.



   (A)   No trees, shrubs, or plants shall be planted, pruned, or
removed without the consent of the Director, or his representatives.  The
Director, or his representative, shall have authority to plant, prune,
remove, or transplant any tree, shrub, plant, or anything upon a lot, when
they may consider such a course necessary to the best interest of the
cemetery and other lot-owners.



   (B)   No iron or wire work and no seats or vases will be allowed on
lots, except by permission of the Director; and when any articles so placed
begin to rust or otherwise become unsightly, the same shall be removed from
the cemetery.



(Ord. passed 5-14-84)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 9.  FOUNDATIONS ON CEMETERY LOTS.



   (A)   Foundations for all monuments, headstones, and the like shall
be built at the expense of the lot- owner, and five days notice must be given
for the building of foundations.  Exception to these requirements may be
made, provided the work is done in accordance with the cemetery rules and
specifications and is inspected and accepted by the Director.



   (B)   Every foundation must be at least as wide and as long as the
base stone resting upon it, and must not project above the surface of the
ground. Foundations must be at least 18 inches deep, and must be built as the
Director may require for safety and permanence.



   (C)   Only one upright monument will be permitted on a family burial
lot, nor shall be it less than three feet high nor more than 2/3 the width of
the lot in height (but not exceeding eight feet in height), and shall be of
granite or marble.  No monument shall cover more than 7% of the ground space
of the lot.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 10.  NUMBERED LOTS REQUIRED.



   All reference to lots shall refer to numbered lots as shown on maps of
the cemeteries as maintained by the Director.  Two or more lots may not be
combined to change or avoid any restriction placed on any lot as shown on the
maps by reason of size or otherwise without approval of the Director with
advice of the Public Works Superintendent.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85)



§ 11.  STONE MARKERS, HEADSTONES, AND MONUMENTS.



   (A)   Only one stone or marker shall be allowed for each grave, and
shall be placed at the head of the grave.  All markers must be of granite or
marble; not less than five inches high; not less than eight, or more than 12
inches in thickness; and not more than 24 inches in width; the top being set
with and following the contour of the ground.  Graves, monuments, and the
like, will be placed on the lots facing the front line of the lot, and
located as directed by the Director.  The only exception to the provisions
of this section shall be markers provided through the U.S. Veterans
Administration, which shall be of their standard sizes.



   (B)   All stone and marble work for monuments, headstones, and the
like, must be accepted by the Director as being in conformity with these
rules before being taken into the cemetery.



   (C)   No monument, headstone or coping, and no portion of any vault
above ground shall be constructed of other material than cut-stone or real
bronze.  No artificial material will be permitted.



   (D)   A permanent stone marker shall be placed on every grave no
later than 90 days from the day of burial.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85; Am. Ord. passed 1-10-00)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 12.  VAULTS.



   The building of vaults, for the burial of deceased or for cremation
urns, will be permitted only when the construction is solid and thorough and
the design had been submitted to the Public Works Director and in his
judgment has been deemed suitable for placement under the guidelines of the
city. Vaults will be permitted only on such lots as the Director may
determine to be suitable for the purpose. The Director will determine the
number of lots required for the placement of such vault and the vault shall
be located in the center of such area and facing the front line of the lots.
As no interment is being made, the fee for locating/marking such grave shall
be collected per request, with that fee being deposited to the Perpetual Care
Trust Fund.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85; Am. Ord. passed 6-9-14)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 13.  MAINTENANCE OF CEMETERY; COST; PROPERTY INJURY; PETS.



   (A)   All rules shall apply to lots sold, including any lots in the
old part of the cemetery.  Perpetual care shall include ordinary and
reasonable care of the cemetery as a whole and of the several burial lots
therein, including the care of existing shrubbery, and trees; but does not
include the furnishing and planting of shrubbery, trees, flowers, and the
like, on the several burial lots, except such as the cemetery may wish to
furnish and plant to carry out its landscape plans.



   (B)   No person shall injure or deface any property or structure in
the cemeteries.  Dogs are to be on a leash, as required by county ordinance,
when walked in the cemeteries and owners shall take care to clean up after
animals when in the cemetery.



   (C)   The prices at which the several lots (or in the old parts
which hereafter revert to the cemetery) of the cemetery shall be sold, shall
be fixed by the City Council and shall be sufficient, as nearly as possible
to cover the cost of developing, maintaining, and operating the cemetery.



(Ord. passed 5-13-85; Am. Ord. passed 3-14-01)



§ 14.  SUPPLEMENTAL RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR SECTIONS 9 AND 10, BESSEMER
CITY MEMORIAL CEMETERY.



   (A)   Sale of Lots.



      (1)   Graves in Section 9 shall be sold only in four or eight
grave plots in the following combinations:



   Four Grave Plot: A, B, G, H or C, D, E, F



   Eight Grave Plot: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H



      (2)   Graves in Section 10 shall be sold only in two or four
grave increments, with lots to be side by side or in blocks of four.



      (3)   No plot may be re-subdivided or sold with out the
express written permission of the Cemetery Director, obtained in advance. The
city shall retain the right of first refusal to repurchase any plot at the
original sale price. The Director may limit the number of grave spaces sold
to any individual and no graves shall be purchased with the intent to resell
the same.



      (4)   When any plot remains without interment for 20 years or
more since the last deed  was issued or interment made, whichever is later,
and the whereabouts of the owner or any direct relative by blood, marriage or
adoption is unknown to the city, the title to such plot shall revert to the
city when, after notice being published once per week for four successive
weeks in a newspaper having general circulation in the county. Notice shall
describe the plot, last known owner and advise that title shall revert to the
city upon failure of the owner to appear. If after such publication such
record owner or heir does not appear within 30 additional days and confirm
ownership to the satisfaction of the Director, title to said plot shall
revert back to the city and the city may resell the same.



   (B)   Markers.



      (1)   No marker, stone or such shall be placed in any section
of the Bessemer City cemeteries until notification to the Cemetery Director
has been made and the location for such marker has been marked by the
Director.



      (2)   No more than one marker may be placed on any single
grave within the cemetery, except where a single grave space has been divided
into two spaces for cremation urns or infant burials.



      (3)   In Section 9, there shall be allowed only one upright
marker on a plot and said marker shall be only placed on the line made
through the square or plot that runs between graves A, B, C, D, and graves E,
F, G, H. Marker shall be centered on such line and before placing markers,
the Director shall be notified to mark the placement of the marker.



      (4)   (a)  In Section 10, single markers may be placed on any
grave, and markers shall be 12 inches in width, 24 inches in length and 6
inches thick; provided that standard markers furnished to the family of any
deceased veteran by the U.S. government, which may not be within the limits
specified herein, may be placed on any grave of any deceased veteran.



         (b)  Such markers may have rough or smooth sides, and may
include a vase, included inside the base of the marker area.  Companion
markers or double markers are allowed in the above section provided that the
markers shall be 12 inches in width, 48 inches in length and 6 inches thick,
with rough or smooth sides.  Such markers may include a vase located inside
the vase of the marker area.



      (5)   All markers must be constructed of first quality granite
or marble, or of bronze.  All markers will be installed at grade level.



      (6)   Corner markers may be permitted but shall be placed
completely flush with the grade as it currently exists. No coping of any type
shall be permitted nor shall the grade be changed, by fill or any other
method, on any plot from the grade established by the city.



      (7)   No plantings of any type shall be made on any plot.



   (C)   All provisions of §§ 56.01 through 56.11 and this Appendix
shall have full force on effect in Sections  9 and 10, and if any conflict
shall arise between these supplemental rules and the primary rules, the more
restrictive shall apply, as interpreted by the Director.



   (D)   The price for lots shall be fixed by the City Council and
shall be sufficient, as nearly as possible to cover the cost of developing,
maintaining, and operating the cemetery.  This price may be adjusted at any
time by the City Council.



   (E)   Grave Liners.  Outer burial containers shall be required for
all burials in Section 10 of the Bessemer City Memorial Cemetery.  The
minimum requirement shall be for a concrete, steel or fiberglass grave
liner.  This requirement shall not be waived in any situation.



(Ord. passed 11-13-95; Am. Ord. passed 7-10-00; Am. Ord. passed 3-14-01)



§ 15.  CERTAIN CEMETERY PORTIONS CLOSED TO SALE OF FUTURE GRAVESITES.



   (A)   The following described portions of Vantine Cemetery and
Bessemer City Memorial Cemetery shall be closed to the sale of future
gravesites:



      (1)   Vantine Cemetery.  A 1.4105 acre tract located at the
northern intersection of “D” Street and the northern margin of the right
of way for Maryland Avenue as shown on the map dated June 6, 2000, drawn by
Robinson and Sawyer, Inc., Consulting Engineers and Land Surveyors, a copy of
which is on file with the cemetery maps maintained by the city in City Hall.



      (2)   Bessemer City Memorial Cemetery.  A 1.9751 acre tract
located near the northwestern intersection of the right of way of 13th Street
and the terminus of Iowa Avenue as shown on the map dated June 6, 2000 drawn
by Robinson and Sawyer, Inc., Consulting Engineers and Land Surveyors, a copy
of which is on file with the cemetery maps maintained by the city in City
Hall.



   (B)   Only those individuals holding valid deeds to gravesites
located within the portions of the cemeteries closed by this section shall be
permitted to utilize those sites for future interment.



(Ord. passed 7-10-00)

CHAPTER 70:  GENERAL TRAFFIC RULES



Section

   70.02   Applicability of traffic code

   70.10   Entering or riding on vehicles without permission



   70.11   Clinging to moving vehicles prohibited



   70.12   Front seat passengers



   70.13   Passengers must remain inside moving vehicles



   70.14   Skateboards; scooters; skates



   70.15   Unnecessary noise



   70.16   Compliance required

Cross-reference:



   Truck routes on specific streets, see Chapter 75, Schedule IV



§ 70.01  SHORT TITLE.



   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the traffic code.



('75 Code, § 17-1)



§ 70.02  APPLICABILITY OF TRAFFIC CODE.



   (A)   Every person propelling any push-cart or riding a bicycle or
an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle,
shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver
of any vehicle, except those provisions thereof which, by their very nature,
can have no application. 



('75 Code, § 17-2)



   (B)   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of
any vehicle owned by, or used in the service of, the United States government
or any state, county, or municipality, and it shall be unlawful for any such
driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter except as otherwise
may be permitted therein, or by state statute. 



('75 Code, § 17-3)



§ 70.03  TRUCKS ON CITY STREETS; REGULATIONS.



   (A)   Findings.  The City Council hereby finds that the
indiscriminate driving of heavy trucks and trailers located within the city
is detrimental to the health, morale, comfort, safety and welfare of the
people of the city and deems it best for the public welfare of the citizens
that the operation of such trucks be confined to certain streets within the
corporate limits of the city.  The trucks and trailers that this section
applies to are the following:



      (1)   Tractor and tandem tractor type trucks when pulling
semi-trailers or tandem semi-trailers.



      (2)   Trucks exceeding seven feet in width.



      (3)   Trucks, including tractors and tandem tractors with or
without trailers, having a gross weight of 2½ tons or more.



   (B)   Routes designated by signs.  When signs are erected, all
trucks and trailers entering the city destined to any point outside the city
and not taking on or discharging within the city limits any goods, wares, or
merchandise shall travel exclusively on the truck routes designated, and over
such portion of such truck routes as shall constitute the shortest and most
direct route from the point of entrance into the city and departure from the
city.



   (C)   Deviation for loading and unloading.  No person shall operate
any such trucks or trailers for the transportation of property, except along
and over the routes set out in Chapter 75, Sched. IV of this traffic code,
except when it is impractical to do so because of street repairs or other
emergencies, or when necessary to travel on other streets to a destination
for the purpose of loading or unloading goods, wares, or merchandise, and
then only by such deviation from the nearest truck traffic route as is
reasonably necessary.



   (D)   Application to trucks loading within the city for
transportation outside the city limits.  All persons operating trucks or
truck trailers for the transporta- tion of goods, wares, or merchandise,
whose property or cargoes are taken on or loaded within the city for the
transportation outside the corporate limits, shall in every instance follow
the truck route out of the city.



(Ord. passed 9-12-83)  Penalty, see § 70.99



Cross-reference:



   Truck routes on specific streets, see Chapter 75, Sched. IV



§ 70.04  REQUIRED OBEDIENCE TO POLICE OFFICERS AND FIREFIGHTERS.



   (A)   No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any
lawful order or direction given by a police officer, or fail or refuse to
comply with any lawful order or direction given by a uniformed fire- fighter
at or near the scene of any fire.  ('75 Code, § 17-5)



   (B)   In the event of a fire or other emergency, or when necessary
to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, police officers may direct
traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding other pro- visions of this
chapter.  ('75 Code, § 17-6)



Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.05  FUNERAL PROCESSIONS.



   (A)   Definitions.  For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



   CHIEF OF POLICE.  The Chief of Police of the city.



   FUNERAL PROCESSION PERMIT.  Any permit required by this section.



   PERMITTED FUNERAL PROCESSION.  Any procession of motor vehicles
travelling at a distance no greater than 40 feet apart after a funeral, for
which a permit has been issued in accordance with this chapter, and which is
escorted by the police of the city.



   PERSON.  Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company, or organization of any kind.



   (B)   Permit required; contents; fee.



      (1)   No funeral procession shall be escorted by the police of
the city without there first having been obtained a funeral procession permit
from the Chief of Police at least 24 hours prior to the funeral.



      (2)   The funeral procession permit shall state the time,
point of beginning, the cemetery, and the route, as determined by the Chief
of Police, to be followed by the procession.



   (C)   Speed limit.  No permitted funeral pro- cession shall proceed
within the city at a speed greater than 20 miles per hour.



   (D)   Permitted funeral processions to have right of way.  Any
vehicle upon the highway as defined in G.S. Ch. 20 shall yield the
right-of-way to all vehicles travelling in a permitted funeral procession.



   (E)   Operating procedures.  The Chief of Police shall establish
written standard operating procedures with respect to funeral processions
which shall become a part of the Police Manual.



(Ord. passed 10-13-86)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.06  INTERSECTIONS.



   No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless
there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk
to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of
other vehicles or pedestrians, notwith- standing any traffic-control signal
indication to proceed.



('75 Code, 17-8)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.07  ALLEYS AND DRIVEWAYS.



   The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building
shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or side-
walk areas extending across any alleyway, and upon entering the roadway he
shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway.



('75 Code, § 17-9)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.08  SIDEWALKS.



   No person shall propel a motor or animal-drawn vehicle on any sidewalk
in the city except when crossing a sidewalk at a crossing place constructed
for such purpose.



('75 Code, § 17-11)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.09  BACKING.



   The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same into any intersection
or over a crosswalk and shall not in any event or at any place back a vehicle
unless such movement can be made in safety, and he shall have given ample
warning to those who may be behind, by hand and horn or other signal.



('75 Code, § 17-10)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.10  ENTERING OR RIDING ON VEHICLES WITHOUT PERMISSION.



   No person shall enter, jump on, or ride any automobile or other vehicle
without the consent of the owner or driver.



('75 Code, § 17-12)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.11  CLINGING TO MOVING VEHICLES PROHIBITED.



   Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller
skates, or any toy vehicle shall not attach the same or himself to any public
conveyance or moving vehicle upon any roadway.



('75 Code, §§ 17-13)  Penalty, see § 70.99



Cross-reference:



   Skateboards, scooters; skates, see § 70.14



   Bicycles, see Ch. 72



§ 70.12  FRONT SEAT PASSENGERS.



   It shall be unlawful for the driver or the person in charge of any
motor vehicle to permit more than three persons including the driver to ride
in the front or driver's seat of a motor vehicle.



('75 Code, § 17-14)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.13  PASSENGERS MUST REMAIN INSIDE MOVING VEHICLES.



   (A)   No person shall allow any part of his body to protrude beyond
the limits of the vehicle in which he is riding except to give such signals
as are by law required, and no person shall hang onto any vehicle
whatsoever.  ('75 Code, § 17-15)



   (B)   No person shall board or alight from any public conveyance or
other vehicle while such conveyance or vehicle is in motion. 



('75 Code, § 17-17)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.14  SKATEBOARDS; SCOOTERS; SKATES.



   No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster,
toy vehicle, or similar device shall go upon any roadway unless it be while
crossing a street at a crosswalk or intersection, except upon streets set
aside as play streets.



('75 Code, § 17-16)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.15  UNNECESSARY NOISE.



   (A)   No vehicle shall be loaded with materials likely to create
loud noises by striking together, without using every reasonable effort to
deaden the noise.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person in operating a motor
vehicle, motorcycle, or minibike within the city to create in the operation
thereof any unreasonably loud, disturbing, or unnecessary noise.



   (C)   In operating a motor vehicle, motorcycle, or minibike, the
following acts, among others, are declared to create loud, disturbing, and
unnecessary noises in violation of this section, but such enumeration shall
not be deemed to be exclusive, namely:



      (1)   The use of any such vehicle so out of repair as to cause
thereby loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling, or any of such
noises, or any other unnecessary noise.



      (2)   The practice of unnecessarily racing the motor of any
such vehicle while standing or moving, thereby causing unnecessary noise from
such motor.



      (3)   The practice of unnecessarily retarding the spark to the
motor of any such vehicle and thereby causing unnecessary, loud, and
explosive noise from the motor.



      (4)   In starting a motor of any such vehicle from a standing
position, the practice of gaining speed unnecessarily quickly and thereby
causing unnecessary and loud noise from the motor and the screeching of
tires, or either of such noises.



      (5)   The practice of coming to an unreasonably quick stop
with any such vehicle and thereby causing unnecessary grinding of brakes and
screeching of tires or either of such noises.



('75 Code, § 17-18)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 70.16  COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act prohibited or fail to
do any act required by this chapter.



('75 Code, § 17-19)



§ 70.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever shall violate any provision of this chapter for which no other
penalty is provided shall be responsible for an infraction and shall be
required to pay a fine not to exceed $50. Each day that any of the provisions
of this chapter are violated shall constitute a separate offense.



(G.S. § 14-4(b))



CHAPTER 71:  TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES



Section



   71.01   Obedience to traffic-control devices



   71.02   Placement, change, or removal of traffic-control devices



   71.03   Types of traffic-control devices authorized



   71.04   Requirements as to signs



§ 71.01  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.



   (A)   Obedience required.  The driver of any vehicle and any
pedestrian shall obey the instructions of any applicable official
traffic-control device placed in accordance with the provisions of state law,
this chapter, or other ordinance of the city, unless other- wise directed by
a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted by state law to the
drivers of Police and Fire Department vehicles, public and private
ambulances, and rescue squad and emergency service vehicles.  ('75 Code, §
17-20)



   (B)   Avoidance of official traffic-control devices. No person may
drive across a sidewalk or through the driveway of a gasoline filling station
or other property for the purpose of avoiding an official traffic-control
device. (Ord. passed 2-12-90)



Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 71.02  PLACEMENT, CHANGE, OR REMOVAL OF TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.



   (A)   Traffic-control devices of the city shall be placed, erected,
installed, changed, or removed only upon order of the City Council pursuant
to action taken by the Council and entered upon its minutes, and any such
action shall be by ordinance when so required by law.



   (B)   Unless otherwise provided by the City Council in any instance,
such orders of the Council shall be executed under the direction of the City
Manager.



   (C)   A list of all devices shall be made as Chapter 75, Sched. I of
this traffic code with respect to stop and yield restrictions and Chapter 75,
Sched. III of this traffic code with respect to the designation of one-way
streets.



('75 Code, § 17-21) (Ord. 46, passed  - - ; Am. Ord. passed 7-13-92) 
Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 71.03  TYPES OF TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES AUTHORIZED.



   (A)   Examples.  Traffic-control devices of the city within the
purview of § 71.02 shall include but shall not be limited to those
indicating stop and yield intersections; speed restrictions; limited or
prohibited turning movements; one-way streets; prohibited and restricted
parking areas; truck routes and other restrictions as to vehicle types
permitted to be driven upon the streets; school zones; safety zones; zones of
quiet; play streets; bus stops; taxicab stands; loading zones; and business
and residence districts. All signs shall conform with the Manual of Uniform
Traffic Control Devices. ('75 Code, § 17-22)



   (B)   Traffic-control devices in place on effective date of this
code.  All traffic-control devices hereto- fore installed by authority of
the City Council and which are in place on the effective date of this code
shall continue to be official until such time as they may be removed by
authority of the City Council; and until they are so removed it shall be
unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any instruction or directive
indicated by any such official traffic-control device.  ('75 Code, § 17-23)



Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 71.04  REQUIREMENTS AS TO SIGNS.



   No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be
enforced against an alleged violator if, at the time and place of the alleged
violation, an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently
legible to an ordinarily observant person.  Whenever a particular section
does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective
without signs being placed to give notice thereof.



('75 Code, § 17-24)



CHAPTER 72:  BICYCLES



Section



   72.01   Traffic laws apply to persons riding bicycles



   72.02   Obedience to traffic-control devices



   72.03   Riding on bicycles



   72.04   Roadways and bicycle paths



   72.05   Speed



   72.06   Emerging from alley, driveway, or building



   72.07   Carrying articles



   72.08   Parking



   72.09   Riding on sidewalks; yield to pedestrians



   72.10   Equipment on bicycles



Cross-reference:



   Clinging to moving vehicles, see § 70.11



   Riding bicycles on certain sidewalks, see Chapter 75, Schedule V



§ 72.01  TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY TO PERSONS RIDING BICYCLES.



   Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of
the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver
of a vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable
to vehicles or by the traffic ordinances of the city applicable to the driver
of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this chapter and except as
to those provisions of laws and ordinances which by their nature can have no
application.



('75 Code, § 17-30) (Ord. passed 12-14-65)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.02  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.



   (A)   Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of
official traffic-control signals, signs, and other control devices applicable
to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.



   (B)   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right
or left turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the
direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the
bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the
regulations applicable to pedestrians.



('75 Code, § 17-31) (Ord. passed 12-14-65)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.03  RIDING ON BICYCLES.



   (A)   A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than
astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto.



   (B)   No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time
than the number for which it is designed and equipped.



('75 Code, § 17-32) (Ord. passed 12-14-65)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.04  ROADWAYS AND BICYCLE PATHS.



   (A)   Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as
near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care
when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction.



   (B)   Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more
than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the
exclusive use of bicycles.



   (C)   Wherever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent
to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the
roadway.



('75 Code, § 17-33) (Ord. passed 12-14-65)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.05  SPEED.



   No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable
and prudent under the conditions then existing.



('75 Code, § 17-34)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.06  EMERGING FROM ALLEY, DRIVEWAY, OR BUILDING.



   The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building
shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any
alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the
sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the
right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway.



('75 Code, § 17-35) (Ord. passed 12-14-65)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.07  CARRYING ARTICLES.



   No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle, or
article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the
handlebars.



('75 Code, § 17-36) (Ord. passed 12-14-65)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.08  PARKING.



   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the
roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the
bicycle or against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the
least obstruction to pedestrian and vehicular traffic.



('75 Code, § 17-37) (Ord. passed 12-14-65)  Penalty, see § 70.99



§ 72.09  RIDING ON SIDEWALKS; YIELD TO PEDESTRIANS.



   Whenever any person is operating or riding a bicycle, skateboard, or
roller-skates on a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any
pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing
such pedestrian.



(Ord. passed 5-14-90)  Penalty, see § 70.99



Cross-reference:



   Riding bicycles on certain sidewalks, see Chapter 75, Schedule V



§ 72.10  EQUIPMENT ON BICYCLES.



   (A)   Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with
a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of
at least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type
which shall be visible from all distances from 50 feet to 300 feet to the
rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor
vehicle.  A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to
the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector.



   (B)   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable
the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement.



('75 Code, § 17-39) (Ord. 3, passed 9-19-49; Am. Ord. passed 12-14-65) 
Penalty, see § 70.99



CHAPTER 73:  STOPPING; STANDING; PARKING



Section



   73.01   Applicability of chapter



   73.02   Unlawful stopping, standing, or parking



   73.03   Stopping in streets



   73.04   Parking restrictions



   73.05   Parking for certain reasons prohibited



   73.06   Stopping, standing, or parking in certain places prohibited



   73.07   Parking of large vehicles



   73.08   Loading zones



   73.09   Permits for loading and unloading at angle to curb



 



   73.99   Penalty



§ 73.01  APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER.



   (A)   The provisions of this chapter prohibiting the standing or
parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein
specified or as indicated on official signs.  ('75 Code, § 17-39.1)



   (B)   The provisions of this chapter imposing a time limit on
parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more
restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing, or
parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times.  ('75 Code,
§ 17-39.2)



(Ord. passed 5-12-75)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.02  UNLAWFUL STOPPING, STANDING, OR PARKING.



   No person owning or having control or charge of a vehicle shall:



   (A)   Park or leave standing such vehicle upon any public street or
public grounds for a continuous period of more than 48 hours.



   (B)   Allow such vehicle to stand on any street or on any public
parking lot of the city unattended without first effectively setting the
brakes, stopping the engine, locking the ignition and removing the ignition
key of such vehicle, and when standing upon any grade of a street, without
turning the front wheels of such vehicle to the curb or side of the street.
Whenever any law enforcement officer shall find a vehicle standing unattended
with the ignition key in the vehicle in violation of this section, such law
enforcement officer shall remove such key from such vehicle and deliver the
same to the police station of the city.



   (C)   Park any vehicle upon a street or alley in such a manner or
under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width
of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic.



   (D)   Stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such a
position as to block the driveway entrance or doorway to any abutting
property.



   (E)   Stop, stand, or park such vehicle if it exceeds 19 feet in
length where head-on or right-angle parking is required.



('75 Code, § 17-39.3) (Ord. passed 5-12-75)



Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.03  STOPPING IN STREETS.



   (A)   No vehicle shall stop in any street except for the purpose of
parking as prescribed in this chapter, unless such stop is made necessary by
the approach of an authorized emergency vehicle as defined in § 70.03 of
this traffic code, by the approach of a funeral or other procession or
vehicle which is given the right-of- way, by the stopping of a school bus or
a public conveyance, by the giving of traffic signals, by the passing of some
other vehicle or a pedestrian, or by some emergency; and in any case covered
by these exceptions vehicles shall stop so as not to obstruct any footway,
pedestrian aisle, safety zone, crossing or street intersection, if such can
be avoided.  ('75 Code, § 17-40)



   (B)   Standing vehicles not to obstruct passage of other vehicles. 
No vehicle shall so stand on any street as to interrupt or interfere with the
passage of public conveyances or other vehicles. 



('75 Code, § 17-41)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.04  PARKING RESTRICTIONS.



   (A)   Parking prohibited at all times where so posted or where curbs
painted yellow.  When official signs are placed, erected or installed,
giving notice thereof, or the curbing has been painted yellow in lieu of such
signs, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets so
sign-posted or painted yellow. ('75 Code, § 17-42)



   (B)   Parking restricted as sign-posted.  When official signs are
placed, erected, or installed giving notice thereof, no person shall park a
vehicle upon any of the streets so sign-posted at any time during which
parking is prohibited by such signs or for a greater length time than is
permitted by such signs.  ('75 Code, § 17-43)



   (C)   Standing or parking parallel to curb.  Except as otherwise
provided in this chapter, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway
where there are adjacent curbs shall be stopped or parked with the wheels of
such vehicle parallel to and within 12 inches of the curb.  ('75 Code, §
17-44) (Ord. passed 5-12-75)



   (D)   Angle parking.  On those streets which have been signed or
marked by the City Traffic Engineer for angle parking, no person shall park
or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway
indicated by such signs or markings.  ('75 Code, § 17-44.1) (Ord. passed
5-12-75)



   (E)   Parking backed up to curb restricted.  No person shall park a
vehicle backed up to the curb, except when actually loading or unloading, and
then only at places where such parking is not prohibited. ('75 Code, § 17-45)



   (F)   Stopping with left side of car to curb prohibited.  No person
shall stop a vehicle with its left side to the curb on any improved two-way
street. ('75 Code, § 17-46) (Ord. passed 5-12-75)



   (G)   Parking within marked parking spaces required.  On any street
which is marked off with lines indicating the parking spaces for vehicles,
such vehicles shall be parked between such lines.  ('75 Code, § 17-47)
(Ord. passed 5-12-75)



Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.05  PARKING FOR CERTAIN REASONS PROHIBITED.



   No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any street for the
principal purpose of:



   (A)   Displaying it for sale or hire.



   (B)   Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, excepting repairs
necessitated by an emergency.



   (C)   Commercial storage, including storage by garages, dealers and
other persons.



   (D)   Storage of any detached trailer or van when the towing unit
has been disconnected.



   (E)   Transferring merchandise or freight from one vehicle to
another.



   (F)   Commercial advertising, except with prior written permission
of the City Manager or City Chief of Police.



   (G)   Presenting shows, exhibitions or entertainment of any kind
where an admission fee is charged or donations solicited or accepted.



('75 Code, § 17-48) (Ord. passed 5-12-75)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.06  STOPPING, STANDING, OR PARKING IN CERTAIN PLACES PROHIBITED.



   No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, except when necessary
to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the
directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the
following places:



   (A)   On a sidewalk.



   (B)   On the planting strip or utility strip not used for sidewalk
purposes which is situated between the edge of the street pavement and the
street right-of- way boundary line.



   (C)   In front of a public or private driveway.



   (D)   Within an intersection.



   (E)   On a crosswalk.



   (F)   Within 20 feet of any flashing beacon, stop sign, or
traffic-control signal located at the side of a street or roadway.



   (G)   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure or within any
underpass structure.



   (H)   On either side of any street at the approaches to a bridge, an
underpass or an overhead bridge within 50 feet in either direction of the
outer edge of such structure.



   (I)   On either side of any street leading to a grade crossing
within 50 feet of the closest rail; provided, that where existing permanent
structures are located closer than 50 feet, parking may be permitted in front
of such structures unless otherwise prohibited, and if such parking does not
block the view in either direction of the approach of a locomotive or train.



   (J)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction, if
such stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic.



   (K)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopping, standing, or
parking at the edge or curb of a street.



   (L)   Within 15 feet in either direction of a fire hydrant or the
entrance to a fire station.



   (M)   Within 25 feet of a corner of any inter- section.



   (N)   In front of any motion picture theater, except for bicycles
where racks are provided.



('75 Code, § 17-49) (Ord. passed 5-12-75)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.07  PARKING OF LARGE VEHICLES.



   Except while actively engaged in loading and unloading, no person shall
park a vehicle with a GVW in excess of 20,000 pounds on any street in a
residential zone.



('75 Code, § 17-49.5) (Ord. passed 1-8-79)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.08  LOADING ZONES.



   (A)   Commercial vehicles may park in designated loading zones for
the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise for a period of time not
exceeding 15 minutes.



   (B)   No person shall park a vehicle in a loading zone for the
purpose of taking orders or buying or selling merchandise of any kind.



   (C)   Loading zones shall be sign-posted so as to give notice as to
the loading zone, or the curbing shall be painted red in lieu of such signs.



('75 Code, § 17-50)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.09  PERMITS FOR LOADING AND UNLOADING AT ANGLE TO CURB.



   (A)   The Chief of Police is authorized to issue temporary permits
for a period not to exceed 48 hours to allow the backing of a vehicle to the
curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject
to the terms and conditions of such permit.  Such permits may be issued
either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the driver of a vehicle
and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized
herein.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to
violate any of the terms or conditions of any such permit or to back a
vehicle to the curb for the purposes set forth herein without first having
obtained such temporary permit.



('75 Code, § 17-50.1)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter may, within
10 days of the time that a traffic ticket for such violation was attached to
his vehicle, pay to the designated official a penalty for, and in full
satisfaction of such violation, in the sum of $5.  Upon failure to make the
payment heretofore designated, a written notice shall be mailed to the
person, and if payment be not made within 48 hours after the time of mailing
of such notice, the fine shall be assessed as a civil penalty, collectible in
the manner of debt.



('75 Code, § 17-51.1) (Ord. passed 5-12-75)



CHAPTER 74:  VEHICLE LICENSES



Section



   74.01   Annual license tax imposed



   74.02   Method of collection



§ 74.01  ANNUAL LICENSE TAX IMPOSED.



   All owners of motor vehicles residing within the corporate limits of
the city are hereby required to pay to the city an annual license tax of $5
for each vehicle. 



(G.S. § 20-97)



§ 74.02  METHOD OF COLLECTION.



   The license tax imposed by this section shall be collected along other
property taxes on motor vehicles by the County of Gaston and remitted to the
city monthly.
