SCHEDULE C
GROSS RECEIPTS CALCULATION



 


A.   All city classifications that are based on gross sales/receipts are
computed as follows:


   Rate of $0.15 per $1,000 in sales (i.e., $12,000.00 x .15/1,000 = $1.80)



B.   The minimum gross receipts tax is $50. For the above example, the fee
would be $50.




C.   The maximum gross receipts tax is $3,000. (Gross receipts would need
to be at least $20,000,000 to meet this amount.




D.   Any business taxed on the basis of gross receipts that does not
provide the required information will be taxed at the maximum amount.



GROSS RECEIPTS means the amount reported as gross income on a business’
state or federal income tax return for the most recently completed tax year.
If a business has not been in business long enough to file a return, an
estimate of receipts is acceptable. Any business outside of the city limit
but conducting business within the city shall report the revenue received
from Bessemer City operations.



 



(Ord. 93-7-1, passed 7-12-93; Am. Ord. passed 11-15-94; Am. Ord. 97-5-1,
passed  - -97; Am. Res. passed 7-9-12)



CHAPTER 111:  VEHICLE TOWING SERVICE



Section



   111.01   Jurisdiction



   111.02   Purpose



   111.03   Definitions



   111.04   License required



   111.05   Issuance of license



   111.06   Hours of operation



   111.07   Duties and responsibilities of rotation wreckers and drivers



   111.08   Dispatching regulations



   111.09   Sanctions for failure to comply with regulations



   111.10   Unlawful to respond to police radio calls for towing service



 



   111.99   Penalty



Cross-reference:



   For Traffic Code, see Title VII of this code



§ 111.01  JURISDICTION.



   On and after March 1, 1992, these regulations shall govern the
dispatching of wreckers by the city Police Department for the removal and
transfer of disabled vehicles, as defined by this chapter, within the city.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)



§ 111.02  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of the regulations expressed herein is to guide and
regulate the efficient dispatch of wrecker vehicles to aid law enforcement
officers in the removal from the public highways and grounds of disabled
vehicles. Specifically, these regulations are designed to establish a list of
qualified wrecker operators who may be called upon, on a rotating basis, to
remove from the public highways and grounds, vehicles which have become
disabled by accident, collision, or otherwise present a hazardous condition
to the public. Furthermore, these regula- tions are designed to prohibit
wrecker operators from soliciting towing work by responding to radio com-
munication without having been directly dispatched by the Police Department.
It is the intent of these regulations to provide an equitable arrangement by
which police officers can order a tow truck to the scene of an accident if
the motorist has not designated a particular towing service to be called by
police.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)



§ 111.03  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CHIEF OF POLICE.  The Chief of Police of Bessemer City.



   MOTOR VEHICLE.  Includes any machine designed or intended to travel
over land or water by self-propulsion or while attached to a self-propelled
vehicle.



   ROTATION WRECKER.  A person, firm, or corporation engaged in a
business offering the services of towing and storage of disabled or wrecked
motor vehicles or motor vehicles found to be in violation of a city ordinance
or state law under the direction of city police officers, State Highway
Patrol, or other law enforcement officers.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)



§ 111.04  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   No wrecker operator shall offer services as a rotation wrecker
within the city without first having obtained a license as hereinafter
provided.



   (B)   Application for licenses issued hereunder shall be made upon a
form prepared and made available by the Chief of Police and shall state:



      (1)   The name, home address, and business address of the
applicant.



      (2)   The type and quantity of equipment owned and maintained
by the business.



      (3)   That the applicant has available space for properly
accommodating and protecting all disabled motor vehicles to be towed or
otherwise removed from the place where they are disabled, together with the
location of the storage area and the method of protection.



   (C)   No license shall be issued to an applicant for a rotation
wrecker license until he has deposited with the Chief of Police Certificates
of Insurance showing that he has purchased the following insurance policies:



      (1)   Garagekeeper's policy.  A garage- keeper's legal
liability policy covering any motor vehicle towed or otherwise removed
pursuant to this chapter against fire, theft, windstorm, and explosions in
the minimum amounts of $25,000 per motor vehicle with each accident deemed a
separate claim.



      (2)   Garage liability policy. A garage liability policy
covering the operation of applicant's business, equipment or other vehicles,
for any bodily injury or property damage. This policy shall be in the amount
of not less than $100,000 for any one person injured or killed and a per
accident limit of not less than $300,000 and $50,000 dollars for property
damage.



      (3)   Thirty days prior to any material change or cancellation
of any policy required herein, written notice of such change or cancellation
must be given to the Chief of Police by the rotation wrecker or his insurance
carrier.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)  Penalty, see § 111.99



§ 111.05  ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.



   Within 15 days of receipt of an application as provided for herein, the
Chief of Police shall deter- mine if a license should be issued to said
applicant upon the following conditions:



   (A)   That the applicant has satisfied the equip- ment, storage, and
service requirements as set out in § 111.04 of this chapter and on the
application.



   (B)   That insurance policies as required by § 111.04 have been
procured.



   (C)   That requirements of this chapter and all other governing laws
and ordinances have been met.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)



§ 111.06  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   Each rotation wrecker licensed by the city shall receive or release
towed vehicles 24 hours a day, seven days a week, including holidays. Each
rotation wrecker shall provide access to vehicles by owners for purposes
other than release between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., seven days a
week, without charge.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)



§ 111.07  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF ROTATION WRECKERS AND DRIVERS.



   A rotation wrecker licensed under this chapter shall comply with the
following terms and conditions:



   (A)   Availability for service. If the rotation wrecker dispatched
cannot respond immediately to a service call, it shall so inform the Police
Department who shall call the next wrecker operator on the rota- tion list.
No rotation wrecker shall assign a call to another wrecker service.



   (B)   Identification. Each rotation wrecker vehicle used for service
calls shall have the business name, address, and telephone number printed in
at least three-inch letters on each side of the wrecker.



   (C)   Duty of wrecker drivers. It shall be the duty of each rotation
wrecker driver to:



      (1)   Clean the wreck area of glass, oil, auto parts, and
other debris, and to carry away the debris for disposal, provided that the
rotation wrecker driver shall not be responsible for the removal of spilled
cargo.



      (2)   To use a clean cover in order to protect the interior of
a vehicle if it becomes necessary to enter it.



   (D)   Telephones. Rotation wrecker operators shall designate two
telephone numbers which shall be listed with the Police Department to be
called for dispatching purposes. One number shall be designated for calls
during business hours and the secondary number shall be designated for
non-business hours.



   (E)   Maintenance of equipment. Rotation wreckers shall keep and
maintain tow-in equipment which is adequate to perform tow-in service in a
reasonably satisfactory manner.



   (F)   Interception of police calls. Rotation wreckers shall report
for service only when dis- patched by the Police Department. No rotation
wrecker shall report for service as a result of inter- cepting a police radio
transmission.



   (G)   Inspections and meetings. The Chief of Police shall be
permitted to conduct regular inspec- tion of the rotation wrecker business
office and its operations relative to the city rotation wrecker system, and
may hold meetings with the wrecker operators to resolve complaints,
procedural problems, and maintain lines of communication with wrecker
operators.



   (H)   Secured parking area. Rotation wrecker operators shall
maintain a fenced area to provide protection for towed vehicles. The fenced
area shall be large enough to store at least 20 cars, and the fence shall be
at least six feet high.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)  Penalty, see § 111.99



§ 111.08  DISPATCHING REGULATIONS.



   (A)   The following regulations shall be observed for the purpose of
dispatching wrecker operators on rotation calls:



      (1)   Requests for dispatch of rotation wrecker operator shall
come from a law enforcement officer at the location of the disabled vehicle.



      (2)   Rotation wrecker operators shall be dispatched only by
the Police Department.



      (3)   The police dispatcher shall advise the officer at the
location of the disabled vehicle of the name of the wrecker which has been
dispatched. In the event that the wrecker operator does not respond to a
dispatched call, the police officer at the scene of the disabled vehicle may
request that the next wrecker operator on the rotation list be called. The
police officer at the scene should remain there until a wrecker arrives, and
longer if conditions warrant.



      (4)   Wrecker service operators shall not answer any call for
service coming directly from the owner of a vehicle unless he first notified
the City Communication Center as to the nature of the request and the
location of the disabled vehicle.



      (5)   The Police Department shall maintain a dispatch log upon
which the following information shall be recorded:



         (a)   The date of the call for service.



         (b)   The time the call was received.



         (c)   From whom the call was dis- patched.



         (d)   The location of the disabled vehicle.



         (e)   Which rotation operator the call was dispatched to.



         (f)   The log should also have recorded any information
received by the police dispatcher regarding calls directly from the owners of
disabled vehicles to wrecker services.



   (B)   Any owners of a disabled vehicle may request a wrecker service
of his own designation, without regard to the provisions of this chapter.



   (C)   Complaints regarding the dispatching pro- cedure for rotation
wreckers shall be directed to the Chief of Police.



   (D)   In the event that a rotation wrecker operator is incapable of
recovering stalled, abandoned, or wrecked vehicles, the operator may seek the
assistance of any wrecker service with equipment capable of moving the
disabled vehicles. It shall be the duty of the rotation wrecker operator
dispatched to the scene to work out financial arrangements, if necessary,
with the assisting wrecker operator.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)  Penalty, see § 111.99



§ 111.09  SANCTIONS FOR FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH REGULATIONS.



   The Chief of Police is authorized to remove a wrecker operator from the
rotation list for failure to follow the regulations set forth herein, for up
to ten days for first offense, 20 days for second offense, and 30 days for
third offense. The Police Chief shall give the offending wrecker operator
adequate notice and an opportunity to be heard before instituting any
suspension from the rotation list. A wrecker operator who fails to responds
to three consecutive calls shall be removed from the rotation list for up to
30 days by the Chief of Police. The operator may petition the City Manager by
registered mail for reinstatement within the 30-day period. Suspension for
failure to respond shall be instituted after notice to the operator and a
hearing before the Chief of Police.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)



§ 111.10  UNLAWFUL TO RESPOND TO POLICE RADIO CALLS FOR TOWING SERVICE.



   It shall be unlawful for any wrecker operator to respond to a call for
assistance to a vehicle that has been disabled due to an accident without
having been called directly by the owner of the disabled vehicle, or
dispatched by the police dispatcher.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)  Penalty, see § 111.99



§ 111.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Misdemeanor. Notwithstanding § 10.99 of ths code of
ordinances, any person violating the provisions of § 111.10 of this chapter
may be found guilty of a misdemeanor under G.S. § 14-4, and may be subject
to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or
both, for each offense.



   (B)   Equitable remedies. This chapter may be enforced by an
appropriate equitable remedy issuing from a court of competent jurisdiction.



(Ord. passed 3-1-92)



Cross-reference:



   For Traffic Code, see Title VII of this code



CHAPTER 112:  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES



Section




Consumption and Possession




   112.01   Definitions



   112.02   Consumption on the public streets and on municipal property
prohibited



   112.03   Possession of open containers on the public streets and on
municipal property prohibited



   112.04   Possession during special events prohibited



Sale of Alcoholic Beverages



   112.15   Sunday sales hours



 



   112.99   Penalty



CONSUMPTION AND POSSESSION



§ 112.01 DEFINITIONS.



   In addition to the common meanings of words, the following definitions
shall be applicable herein:



   MALT BEVERAGE.  Beer, lager, malt liquor, ale, porter, and any other
brewed or fermented beverage containing at least 0.5%, and not more than 6%
alcohol by volume. [G.S. § 18B-101(9)]



   OPEN CONTAINER.  A container whose seal has been broken or a container
other than the manufacturer's unopened original container. [G.S. §
18B-300(c)]



   PUBLIC STREET.  Any highway, road, street, avenue, boulevard, alley,
bridge, or other way within and/or under the control of the city and open to
public use, including the sidewalks of any such street.



   UNFORTIFIED WINE.  Wine that has an alco- holic content produced only
by natural fermentation or by the addition of pure cane, beet, or dextrose
sugar, and that has an alcoholic content of not more than 17% alcohol by
volume. [G.S. § 18B-101(15)]



(Ord. 95-11-1, passed  - -95)



§ 112.02  CONSUMPTION ON THE PUBLIC STREETS AND ON MUNICIPAL PROPERTY
PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an occupant of a motor
vehicle to consume malt beverages and/or unfortified wine on the public
streets. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any person to consume malt
beverages and/or unfortified wine on any property, whether located inside or
outside the corporate limits, owned, occupied, or controlled by the city
including, but not limited to, public buildings and the grounds appurtenant
thereto, municipal parking lots, public parks, playgrounds, recreational
areas, tennis courts, and other athletic fields.



(Ord. 95-11-1, passed  - -95)  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.03  POSSESSION OF OPEN CONTAINERS ON THE PUBLIC STREETS AND ON
MUNICIPAL PROPERTY PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an occupant of a motor
vehicle to possess any open container of malt beverage and/or unfortified
wine on the public streets. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any person
to possess any open container of malt beverage and/or unfortified wine on any
property, whether located inside or outside the corporate limits, owned,
occupied, or controlled by the city including, but not limited to, public
buildings and the grounds appurtenant thereto; municipal parking lots, public
parks, playgrounds, recreational areas, tennis courts, and other athletic
fields.



(Ord. 95-11-1, passed  - -95)  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.04  POSSESSION DURING SPECIAL EVENTS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to possess malt beverage and/or
unfortified wine on public streets, alleys, or parking lots which are
temporarily closed to regular traffic for special events, unless the
governing body adopts a resolution making other pro- visions for the
possession of malt beverages and/or unfortified wine at the special event.



(Ord. 95-11-1, passed  - -95)  Penalty, see § 112.99



SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES



§ 112.15  SUNDAY SALES HOURS.



   Pursuant to the authority granted in S.L. 2017-87 any establishment
located in the corporate limits of Bessemer City and holding an ABC permit
issued pursuant to G.S. § 18B-1001 is permitted to sell beverages allowed by
its permit beginning at 10:00 a.m. on Sundays.



(Ord. passed 6-11-18)



§ 112.99  PENALTY.



   Violation of §§ 112.01 through 112.04 shall con- stitute a
misdemeanor punishable in accordance with G.S. § 14-4. 



(Ord. 95-11-1, passed  -  -95)



CHAPTER 113:  VENDING



Section




General Provisions

   113.03   Vending prohibited in certain locations



   113.04   Prohibited conduct




Pushcart Vendors




   113.20   Puschart vendors



 



   113.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 113.01  PURPOSE.



   The primary purpose of the public streets and sidewalks is for use by
vehicular and pedestrian traffic. Vending on the public streets and sidewalks
promotes the public interest by contributing to an active and attractive
pedestrian environment. Reason- able regulation of street and sidewalk
vending in the vicinity of a school is necessary to protect the public
health, safety, and welfare. The regulations contained in this chapter do not
prohibit pure speech by religious organizations, but merely regulate the
activities of an organization which are commercial in nature.



(Ord. passed 1-14-85)



§ 113.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   MOTOR VEHICLE.  Any vehicle used for the displaying, storing, or
transporting of articles offered for sale by a vendor which is required to be
licensed and registered by the Department of Motor Vehicles.



   STAND.  Any table, showcase, bench, rack, pushcart, wagon, or other
wheeled vehicle or device which may be moved without the assistance of a
motor and which is not required to be licensed and registered by the
Department of Motor Vehicles, used for the displaying, storing, or
transporting of articles offered for sale by a vendor.



   VENDOR.  Any person engaged in the selling, or the offering for sale,
of food, beverages, or merchandise on the public streets or sidewalks, from a
stand or motor vehicle, or from his person.



(Ord. passed 1-14-85)



§ 113.03  VENDING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN LOCATIONS.



   Vending is prohibited with the following exceptions:



   (A)   Vending on the sidewalks is permitted in the central business
district subject to the restriction contained in § 113.04.



   (B)   Vending from motor vehicles is permitted throughout the city
subject to the restrictions contained in § 113.04.



   (C)   All vendors must possess any and all required business
licenses and permits.



(Ord. passed 1-14-85)



§ 113.04  PROHIBITED CONDUCT.



   No vendor shall vend within 600 feet of the grounds of any elementary
or secondary school between ½ hour prior to the start of the school day, and
½ hour after dismissal at the end of the school day.



(Ord. passed 1-14-85)  Penalty, see § 113.99



PUSHCART VENDORS



§ 113.20  PUSHCART VENDORS.



   (A)   Permit required for operation. Pushcart vendors may operate on
public rights-of-way that are designated by the City council on a map
maintained in the city Zoning Department or in other areas of the city
designated for commercial uses; all pushcarts must obtain and maintain a
permit for each location where the owner of the pushcart intends to operate.
Permit applications shall contain the following information:



      (1)   A food vending permit from Gaston County Health
Department.



      (2)   A valid City of Bessemer City business license.



      (3)   A scaled sketch plan or photographs showing proposed
cart dimensions and location. The cart operation area shall not exceed 100
square feet.



      (4)   A list of products to be sold.



      (5)   Proof of a valid insurance policy that provides a
minimum liability coverage of $1,000,000 with the city named as an additional
insured if on designated public rights-of-way.



      (6)   A written indemnity agreement that will hold harmless
the city, its officers, and employees, for any loss or liability or damage,
including costs, for bodily injury or property damage sustained by a person
as a result of the negligent installation, use, or maintenance of a permitted
space if upon any public rights-of-way.



      (7)   A food permit from the North Carolina Department of
Agriculture if the applicant intends to sell baked goods or ice cream.



   (B)   Permit suspended during special events. All permits issued
pursuant to this section shall be suspended during a special event approved
by the City Council. Carts are excluded within 400 feet of the edge of any
special events area unless the permit holder is given permission from the
event sponsor to set up within the designated event area. No more than three
permits per cart shall be issued to any cart owner.



   (C)   Operation regulations. Pushcarts shall conform to the
following regulations regarding location and operation:



      (1)   Carts must not locate in any area that impedes,
endangers, or interferes with pedestrian or vehicular traffic.



      (2)   Carts selling food products must be located at least 50
feet from the entrance to any business selling food unless the owner of the
other business gives written permission for the infringement of the “no
vending” area.



      (3)   Vendor must provide written permission from the property
owner on which the cart is located.



      (4)   No more than two carts will be allowed on any block face.



   (D)   Design standards. All carts must meet the following design
standards:



      (1)   Carts must be non-motorized with operable wheels.
Persons with disabilities may use a motorized system to propel the cart.



      (2)   All carts must be self-contained with a waste
receptacle. All equipment other than coolers must be contained on or within
the cart.



      (3)   A cart may not exceed six feet in height and nine feet
in length and five feet in width.



      (4)   Umbrellas or canopies must be attached to the cart and
must not exceed eight feet in height above grade. Maximum diameter of
canopies and umbrellas shall not exceed six feet.



      (5)   Carts must be constructed of durable material.



      (6)   Carts must comply with all local, state, and federal
rules regarding sanitation and protection of food from airborne contamination.



      (7)   All signage shall be attached to the cart. No
freestanding signage is permitted.



      (8)   Sales of goods and merchandise are limited to food and
beverage, fresh cut flowers, or original artwork and handicrafts produced by
the vendor. All items for sale must be confined to the cart. Food vendors may
place a maximum of three coolers within their containment area so long as the
coolers are neatly stacked to avoid visual clutter. No generators may be used
at any time.



      (9)   A vendor may maintain one chair for his or her own use.
No public seating is allowed. Pushcarts may not be stored, parked, or left
overnight on any city property.



      (10)   Carts may only be operated between the hours of 6:00
a.m. and 12:00 a.m. The operator must be present at all times and must have a
valid permit on his or her person or on the cart at all times.



      (11)   The operator is responsible for all waste and trash
removal. The containment area must be kept clear of grease, trash, paper,
cups or cans associated with the operation.



   (E)   Revocation of license. Any violation of this section may
result in a revocation of the business license.



(Ord. passed 4-9-12)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed
$500 or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months, or by both
fine and imprisonment.



(Ord. passed 1-14-85)

Statutory reference:



   Authority to regulate and license businesses, see G.S. § 160A-194



   Authority to regulate and control taxicab drivers, see G.S. § 20-37



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 114.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DRIVER.  A person who, by manipulation of the mechanism of a vehicle
or by other means, causes the vehicle to move, increase or decrease speed,
change direction or stop moving.



   OPERATOR.  A person who owns or manages a taxicab business or other
business in which one or more vehicles are made available for hire.



('75 Code, § 15-1)



§ 114.02  ESTABLISHMENT OF RATES; TAXICAB METERS.



   The City Council may establish rates to be charged by taxicab
operators, and all such rates so established shall be maintained on file in
the office of the City Clerk. The City Council may require that each taxicab
be equipped with a taxicab meter, to be maintained by the operator of such
taxicab in a serviceable and accurate condition at all times.



('75 Code, § 15-2)



§ 114.03  RATES TO BE DISPLAYED IN CABS.



   Every taxicab driven within the city or between the city and points not
incorporated within a radius of five miles of the city shall have at all
times prominently posted and displayed in such taxicab, so as to be visible
to the passengers therein, the rates and fares for the use of such cab.



('75 Code, § 15-3) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.04  EXCESSIVE CHARGES PROHIBITED.



   No person operating or driving a taxicab shall charge or attempt to
charge any passenger a greater rate of fare than that to which he is entitled
under the provisions of this chapter.  All taxicab drivers shall travel the
nearest and most direct route to the point of destination unless directed to
do otherwise by the passenger.



('75 Code, § 15-4)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.05  PROHIBITED USES OF TAXICABS BY DRIVERS AND OPERATORS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person holding a city taxicab
driver's permit to accept or retain as a passenger in a taxicab driven by him
any person who he knows, or has reasonable suspicion to believe, to be then
and there in illegal possession of any alcoholic beverage, drug, narcotic or
marijuana.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person holding a city taxicab
driver's permit to transport within a taxicab driven by him any alcoholic
beverage, drug, narcotic, or marijuana which is known by him, or which he has
reasonable suspicion to believe, to have been unlawfully obtained by or for
the person to whom it is to be delivered or is to be used in a manner
contrary to law.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person holding a city taxicab
driver's permit to accept or retain as a passenger in a taxicab driven by him
any person who he knows, or has reasonable suspicion to believe, is then and
there bent upon the purpose of using the taxicab as a place for the
commission of any act of prostitution or as a means of travel to a place for
the commission of any act of prostitution.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person holding a city taxicab
operator's permit to knowingly counten- ance any violation of any other
division of this section by any taxicab driver in his employment.



('75 Code, § 15-5) (Ord. 57, passed  - - )  Penalty, see § 10.99



OPERATOR'S PERMITS



§ 114.10  OPERATOR'S PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   No person shall engage in the business of operating a taxicab
or other motor vehicle for hire in the city or between the city and points
not incorporated within a radius of five miles of the city unless there has
been duly issued to him by the City Council a written permit to engage in
such business. The issuance of any permit shall be within the discretion of
the City Council and no permit shall be issued to any person it may find to
be unfit to operate a taxicab, and the Council may refuse to issue any permit
if public convenience and necessity does not require the services of an
additional taxicab or other vehicle for hire.



   (B)   Permits issued pursuant to division (A) of this section may
contain such prohibitions, restrictions and conditions as may be deemed
prudent by the City Council in the best interests of the city and its
inhabitants and not contrary to law, this code, or other ordinance.



('75 Code, § 15-6) (Ord. 56, passed 9-5-49)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.11  PROOF OF FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY.



   No operator's permit shall be issued under this chapter until the
applicant therefor has filed with the City Clerk proof of financial
responsibility as provided in G.S. § 20-280.



('75 Code, § 15-7) (Ord. No. 56, passed 9-5-49)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.12  CONTENTS OF OPERATOR'S PERMIT; REQUIREMENTS.



   No operator's permit under this chapter shall be valid unless
authorized by the City Council, signed by the City Manager and attested to by
the City Clerk on a written form prepared by the City Attorney and approved
by the City Council. Each permit must also be signed by the person to whom it
is issued, indicating his acceptance thereof under the conditions set forth
in this chapter.



('75 Code, § 15-8) (Ord. 56, passed 9-5-49)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.13  EXPIRATION OF OPERATOR'S PERMITS.



   Any operator's permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall become void
when the person to whom it is issued shall discontinue to engage in the
business authorized, and otherwise, unless revoked as herein provided, each
permit shall expire on the last day of June following the date of issuance
thereof.



('75 Code, § 15-9)



§ 114.14  OPERATOR'S PERMIT FEE; ANNUAL LICENSE TAX.



   Concurrently with the issuance of an operator's permit under this
chapter, the operator shall pay to the City Clerk a permit fee of $5 and a
license tax, computed at the rate of $1.25 per month from the date of
issuance of the permit until the next following 30th day of June, for each
taxicab authorized to be operated under the permit; and thereafter, on or
before the first day of July of each year, such operator shall pay a license
tax of $15 for each taxicab authorized to be operated under the permit.



('75 Code, § 15-10) (Ord. 56, passed 9-5-49)



Statutory reference:



   Authority to levy not to exceed tax on taxicab vehicles, see G.S. §
20-97(a)



§ 114.15  TRANSFER OF PERMIT OR LICENSE.



   No operator's permit or license under this chapter may be sold, leased,
assigned, or otherwise transferred except to the heirs, legatees, executors,
or administrators of a deceased permit holder who may desire to continue the
business authorized by the permit, with the approval of the City Council.



('75 Code, § 15-11) (Ord. 56, passed 9-5-49)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.16  REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.



   (A)   An operator's permit under this chapter may be revoked by the
City Council at any time, upon proof satisfactory to the Council, that the
operator has violated, or that he knew or in the exercise of ordinary care he
should have known that a driver employed by him has violated any provision of
G.S. Ch. 18B appertaining to the transportation of alcoholic beverages; or
has committed any offense involving moral turpitude; or has violated any
provision of this chapter; or has suffered any vehicle authorized in the
permit to be driven while on business in an unsafe or unsanitary condition;
or has not maintained the liability insurance required by G.S. § 20-280; or
has violated any prohibition, restriction, or condition contained in his
operator's permit; or has been convicted of or paid fines for more than six
traffic violations in any one month.



   (B)   Prior to the revocation of an operator's permit under division
(A) of this section the City Council shall cause written notice to be given
the permit holder, stating the grounds for revocation and notifying him that
he shall be afforded, upon his request, an opportunity to be heard before the
Council in public, in person or by attorney, or both, with witnesses in his
behalf, at the next regular or special meeting of the Council after the
seventh day following service of such notice; and the Council shall comply
with any such request of the permit holder as herein provided, and shall not
revoke a permit until after such requested public hearing.



   (C)   The City Council, following notice given as  provided in
division (B) of this section, may suspend an operator's permit for any cause
specified in division (A) of this section, until such time as a permit may be
revoked under this section; provided, that the City Council shall find that
such suspension is immediately necessary to protect the safety of the
inhabitants of the city.



('75 Code, § 15-12) (Ord. 56, passed 9-5-49)



§ 114.17  COMPLIANCE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of
operator or driver of a taxicab or other vehicle for hire without a currently
valid permit so to do, or to operate a taxicab or other vehicle for hire
without having paid the license tax for the current year as provided in this
chapter, or to other-wise violate or fail to comply with any provision of
this chapter.



('75 Code, § 15-13) (Ord. 56, passed 9-5-49) Penalty, see § 10.99



TAXICAB DRIVER'S PERMITS



§ 114.25  TAXICAB DRIVER'S PERMIT AND CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   No person shall drive any taxicab carrying passengers for hire
from place to place within the city, or between the city and points not
incorporated within a radius of five miles of the city, unless he shall have
first applied to and secured from the City Council a taxicab driver's permit.



   (B)   No person shall drive any taxicab carrying passengers for hire
from place to place within the city, or between the city and points not
incorporated within a radius of five miles of the city, unless he shall have
in his possession a city taxicab driver's permit and a state chauffeur's
license, each currently in effect.



   (C)   Each city taxicab driver's permit must be signed by the person
to whom it is issued, indicating his acceptance thereof under the conditions
set forth in this chapter.



('75 Code, § 15-14) (Ord. 56, passed 9-5-49)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.26  APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; ANNUAL RENEWAL.



   An application for an original taxicab driver's permit may be made at
any time while the applicant is qualified for issuance of such permit to him.
All applications for annual renewal of taxicab drivers' permits shall be made
before January 1 of each year, and no reduction in the permit fee shall be
made for any renewal of permit for which application is made after January 1.



('75 Code, § 15-15)



§ 114.27  FORM AND CONTENTS OF APPLICATION.



   (A)   Each applicant for a taxicab driver's permit shall make
application therefor upon forms provided by the City Clerk for such purpose,
and he shall state thereon, among other things, his name, address, physical
condition and physical description, former employers, court record, state
chauffeur's license number, and length of residence in this state and in this
county. Such application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant.



   (B)   The applicant shall then appear at the office of the Police
Department for the purpose of having his fingerprints taken and photograph
made, both of which shall constitute a part of his application.



   (C)   The original copy of each application shall be retained on
file in the office of the City Clerk, and duplicate copies shall remain on
file in the office of the Chief of Police.



('75 Code, § 15-16)



§ 114.28  INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT BY POLICE CHIEF.



   The City Clerk, upon receipt of a sworn applica- tion for a taxicab
driver's permit, shall transmit a copy thereof promptly to the Chief of
Police, who shall investigate the facts stated therein. The Chief of Police
shall then report his findings and recommenda- tions to the City Council.



('75 Code, § 15-17)



§ 114.29  QUALIFICATIONS FOR GRANTING PERMIT.



   If the City Council or its authorized committee finds that an applicant
for a taxicab driver's permit has not been convicted of a felony, a violation
of any federal or state statute relating to the use, trans- portation,
possession or sale of intoxicating liquors, any federal or state statute
relating to prostitution, or any federal or state statute relating to the
use, trans- portation, possession, or sale of narcotic drugs; and that the
applicant is a citizen of the United States and has resided in the county for
at least one year or in the state for at least 30 days and is not a habitual
user of intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs, and has not been an habitual
violator of traffic laws, the City Council or its authorized committee shall
order the City Clerk to issue a taxicab driver's permit to such applicant.



('75 Code, § 15-18)



§ 114.30  WAITING PERIOD; TEMPORARY PERMIT.



   No taxicab driver's permit shall be issued until 15 days after
application therefor has been made, provided that a temporary permit may be
granted by an authorized committee of the City Council pending investigation
to any person meeting the requirement as to residence in North Carolina as
set out in § 114.29. Such temporary permit shall be valid for a period of 72
hours after issuance thereof.



('75 Code, § 15-19)



§ 114.31  FEES.



   The City Clerk shall charge a fee of $3 for each original taxicab
driver's permit and a fee of $.50 for each annual renewal thereof.



('75 Code, § 15-20)



§ 114.32  FORM OF PERMIT.



   Taxicab drivers' permits shall be in substantially the following form
and must be displayed at all times when operating a taxi.



   “Taxicab Driver's Permit



   Permit number              City of Bessemer City, N.C.



               Date of issuance          



               Date of expiration        



   Issued to:                                       
         



   Address:                                         
           



   Age       Weight       Height       Race       Color of
hair:       Color of eyes:        



   Good until expiration date shown above unless earlier revoked by the
City Council of the City of Bessemer City, N.C.



            (Signed)                             
         



                  City Clerk.”



('75 Code, § 15-21)



§ 114.33  DURATION OF PERMIT; RENEWALS.



   A taxicab driver's permit granted pursuant to this chapter shall
entitle the person to whom it is granted to drive a taxicab until the
expiration of December 31 of the year in which it is granted, and it shall be
necessary for the holder of the permit to obtain a new permit as provided in
this chapter before he is allowed to drive a taxicab during any year
thereafter.



('75 Code, § 15-22)



§ 114.34  DISPLAY OF PERMIT.



   The driver of every taxicab shall, at all times while operating such
taxicab, prominently post and display in the taxicab, so as to be visible to
the passengers therein, his permit to drive a taxicab, with his photograph
attached.



('75 Code, § 15-23)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.35  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION FOR JUST CAUSE.



   The City Council retains the power to suspend or revoke for just cause
any taxicab driver's permit, and may consider that just cause exists if the
person holding such permit is convicted of a felony, a viola- tion of any
federal or state statute relating to the use, transportation, possession or
sale of intoxicating liquors, a violation of any federal or state statute
relating to the use, transportation, possession, or sale of narcotic drugs,
repeated violations of traffic laws or ordinances, a violation of any state
or federal statute relating to prostitution, or becomes a habitual user of
intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs, pro- vided, that this enumeration of
grounds which may be considered as just cause shall not be construed as
exclusive.



('75 Code, § 15-24)



§ 114.36  VALIDITY OF PERMITS.



   Taxicab drivers permits valid immediately prior to the effective date
of this code are hereby continued in full force and effect for a period of 60
days after the effective date of this code, to enable the permit holders to
comply with the provisions of this chapter.



('75 Code, § 15-25)



CHAPTER 115:  ADULT BUSINESSES



Section



   115.01   Definitions



   115.02   Location regulations



§ 115.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ADULT CABARET.  Any place featuring top- less dancers, go-go dancers,
strippers, male or female impersonators, or entertainers displaying specified
anatomical areas as defined by G.S. § 14-202.10 as such statute may be
amended from time to time, or other similar entertainers.



   ADULT ESTABLISHMENT.  Any place as defined by G.S. § 14-202.10 as
such statute may be amended from time to time, including adult cabarets,
except that the definition of massage business shall not include any
establishment or business where massage is practiced that is a health club,
exercise studio, hospital, physical therapy business, or other similar
health-related business. ADULT ESTAB-LISHMENT specifically includes, however,
any massage business where massages are rendered by any person exhibiting
specified anatomical areas.Specified anatomical areas are those defined by
G.S. § 14-202.10 as such statute may be amended from time to time, or other
similar entertainers.



(Ord. passed 11-15-94)



§ 115.02  LOCATION REGULATIONS.



   The following regulations shall apply to the location of any business
defined as an adult estab- lishment or adult cabaret:



   (A)   No such business shall locate within 1000 feet of any other
adult establishment as measured in a straight line from property line to
property line, with no consideration as to intervening structures, roads, or
land forms.



   (B)   No adult establishment shall be located within 1000 feet of a
church, public or private elementary or secondary school, child day care or
nursery school, public park or playground, or residentially zoned property.
The 1000 foot distance shall be measured in a straight line from property
line to property line, with no consideration as to intervening structures,
roads, or landforms.



   (C)   There shall not be more than one adult establishment on the
same property or in the same building, structure, or portion thereof.



   (D)   No other principal or accessory use may occupy the same
building, structure, property, or portion thereof with any adult
establishment.



   (E)   No printed material, slide, video, photo- graph, written
materials, live show, or other visual presentation shall be visible, nor
shall any live or recorded voices, music, or sounds be heard from outside the
walls of the establishment.



   (F)   Wall signs as defined and permitted in Chapter 155 of this
code are permitted as a means of advertising adult establishments. No
freestanding signs shall be permitted. No other advertisement, displays, or
signs or other promotional materials shall be visible to the public from
pedestrian sidewalks, walkways, or vehicular areas.



   (G)   Maximum gross floor area of the principal building shall be
2,000 square feet.



(Ord. passed 11-15-94)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 116:  GAME ROOMS AND OTHER PUBLIC AMUSEMENTS



Section



   116.01   Definitions



   116.02   Licenses required



   116.03   Certain prohibitions to be observed by licensee and
employees



   116.04   Rules for operation



   116.05   Licensee responsible



   116.06   Revocation of licenses



   116.07   Enforcement of chapter



§ 116.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   GAME ROOM.



      (1)   Any place of business that operates five or more
mechanical games, video games, pool tables, pay devices or tables for which
charge is made either directly or indirectly. Electronic gaming operations,
include internet sweepstakes and other games of chance, shall not be
considered a GAME ROOM.



      (2)   Examples of game rooms, by way of illustration and not
limitation, are poolrooms, bowling alleys, billiard halls, video arcades,
amusement centers, and the like.



(Ord. 96-11-1, passed 11-11-96; Am. Ord. passed 7-9-07; Am. Res. passed
5-14-12)



§ 116.02  LICENSES REQUIRED.



   (A)   Every owner of a game room shall apply for and obtain a
license from the City Manager to operate a game room.  Application for such
a license shall be made upon forms provided by the City Clerk.  It shall be
unlawful to operate a game room within the city without a license as required
by this chapter.



   (B)   The City Manager shall not issue a license to any applicant
who:



      (1)   Has been convicted within the past two years of selling
intoxicating liquors and/or narcotic drugs, or of any felony.



      (2)   Is not a citizen and resident of North Carolina.



      (3)   Is a habitual user of intoxicating liquor or narcotic
drugs.



   (C)   Upon receipt of the application to operate a game room, the
matter shall be placed upon the agenda for the next regular City Council
meeting.  Council may grant or deny any license application without cause.



   (D)   The license shall only authorize the operation of the game
room by the owner to whom the license is issued, and at the location
specified in the application.  Licenses shall not be transferrable and shall
automatically expire two years from date of issuance.



   (E)   Every license issued pursuant to this chapter shall specify
the premises for which it is used, the number of tables, alleys, or games to
be operated, the name and address of the owner, and the dates upon which the
license begins and shall expire. License shall be posted in a prominent place
on the premises at all times.



   (F)   An application fee of $25 shall be paid to and collected by
the Finance Officer when the application is submitted, to cover the cost of
administration of this chapter.



(Ord. 96-11-1, passed 11-11-96; Am. Ord. passed 7-9-07)  Penalty, see §
10.99



§ 116.03  CERTAIN PROHIBITIONS TO BE OBSERVED BY LICENSEE AND EMPLOYEES.



   Licensees under this chapter shall not directly, or through their
employees and agents:



   (A)   Suffer or permit any gambling on the licensed premises at any
time; nor the sale or use of any racing, football, or other parley cards.



   (B)   Suffer or permit the licensed premises to become disorderly;
or permit any profane, obscene, or indecent language thereon.



   (C)   Suffer or permit any intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs to
be sold or kept or consumed on the licensed premises.



   (D)   Employ any person who has been convicted in the past year of
unlawfully selling alcoholic beverages, narcotic drugs or any felony.



   (E)   Suffer or permit any person under 18 years of age to enter or
remain upon the licensed premises.



   (F)   Suffer or permit the willful violation of any of the General
Statutes of North Carolina.



(Ord. 96-11-1, passed 11-11-96; Am. Ord. passed 7-9-07)  Penalty, see §
10.99



§ 116.04  RULES FOR OPERATION.



   The following rules shall be observed by all operators of poolrooms,
bowling alleys, and other amusements required to be licensed by this chapter
within the city:



   (A)   Game room establishments shall at all times be subject to
entry by the City Manager or Police



Officers for the purpose of verifying compliance with the terms and
conditions of this chapter.



   (B)   All game rooms shall close no later than 11:59 p.m., Sunday
through Saturday. All game rooms may open no earlier than 7:00 a.m., Monday
through Saturday, and no earlier than 1:00 p.m. on Sundays.



   (C)   Play on any table, alley, or machine shall be allowed only
during the hours set forth herein.



   (D)   The establishment shall remain closed on Sundays, except as
provided in division (B) above.



   (E)   No game or device shall, however, be screened from view so as
to not be readily visible from within the premises.



   (F)   No screens, curtains, blinds, partitions, or other obstruction
shall be placed between the entrance to the room where amusements or games
are played and the rear wall of the room.  A clear view of the interior
premises from the entrance to the rear of the premises must be maintained at
all times.



(Ord. 96-11-1, passed 11-11-96; Am. Ord. passed 7-9-07)  Penalty, see §
10.99



§ 116.05  LICENSEE RESPONSIBLE.



   The acts and conduct of the agents and employees of the licensee in the
conduct of the business shall be deemed to be the acts and conduct of the
licensee. Additionally, the licensee and employees shall not permit patrons
to loiter in or about the premises.



(Ord. 96-11-1, passed 11-11-96; Am. Ord. passed 7-9-07)  Penalty, see §
10.99



§ 116.06  REVOCATION OF LICENSES.



   (A)   After giving the operator of a game room adequate notice and
an opportunity to be heard, the City Council may revoke the license of any
game room operator who:



      (1)   Violates the provisions of this chapter, or



      (2)   Is convicted of unlawfully selling alcoholic beverages
or narcotic drugs.



   (B)   (1)   Additionally, the City Manager may temporarily revoke
the license of a game room upon a particularly egregious act or situation
involving the licensee, employees or patrons. 



      (2)   When license is so revoked, City Council, or a committee
thereof, shall hear any appeal of the action within two weeks.



(Ord. 96-11-1, passed 11-11-96; Am. Ord. passed 7-9-07)



§ 116.07  ENFORCEMENT OF CHAPTER.



   The provisions of this chapter may be enforced by any of the remedies
enumerated in § 10.99 of this Code.



(Ord. 96-11-1, passed 11-11-96; Am. Ord. passed 7-9-07)



CHAPTER 117:  ESCORT AND DATING SERVICES



Section



   117.01   Escort and dating services; purpose and intent



   117.02   Definitions



   117.03   Permit required



   117.04   Application for escort or dating service permit



   117.05   Registration of escorts



   117.06   Revocation



   117.07   Appeals



§ 117.01  ESCORT AND DATING SERVICES; PURPOSE AND INTENT.



   Experience has shown that escort and dating services are frequently
fronts for prostitution. Experience has also shown that applicants for an
escort, dating service or similar type business privilege license under
Chapter 110 of the City Code frequently provide false information. It is the
intent of this chapter to ensure that owners and operators of escort and
dating services provide accurate and verifiable information about the
business and to establish accountability for any attempt to use an escort or
dating service as a front for prostitution.



(Ord. 97-5-2, passed 5-12-97)



§ 117.02  DEFINITIONS.



   DATING SERVICE.  Any business, agency or person who offers or performs
for pecuniary compensation any service to aid persons to become socially
acquainted or to otherwise assist persons to meet for social purposes.



   ESCORT.  A person who is an employee, agent or independent contractor
of an escort service, and:



      (1)   Whose name is furnished by the escort service; or



      (2)   Who is introduced or furnished by the escort service to
persons; or



      (3)   Who is provided by the escort service for the
accompaniment of other persons to or about social affairs, entertainments or
places of amusement; or



      (4)   Who is provided by the escort service to consort with
others about any public or private place; and



      (5)   Who receives pecuniary compensation in exchange therefor.



   ESCORT SERVICE.  Any business, agency or person who for pecuniary
compensation furnishes or offers to furnish names of escorts, or who
introduces, furnishes or arranges for escorts, who may accompany other
persons to or about social affairs, entertainments or places of amusement, or
who may consort with others about any public or private place.



   PERMITTING AUTHORITY.  The Chief of Police in the Bessemer City Police
Department or his designee.



   PERSON.  Any natural individual, firm, partnership, corporation or
association.



(Ord. 97-5-2, passed 5-12-97)



§ 117.03  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct, carry on, or
to permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, the operation of (a) an
escort service as herein defined, without a valid escort service permit
issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, or (b) a dating service as
herein defined, without a valid dating service permit issued pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter. The issuance of an escort service permit does not
authorize the permit holder to operate a dating service. The issuance of a
dating service permit does not authorize the permit holder to operate an
escort service. A separate permit shall be required for each location within
the city at which a dating service or escort service is established or name
under which it operates. An escort service or dating service permit is not
transferrable.



(Ord. 97-5-2, passed 5-12-97)



§ 117.04  APPLICATION FOR ESCORT OR DATING SERVICE PERMIT.



   (A)   Any person desiring to obtain a permit to operate an escort
service or dating service shall make application to the Permitting Authority.



   (B)   An applicant for an escort service permit or dating service
permit shall provide the following:



      (1)   The full true name of the applicant/ owner of the
business.



      (2)   The full true name under which the business will be
conducted and, if the business will be conducted in a name other than that of
the applicant/owner, a certified copy of an assumed name certificate prepared
and recorded in the Gaston County Register of Deeds Office.



      (3)   The address where the business is to be conducted and
where the books and records are maintained for examination by the collector
of revenue, or his agent, pursuant to § 110.12 of this Code, and the hours
of operation during which the books and records are available for examination.



      (4)   If the owner of the real property upon which the
business is to be conducted is not the applicant,  the name and address of
the owner of  the real property upon which the business is to be conducted
and a copy of the lease or rental agreement.



      (5)   All telephone numbers to be used by the business.



      (6)   If the applicant/owner is a natural person, the
applicant/owner shall appear in person and complete and sign all applications
forms and provide the following information: (a) the present residence and
business addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant, (b) a valid
drivers license or other governmental issued picture identification, and (c)
government issued social security card.



   If the applicant/owner is a partnership: (a) the names and residence
addresses of each partner, including limited partners, and (b) a copy of the
partnership agreement. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the
provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply.



   If the applicant/owner is a corporation: (a) a certified copy of the
Articles of Incorporation, or if a foreign corporation, a certified copy of
the certificate of authority, and a certified copy of the most recent annual
report filed with the Secretary of State of North Carolina, and (b) the names
and residence addresses of each of its current officers and directors, and of
each stockholder holding more than five percent of the stock of the
corporation.



   If the applicant/owner is a partnership or corporation, the applicant
shall designate one of its general partners or officers to act as its
responsible managing officer. Such person shall appear in person and complete
and sign all application forms, and shall provide his or her present
residence and business addresses and telephone numbers, a valid drivers
license or other governmental issued picture identification, and government
issued social security card.



      (7)   A federal tax identification number assigned to the
business and a completed tax information authorization form (IRS Form 8821).



   (C)   Within 30 days of application, the Permitting Authority shall
investigate an application and verify all information submitted. If the
application is complete and all information provided is accurate, a permit
shall be issued. If the application is incomplete or if any information
provided is inaccurate, the application shall be denied.



   (D)   The holder of an escort service permit or dating service
permit shall notify the Permitting Authority in writing of any change of
information required under division (B) within 30 days of such change.



(Ord. 97-5-2, passed 5-12-97)



§ 117.05  REGISTRATION OF ESCORTS.



   Any person desiring to operate as an escort shall appear in person and
register with the Permitting Authority by providing the following information:



   (A)   Full true name and any alias(es) that might be used while
acting as an escort.



   (B)   Present residence address and telephone number.



   (C)   Valid drivers license or other governmental issued picture
identification.



   (D)   Government issued social security card.



   (E)   Name of the escort service(s) for which the registrant is an
employee, agent, or independent contractor.



(Ord. 97-5-2, passed 5-12-97)



§ 117.06  REVOCATION.



   The Permitting Authority may revoke an escort service permit or dating
service permit for any of the following reasons:



   (A)   An applicant/owner provides the Permitting Authority with any
false, inaccurate, or incomplete information, regardless of whether such
information was initially believed to be true or complete.



   (B)   Failure to provide notice of change in information as required
by § 117.04(D).



   (C)   The furnishing of or offer to furnish names of escorts who are
not registered as escorts of the escort service pursuant to § 117.05, or the
introduction, furnishing or arrangement for escorts who are not register as
escorts of the escort service pursuant to § 117.05, who may accompany other
persons to or about social affairs, entertainments or places of amusement, or
who may consort with others about any public or private place.



   (D)   A dating service permit may be revoked for operation of an
escort service without a valid escort service permit.



   (E)   The escort service or dating service engages in, conducts,
permits, promotes or facilitates activities which constitute violations of
any subdivision of G.S. §§ 14-204 or 14-277, or which constitute
solicitations to commit violations of any subdivisions of those statutes.



(Ord. 97-5-2, passed 5-12-97)



§ 117.07  APPEALS.



   An applicant/owner may appeal the denial or revocation of an escort
service permit or dating service permit by providing written notice of appeal
to the Permitting Authority within ten business days of a denial or
revocation. Appeals shall be heard by the City Manager within 15 working days
from date of appeal.



CHAPTER 118:  SOLICITATION AND PEDDLERS



Section



   118.01   Purpose



   118.02   Invitation to dwellings required



   118.03   Permit process



   118.04   Display of permit required



 



   118.99   Penalty



§ 118.01  PURPOSE.



   It is the intent of the City Council in enacting this chapter to
improve the quality of life and economic vitality of the city, and to protect
the safety and general welfare of the general public, by imposing reasonable
restrictions on solicitation while respecting the constitutional rights of
free speech for all citizens.  The authority to enact this chapter is given
in G.S. § 160A-178.



(Res. passed 10-12-09)



§ 118.02  INVITATION TO DWELLINGS REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful, unless with the prior permission or
invitation of the owner or occupant, for any person to enter upon any
privately owned premises in the city used as a dwelling for the purpose of
soliciting orders for the immediate or future delivery of goods, merchandise,
or services, specifically including the taking of subscriptions for magazines.



   (B)   This section shall not apply to solicitation for charitable,
civic, religious or patriotic purposes by persons who serve without
compensation or remuneration, provided such person shall have first obtained
a permit from the city.



(Res. passed 10-12-09)  Penalty, see § 118.99



§ 118.03  PERMIT PROCESS.



   (A)   Any person desiring a permit to engage in business as a
solicitor or peddler within the city shall make written application to the
city on a form provided by the city.



   (B)   Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this
chapter, the applicant shall furnish a bond in the sum of $1,000 to the city
signed by the applicant and signed as surety by some surety company
authorized to do business in North Carolina, conditioned upon the final
delivery of goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, magazines, and
newspapers in accordance with the terms of any order obtained prior to
delivery and also conditioned to indemnify any and all purchasers or
customers for any and all defects in material or workmanship that may exist
in the article sold by the principal on such bond, at the time of delivery,
and that may be discovered by such purchaser or customer within 30 days after
delivery.  Such bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons that
may make any purchase or give any order to the principal on such bond, or to
any agent or employee of the principal.  Only one bond shall be required for
each applicant.



   (C)   Applicants soliciting for charitable, civic, religious, or
patriotic purposes without compensation or remuneration shall be exempt from
the bond requirement.



   (D)   Permits issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be
valid for 14 days.



   (E)   All permit applications shall be approved by city staff.



(Res. passed 10-12-09)



§ 118.04  DISPLAY OF PERMIT.



   (A)   Every solicitor or peddler licensed under the provisions of
this chapter and doing business within the city shall display his or her
permit upon the request of any person.  Failure to display such license
shall be deemed a misdemeanor.



   (B)   Any permit issued under the provisions of this chapter may be
revoked for the violation by the permittee of any applicable provision of
this chapter, state law or city ordinance, rule, or regulation.



(Res. passed 10-12-09)  Penalty, see § 118.99



§ 118.99  PENALTY.



   The provisions of this chapter may be enforced by any of the remedies
enumerated in § 10.99 of this Code.



(Res. passed 10-12-09)



CHAPTER 119:  SIDEWALK CAFÉ AND PUBLIC SPACE DINING



Section



   119.01   General



   119.02   Permit required



   119.03   Application



   119.04   Issuance of permit



   119.05   Alcoholic beverages



   119.06   Denial



   119.07   Terms; transfer



   119.08   Permit suspension



   119.09   Permit revocation



§ 119.01  GENERAL.



   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this code to the contrary,
sidewalk cafes and dining areas shall be permitted in the Central Business
District and Downtown Overlay District as indicated on the official zoning
map of the city and shall be subject to regulations as are set forth in this
chapter.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No restaurant owner may operate a sidewalk café without first
obtaining a permit from the City Manager in accordance with the requirements
of this chapter. As used in this section, the term CITY MANAGER includes his
or her authorized representative.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.03  APPLICATION.



   Any restaurant owner desiring to operate a sidewalk café shall prepare
and file an application with the City Manager which shall contain the
following information:



   (A)   The name, addresses and telephone number of the restaurant
desiring to operate a sidewalk café;



   (B)   The name, address and telephone number of the restaurant
operator;



   (C)   The type of food, beverage or food product to be sold and
served at the sidewalk café;



   (D)   The hours of operation of the restaurant and the proposed
hours of operation of the sidewalk café;



   (E)   A site plan showing the section of sidewalk or pedestrian way
to be used for the sidewalk café, and the section to be kept clear for
pedestrian and fire lane use, and depicting the proposed placement of tables,
chairs, umbrellas, trash receptacles and other furnishings on the sidewalk or
pedestrian way;



   (F)   Proof of an insurance policy, issued by an insurance company
licensed to do business in the state, protecting the permittee and the city
from all claims for damages to property and bodily injury, including death,
which may arise from operation under or in connection with the permit. The
insurance shall name the city as additional insured and shall provide that
the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the expiration date
without 30 days advance written notice to the city. The insurance shall
afford minimum limits of $1,000,000 aggregate annually. In addition to the
aforesaid general liability coverage provided by permittee on behalf of city,
the permittee shall also offer proof of a liquor liability policy or
endorsement issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the
state, which protects the permittee and the city from all claims for damages
to property or bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operation
under or in connection with the permit (and specifically for the sale and
consumption of alcoholic beverages as authorized by this chapter). Additional
liquor liability policy or endorsement shall name the city as additional
insured and shall provide that the policy or endorsement shall not terminate
or be cancelled prior to the expiration date without 30 days written notice
to the city. The liquor liability insurance policy or endorsement shall
afford minimum limits of $1,000,000 aggregate annually;



   (G)   A copy of all the permits and licenses issued by the county,
state or the city, including health and ABC permits and business licenses,
necessary for the operation of the restaurant business, or a copy of the
application for the permit if no permit has been issued. This requirement
includes any permits or certificates issued by the city or other governmental
authority, for exterior alterations or improvements to the restaurant;



   (H)   A sworn statement describing any violation by the restaurant
operator of any laws, regulations or ordinances relating to the possession,
sale consumption or transportation of intoxicating beverages or controlled
substances during the five years immediately preceding the date of the permit
application;



   (I)   Additional information as may be requested by the City Manager
or his or her designee in order to determine compliance with this section; and



   (J)   An annual fee in the amount as set forth in the fee schedule
to cover the cost of processing and investigating the application and issuing
the permit.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.04  ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.



   No permit for the operation of a sidewalk café may be issued unless
the application is complete and the following requirements are met.



   (A)   The sidewalk café must be associated with an operating
restaurant so that it is under the same management and shares the same food
preparation facilities, restroom facilities and other customer convenience
facilities as the restaurant. The sidewalk café must be operated under the
same name as the restaurant and may not be open or operated at any time when
the restaurant is not open for business.



   (B)   The operation of the sidewalk café must be clearly incidental
to the associated restaurant business. The seating capacity of the sidewalk
café may not be more than 50% of the interior seating capacity of the
associated restaurant.



   (C)   The placement of tables, chairs and other furnishings as shown
in the site plan must be done in a manner that at least five feet of
unobstructed space (as measured from the building façade or, in the absence
of a building façade, a straight line connecting the building façades)
remains on the sidewalk or pedestrian way for the passage of pedestrians. No
fire exits or lanes may be blocked and must remain clear at all times. The
pedestrian passage may not be used for the display of merchandise or for
portable signs otherwise authorized.



   (D)   The restaurant seeking to operate the sidewalk café must
front on and open onto the sidewalk or pedestrian way proposed for the
sidewalk café. The placement of tables, chairs and other furnishings may not
extend beyond the sidewalk or pedestrian way frontage of the associated
restaurant, with the following exception: tables, chairs and other
furnishings may extend up to eight feet onto adjacent property frontage in
either or both directions with the written permission (provided at the time
of application) of the occupant of the adjacent property.



   (E)   The tables, chairs and other furnishings used in the sidewalk
café shall not be anchored and shall be of a type of street furniture that
is easily movable.



   (F)   Except as elsewhere permitted by the code, the operation or
furnishing of the sidewalk café shall involve no permanent alteration to or
encroachment upon any street, sidewalk or pedestrian way or to the exterior
of the associated restaurant.



   (G)   Each sidewalk café shall provide adequate trash removal for
its patrons. At the end of each business day and during operating hours, the
operator shall remove all trash and debris of any sort from the sidewalk
area. In addition, the operator shall remove from the sidewalk alongside and
abutting properties any trash or debris originating as a result of the
operation of the sidewalk café.



   (H)   Tables, chairs and other furnishings that remain on the
sidewalk at times when the business is not in operation shall be secured in a
manner that allows clear access from the street equal to or exceeding half of
the frontage of the associated restaurant.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.05  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.



   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this code, alcoholic beverages
may be served in approved sidewalk cafés provided that the following
requirements are met.



   (A)   The sidewalk café shall be part of a restaurant and shall
otherwise be authorized, permitted or licensed under the state law and this
code to serve and sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption.



   (B)   The sidewalk café must be included as part of the premises
for which an ABC permit is issued pursuant to state law, for the purpose of
applying and enforcing state laws regarding the sale or consumption of
alcoholic beverages.



   (C)   Signs shall be posted, visible at all exit points from the
sidewalk café, that it is unlawful to remove alcoholic beverages from the
premises.



   (D)   The restaurant operator shall not have violated any law,
regulation or ordinance relating to the possession, sale, transportation or
consumption of intoxicating beverages or controlled substances for the three
years preceding the commencement of the sale of alcoholic beverages at the
sidewalk café.



   (E)   No outdoor bar is allowed within the sidewalk café, nor shall
outdoor preparation of alcoholic beverages be permitted, except that
unfortified wine may be decanted or beer poured at a table as part of a meal.



   (F)   Any alcoholic beverages served and consumed at an approved
sidewalk café must be served and consumed in glasses or cups.



   (G)   Any alcoholic beverages served and consumed at an approved
sidewalk café can only be served to and consumed by a customer.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.06  DENIAL.



   A permit may be denied if it is found that the application does not
demonstrate compliance with this section and/or that the granting of the
permit would not be in the public interest. Any applicant denied a permit to
operate a sidewalk café shall receive a written statement outlining the
grounds on which the denial is based. The applicant may appeal the denial of
the permit to city, and City Council may take action as it shall find
necessary. The finding and determination of City Council shall constitute
final action by the city.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.07  TERMS; TRANSFER.



   Permits for a sidewalk café issued in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter shall be issued for the period beginning July 1 or thereafter
and expiring June 30 of each year. If a permittee discontinues the restaurant
operation or the sidewalk café, no refund of the permit fee shall be made.
Permits issued pursuant to this section shall not be transferable or
assignable. Permits may prohibit operation of sidewalk cafés during special
events and contain other conditions and restrictions as may be necessary to
protect the public health, safety and welfare.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.08  PERMIT SUSPENSION.



   (A)   The City Manager may suspend a permit issued pursuant to this
section if he or she finds one or more of the following conditions exist:



      (1)   Violation of any provision of the County Health
Department regulations or of this chapter;



      (2)   Violation of any law, regulation or ordinance regarding
the possession, sale, transportation or consumption of intoxicating beverages
or controlled substances;



      (3)   Operation of the sidewalk café in a manner as to create
a public nuisance or to constitute a hazard to the public health, safety or
welfare; specifically including failure to keep the café area clean and free
of refuse; and/or



      (4)   Operation of the restaurant or sidewalk café in
violation of any city, county or state law, ordinance or regulation.



   (B)   The permit suspension shall take effect immediately upon
delivery of a citation to the restaurant operator or, in his or her absence,
the person with supervisory authority over the operation of the restaurant
and shall be reinstated once the City Manager has verified that the condition
has been remedied.



   (C)   The restaurant operator may request a hearing contesting the
suspension of the permit by filing written notice thereof upon the City
Manager. The hearing shall be held and a written decision rendered within 15
days of the date of receipt. The decision of the City Manager may be appealed
to the City Council by written notice thereof filed with the City Clerk
within 15 days of the date of receipt of the decision.



(Ord. passed 8-12-13)



§ 119.09  PERMIT REVOCATION.



   (A)   The City Manager may revoke a permit issued pursuant to this
section if he or she finds that the restaurant operator has:



      (1)   Deliberately misrepresented or provided false
information in the permit application;



      (2)   Violated any provision of the County Health Department
regulations or of this chapter;



      (3)   Violated any law, regulation or ordinance regarding the
possession, sale, transportation or consumption of intoxicating beverages or
controlled substances;



      (4)   Operated the sidewalk café in a manner as to create a
public nuisance or to constitute a hazard to the public health, safety or
welfare; specifically including failure to keep the café area clean and free
of refuse;



      (5)   Failed to maintain any health, business or other permit
or license required by law or the operation of a restaurant business;



      (6)   Failed to consistently maintain the sidewalk café in a
neat and trash free manner; and/or



      (7)   Operated the restaurant or sidewalk café in violation
