the Housing Inspector certifies to the Council, after the notice of appeal is
filed with him, that by reason of the facts stated in the certificate (a copy
of which shall be furnished to the appellant), a suspension of his
requirement shall not be suspended except by a restraining order granted by
the Council for due cause shown upon not less than one day's written notice
to the Housing Inspector, or by a restraining order of any court of record.



(Ord. 94-8-4, passed 8-8-94)  Penalty, see § 150.999



INSPECTIONS DIVISION



§ 150.125  CREATION; APPOINTMENT OF SUPERINTENDENT; COMPOSITION.



   There is hereby created a division of the City Manager's Office to be
known as the Inspections Division. The Inspections Division shall be headed
by the Inspections Superintendent to be appointed by the City Manager, which
Inspections Superintendent shall be under the immediate direction and control
of the City Manager or his designee. The Inspections Division shall be
composed of such inspectors and personnel as the Council may from time to
time authorize.



(Ord. 94-8-4, passed 8-8-94)



Cross-reference:



   Joint enforcement with county, see § 150.004



§ 150.126  DUTIES; RESPONSIBILITIES AND POWERS.



   (A)   The duties and responsibilities of the Inspections Division
and of the Inspectors therein shall be to enforce within the city and the
extra- territorial area provided in this chapter, all state and local laws
relating to the following:



      (1)   The construction of buildings and other structures.



      (2)   The installation of such facilities as plumbing systems,
electrical systems, heating systems, refrigeration systems and air
conditioning systems.



      (3)   The maintenance of buildings and other structures in a
safe, sanitary, and healthful condition.



      (4)   The enforcement of the city minimum housing code, zoning
code, and the condemnation of non-housing.



      (5)   Other matters that may from time to time be specified by
the Council.



   (B)   These duties shall include, but not be limited to, the receipt
of applications for permits and the issuance or denial of permits, the making
of any necessary inspections, the issuance or denial of certificates of
compliance, the issuance of orders to correct violations, the recommendation
to the Council to institute judicial actions against actual or threatened
violations, the keeping of adequate records, and the taking of any other
actions that may be required in order to adequately enforce those laws.



   (C)   The Inspections Superintendent is hereby granted all power
necessary to carry out the mandates of the Council in the operations of the
Inspections Division. This shall include in addition to any incidental powers
necessary, any specific powers which may from time to time be granted by city
Council in any specific ordinances.



(Ord. 94-8-4, passed 8-8-94) 



§ 150.127  CONFLICTS OF INTEREST.



   No member of the Inspections Division shall engage in any work that is
inconsistent with his duties or with the interests of the city.



(Ord. 94-8-4, passed 8-8-94)  Penalty, see § 150.999



§ 150.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter for
which no penalty is otherwise provided shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
shall be punished as provided in G.S. § 14-4.



   (B)   Any person who violates any provision of § 150.002 of this
chapter shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50 for each violation.



   (C)   (1)   Failure to obtain a permit prior to moving a
structure or failure to comply with any other requirements of §§ 150.050
through 150.053 shall result in a civil penalty being imposed on the
responsible party, who shall include but not be limited to the general
contractor, the structure mover, the owner of the structure at the time of
the move, and, if different, the owner of the structure at the end of the
move, in the amount of $2,500. In addition, the inspections superintendent
may refuse to issue any further structure moving permits or building permits
to the general contractor, mover, the mover's business, the owner of the
structure at the time of the move, or, if different, the owner of the
structure at the end of the move, until all appropriate penalties have been
paid and all provisions of §§ 150.050 through 150.053 have been complied
with. No other structure moving permits shall be issued allowing structures
to be moved to properties owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by persons,
firms, corporations or other entities which own, lease, manage or otherwise
control properties, dwellings or other structures that are in violation of
the minimum housing or public nuisance codes. If a person fails to pay this
civil penalty within ten days after being cited for a violation, the city may
seek to recover this penalty by filing a civil action in the nature of a debt.



      (2)   Violations of the above-mentioned sections shall be
considered a misdemeanor pursuant to G.S. § 14-4, punishable by imprisonment
for up to 30 days and/or a criminal fine in the amount of $500.



      (3)   The City Council hereby finds that the placement of a
structure on a lot within the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction in
violation of §§ 150.050 through 150.053 endangers the health, safety, and
welfare of its citizens, and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. In
the event any person, firm or entity moves any structure onto property in the
city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction without first having obtained a
permit as required by §§ 150.050 through 150.053, the city shall be
entitled to obtain injunctive relief through an action in the nature of an
action to abate a nuisance to cause the immediate removal from the city of
the offending structure.



   (D)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any unsafe
building to fail, neglect, or refuse to repair, alter, and improve the same;
or to fail to vacate, close, and remove or demolish the same, upon order of
the Inspections Superintendent duly made and served as herein provided,
within the time specified in such order, and each day that any such failure,
neglect, or refusal to comply with such order continues shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any
unsafe building with respect to which an order has been issued pursuant to §
150.087 of this chapter, to occupy or permit the occupancy of the same after
the time prescribed in such order for its repair, alteration, and improvement
or its vacation, closing, and removal or demolition, and each day that such
occupancy continues after such prescribed time shall constitute a separate
and distinct offense.



      (2)   Any owner of a building who fails to comply with any
order described in § 150.088(A) and (B), or who allows occupancy of the
building subject to the order after the compliance period in the order has
expired, shall be subject to a civil penalty of $250 for each day that
noncompliance continues following the expiration of the compliance period
specified in the Order of Compliance. If a person fails to pay the civil
penalty within ten days of receipt of the citation, the city may seek to
collect it in a civil action in the nature of a debt.



      (3)   Failure by any owner to comply with any order described
in division (D)(1) of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable
by a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days.



      (4)   Each day that a violation continues after notification
that the violation exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense
for purposes of the penalties and remedies set forth in this section.



      (5)   Sections 150.065 through 150.095 may be enforced by any
appropriate equitable action.



      (6)   Sections 150.065 through 150.095 may be enforced by any
one, all, or any combination of the remedies authorized in this division (D).



(Ord. 94-8-4, passed 8-8-94; Am. Ord. passed 4-10-00; Am. Ord. TC00-5, passed
10-9-00; Am. Ord. TC01-04, passed 1-14-02)



CHAPTER 151:  MOBILE HOMES



Section




General Provisions




   151.01   Definitions



   151.02   Temporary mobile home conditional use permit for emergency
use



   151.03   Additions to mobile homes



   151.04   Enforcement; inspections



   151.05   Responsibility of licensee




Licenses




   151.20   Application



   151.21   Prerequisites to issuance of license



   151.22   Posting license



   151.23   Separate licenses; apportionment of fees



   151.24   Assignment



   151.25   Annual renewal; license fee



   151.26   Revocation



   151.27   Appeals; hearings



 



   151.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 151.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   LICENSEE.  Any person licensed to operate or maintain a mobile home
park under the provisions of this chapter.



   MOBILE HOME (MANUFACTURED HOME). A dwelling unit that:



      (1)   Is not constructed in accordance with the standards set
forth in the North Carolina State Building Code for uniform residential
building code for one and two-family dwellings; and



      (2)   Is composed of one or more components, each of which was
substantially assembled in a manufacturing plant and designed to be
transported to the home site on its own chassis; and



      (3)   Exceeds 40 feet in length and eight feet in width.



   MOBILE HOME (MANUFACTURED HOME) PARK.  A parcel of land under single
ownership on which two or more mobile homes are occupied as residences.



   MOBILE HOME SPACE.  An area within the park which has been approved
for a single mobile home and which is located in a mobile home park.



('75 Code § 9.1-1) (Am. Ord. passed 1-9-89; Am. Ord. passed 3-8-93)



§ 151.02 TEMPORARY MOBILE HOME CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT FOR EMERGENCY USE.



   (A)   A conditional use permit (CUP) may be granted by the Zoning
Administrator for placement of a mobile home in the RA-15, R-15, R-10, R-5,
and RMF zoning jurisdictions (see Chapter 155, Zoning Code) where due to fire
or other similar unanticipated catastrophic event, the principal structure is
deter-mined by the Zoning Administrator to be unfit for safe and healthy
human habitation. All such mobile homes shall meet the following requirements:



      (1)   Said permit shall be valid for a maximum period of six
months. This permit may be extended on a one-time basis only for a maximum of
three months by the Board of Adjustment if it is determined that:



         (a)   Substantial progress has been made in constructing
a new structure on the lot or repairing the existing structure.



         (b)   The structure being constructed or repaired, at
the time the permit extension is applied for, is still not fit for human
habitation.



      (2)   The mobile home must be located in the rear yard if
topographically and practically possible, provided if the mobile home cannot
be placed in the rear yard for such topographical or practical
considerations, then the mobile home must be located so that it is not within
20 feet of any residential structure (except the applicant's residence which
was damaged in the event) or any street. No variances will be granted on
these requirements.



      (3)   No mobile home may be placed on a lot which already
contains another mobile home.



      (4)   The mobile home shall be removed at the end of the
six-month period, or nine-month period (if an extension is granted by the
Board of Adjustment), or within one week of the completion of all repair or
construction work to the principal structure, whichever comes first.



      (5)   The mobile home will have adequate access to city water
and sewer or to a well and septic tank as verified by permits from the Gaston
County Health Department.



      (6)   The granting of the CUP will not materially endanger the
public health, safety, and welfare.



   (B)   Such permit is granted to a particular owner on the basis of
circumstances peculiar to that owner and it shall not remain in effect in the
event of a change of ownership of any land structure, use, or other item
covered by the CUP.



   (C)   When granting the CUP, the Zoning Administrator may impose
reasonable conditions, restrictions, and safeguards as considered necessary
to protect the public health, safety, and welfare in accordance with the
purpose and intent of this section. Violation of these conditions,
restrictions, and safe-guards shall be considered a violation of this section.



(Ord. passed 4-10-95)



§ 151.03  ADDITIONS TO MOBILE HOMES.



   No living compartment shall be added to any mobile home parked within a
mobile home park, except for a prefabricated structure specifically designed
by the manufacturer for mobile home extension and approved by the Zoning
Administrator.



('75 Code, § 9.1-18) (Ord. passed 11-12-72) Penalty, see 151.99



§ 151.04  ENFORCEMENT; INSPECTIONS.



   The Zoning Administrator is hereby authorized and it shall be his duty
to enforce the provisions of this chapter. He shall have the right and is
hereby empowered to enter upon any premises on which any mobile home park is
located, or about to be located, and to inspect the same and all
accommodations connected therewith at any reasonable time.



('75 Code, § 9.1-2) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.05  RESPONSIBILITY OF LICENSEE.



   The licensee, together with any duly authorized attendant or caretaker,
shall be answerable for the violation of any law or ordinance to which the
mobile home park is subjected.



('75 Code, § 9.1-3) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)  Penalty, see § 151.99



LICENSES



§ 151.20  APPLICATION.



   (A)   All persons who are operating a mobile home park at the time
of the effective date of this chapter or who desire to engage in the business
of operating a mobile home park shall apply in writing to the Zoning
Administrator for a license. The appli-cation for a license shall be made
upon a form to be provided by the Zoning Administrator, shall be signed by
the person who is to engage in the business and shall contain the following:



      (1)   The complete and exact name under which the business is
proposed to be operated.



      (2)   If the business is proposed to be operated by an
individual under an assumed name, the name of such individual and his address.



      (3)   If the business is a partnership, the name and address
of each partner.



      (4)   If the business is a corporation, the names and
addresses of the officers of the corporation and the location of the
principal or registered office.



      (5)   A physical survey and legal description of the land upon
which the mobile home park is to be located.



      (6)   A site plan including the following: grading,
engineering, design, construction size, height, shape and location of
buildings, location and design of parking areas, pedestrian and vehicular
circulation on site, recreational facilities and areas, means for collection
and depositing storm water and natural or artificial water courses and
utilities systems.



('75 Code, § 9.1-5) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.21  PREREQUISITES FOR ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.



   No license shall be granted to any mobile home park unless:



   (A)   The license fee herein imposed is paid.



   (B)   The Zoning Administrator is satisfied that compliance has been
made with the requirements of the city code and with the laws of the state.



   (C)   The site plan has been approved by the Public Works Director
and by the Planning Director of the city Planning and Zoning Commission;
provided, that if the site plan is disapproved, the applicant may appeal such
decision to the City Council.



('75 Code, § 9.1-6) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.22  POSTING LICENSE.



   Any license issued under this chapter must be posted conspicuously in
the place of business. If such licensee has no regular place of business, the
license must be kept wherever the business is being operated and where it may
be inspected at all times by the proper city officials.



('75 Code, § 9.1-8) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.23  SEPARATE LICENSES; APPORTIONMENT OF FEES.



   (A)   Separate licenses. Every person operating a mobile home park
in more than one place shall secure a separate license for each place of
business unless such places of business are contiguous to each other,
communicate with and open in to each other, and are operated as a unit, and
such person shall pay the prescribed license fee for each place of business.
('75 Code, § 9.1-10)



   (B)   Apportionment of fees. When any mobile home park is opened and
operations commenced after February 1, the licensee shall pay for such
business, and the privileges of operating the same, one-half of the license
fee prescribed. ('75 Code, § 9.1-9)



(Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.24  ASSIGNMENT.



   No license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be
assigned except to the purchaser of a mobile home park who elects to carry on
the same business at the same place. Upon delivery to the Zoning
Administrator of the license properly assigned, the applicant shall be
entitled to have a new license issued to him upon payment of $10. The Zoning
Administrator shall cancel such assigned license upon the issuance of a new
license. 



('75 Code, § 9.1-11) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.25  ANNUAL RENEWAL; LICENSE FEE.



   (A)   Any license issued by the Zoning Admini- strator shall expire
on June 30 of each year but may be renewed under the provisions of this
chapter for additional periods of one year. ('75 Code, § 9.1-12)



   (B)   The annual license fee or renewal thereof for any mobile home
park shall be $5 for each mobile home space improved and available for
occupancy within the corporate limits of the city.



('75 Code, § 9.1-13) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.26  REVOCATION.



   The Zoning Administrator is hereby authorized to revoke any license
issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter if after due investigation he
determines that the holder thereof has violated any of the provisions of this
chapter or that any mobile home park is being maintained in an unsanitary
manner, or is a nuisance.



('75 Code, § 9.1-14) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.27  APPEALS; HEARINGS.



   (A)   Any person aggrieved by an order of the Zoning Administrator
granting, denying, renewing, or revoking a license for a mobile home park
under this chapter may appeal to the City Council within ten days after the
issuance of such order by the Zoning Administrator. The City Council shall
fix a reasonable time for the hearing of an appeal and give due notice to the
appellant. Any appeal shall have the effect of suspending the requirement of
the Zoning Administrator until the hearing by the City Council.



('75 Code, § 9.1-15) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



§ 151.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be guilty of a mis- demeanor and may be punished by a fine of not
more than $50 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or punished by both fine
and imprisonment in the discre-tion of the court. Each day that a violation
continues to exist shall be considered a separate offense.



('75 Code, 9.1-4) (Ord. passed 11-12-72)



CHAPTER 152:  DRAINAGE REGULATIONS



Section



   152.01   Definitions



   152.02   Drainage devices; installation, maintenance; permit required



   152.03   Approval of permit



   152.04   Construction and alteration of land surfaces



   152.05   Drainage piping



   152.06   Roadway crossings



   152.07   Natural channel maintenance on private property



   152.08   Storm drain crossing



   152.09   Storm drainage plan required



   152.10   Streets without curbs or gutters



   152.11   Ditch lines; rights-of-way



   152.12   Storm drainage systems



Cross-reference:



   Subdivision regulations, see Chapter 154



   Building regulations, see Chapter 150



   Streets and sidewalks, see Chapter 96



§ 152.01  DEFINITIONS.



      For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DRAINAGE DEVICE.  Any culvert, pipe, ditch, swale, or other device
used to channelize, collect, divert, or in any way modify the natural flow of
surface water over property.



   DRAINAGE POLICY.  The set of policies and regulations as modified from
time to time, drawn by the City Manager, approved by the City Council, and
made available to the public. The City Manager shall present to the Council a
proposed set of policies and regulations together with such amendments as
become necessary from time to time.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



§ 152.02  DRAINAGE DEVICES; INSTALLATION, MAINTENANCE; PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   From and after the effective date of this chapter, no drainage
device other than drain pipes from down spouts from residences shall be
placed, installed, or maintained in any manner contrary to the drainage
policies of the city.



   (B)   No drainage device may be installed or maintained within the
city, without the owner of the property on which the proposed installation is
to take place, first obtaining a permit from the City Manager issued pursuant
to the drainage policy.



   (C)   The city shall issue a permit for the installa- tion and
maintenance of a drainage device only after a determination that the proposed
installation meets the requirements of and conforms to the drainage policies.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 152.03  APPROVAL OF PERMIT.



   No plat, plan of subdivision, or building permit shall be approved or
issued by the city without the property owner first submitting for review and
approval, a plan and map or plat showing the flow and discharge of surface
water from the site or subdivision, which plan shall be filed with the City
Manager. The City Manager may waive all or any portion of this requirement if
the proposed work to be performed will not, in his opinion, substantially
affect the flow of surface water from the property.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



Cross-reference:



   Subdivision regulations, see Chapter 154



   Building regulations, see Chapter 150



§ 152.04  CONSTRUCTION AND ALTERATION OF LAND SURFACES.



   All construction, excavation, and alteration of land surfaces within
the jurisdiction of the city shall be done in accordance with the drainage
policies of the city as modified from time to time.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 152.05  DRAINAGE PIPING.



   All streams or natural waterways having a water- shed greater than ten
acres shall not be piped except at road crossing by any party with the
exception that such a stream may be piped for a 25-year storm and that such
piping system must be designed by a licensed engineer.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



§ 152.06  ROADWAY CROSSINGS.



   The city shall be responsible for all roadway crossings on city streets
and other storm drain systems located in city street right-of-ways in
existence as of the first adoption of these regulations. This responsibility
shall exist only as to the width of the street right-of-way.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



§ 152.07  NATURAL CHANNEL MAINTENANCE ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.



   (A)   Except as noted in § 152.08 of this chapter, the city will
not be responsible for natural waterway channel maintenance on private
property. It shall be incumbent on the property owners to clear and leave
open all natural drainage waterways on his property and he shall not place
any restrictions in the water- way that would hamper the natural flow.



   (B)   In cases existing where private drainage systems presently
connect to city system piping, either up stream or down stream, the city
shall not be responsible for operation or maintenance of any off right-of-way
piping or assume any liability for such except as noted in § 152.08 of this
chapter.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



§ 152.08  STORM DRAIN CROSSING.



   In cases where a storm drain crossing is made, the city, upon
recommendation of the Public Works Director, approved by the City Manager,
and accepted by City Council, may assume maintenance responsibilities across
private property if a drainage easement is granted for such drainage for the
property effected at no cost to the city save legal and recording costs.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



§ 152.09  STORM DRAINAGE PLAN REQUIRED.



   All proposed subdivision plats or individual building plats (except
single-family residences) shall have a storm drainage plan to show natural
drainage over the property and the proposed method of collecting storm water
prior to its release to adjacent properties. The plats shall be made part of
the zoning permit application and shall be approved by the city. Permanent
drainage easements may be required and these shall be obtained or granted at
no expense to the city.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



§ 152.10  STREETS WITHOUT CURBS OR GUTTERS.



   In presently existing streets without curbs and gutters, the following
regulations shall apply:



   (A)   No single driveway entrance shall exceed 24 feet in width, and
at a ditch crossing, no pipe shall be smaller than 15 inches, and larger pipe
may be required. In cases where smaller driveway pipes presently exist they
may continue except at the discretion of the city they may be ordered to be
removed or enlarged at no expense to the city. The sheet flow of one driveway
may be drained upon the street but any additional driveways shall be designed
to drain onto the side ditch on the same side as the drive. Driveways shall
not be constructed lower than the street grade, present or future, except at
the risk or liability of the driveway owner. The city shall assume no
liability for sheet flow into a driveway constructed lower than street grade.
It is suggested as a design standard that a minimum elevation of 6 inches be
required for all such driveways as they cross the ditch line or right-of-way.



   (B)   The front ditch line may be piped, by permit issued by the
city and at no expense to the city. Such piping shall not be smaller than 15
inches, and larger pipe may be required. A ditch line or swale shall still be
required to have the effect to drain the street and to prevent sheet flow
drainage from the property from coming into the street. A drop inlet and/or
catch basin shall be required at every property line or 150 feet, whichever
is smaller. All piping, basins, and the like shall be at the sole expense of
the requesting property owner. Labor rates shall be charged as per charges
adopted by Council. All such piping shall be subject to removal by the city
at any time it is in the best interest of the city. The city will assume
maintenance responsibility for such systems properly constructed and approved
by the city.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 152.11  DITCH LINES; RIGHTS-OF-WAY.



   (A)   The city hereby reemphasizes its right to re- establish any
ditch lines or drainage situations in its rights-of-way at its discretion. In
cases where down stream adjacent property owners object to such action, the
city shall not assume any liability for its not taking any action.



   (B)   The city shall not be responsible nor shall it take any action
to modify any sheet flow type drainage or any unopened right-of-way, present
or future, or any other city-owned property not in use.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



§ 152.12  STORM DRAINAGE SYSTEMS.



   All storm drainage systems shall be designed for a ten-year storm and
all cross drainage in natural water courses shall be designed for a 25-year
storm. The city shall endeavor to inventory its cross street drainage over
the next two years with regards to condition and adequacy, and shall develop
a five-year plan to upgrade any shortcomings found.



(Ord. passed 1-13-86)



CHAPTER 153:  WATERSHED PROTECTION



Section



   153.01   Adoption of the Unified  Development Ordinance (UDO) by
reference



§ 153.01  ADOPTION OF THE UNIFIED  DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE (UDO) BY
REFERENCE.



   The watershed protection regulations are now included in the Unified
Development Ordinance (UDO), which is hereby adopted by reference as if set
forth in full.  Copies of the UDO are available for public review during
regular office hours in the Office of the City Planner.  Questions
concerning the UDO should be directed to the City Planner.



(Ord. passed 8-13-07)



CHAPTER 154:  SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS



Section



   154.01   Adoption of the Unified Development Ordinance (UDO) by
reference



§ 154.01  ADOPTION OF THE UNIFIED  DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE (UDO) BY
REFERENCE.



   The subdivision regulations are now included in the Unified Development
Ordinance (UDO), which is hereby adopted by reference as if set forth in
full.  Copies of the UDO are available for public review during regular
office hours in the Office of the City Planner.  Questions concerning the
UDO should be directed to the City Planner.



(Ord. passed 8-13-07)



CHAPTER 155:  ZONING CODE



Section



   155.001   Adoption of the Unified Development Code (UDO) by
reference.



§ 155.001  ADOPTION OF THE UNIFIED  DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE (UDO) BY
REFERENCE.



   The Zoning Code is now included in the Unified Development Ordinance
(UDO), which is hereby adopted by reference as if set forth in full.  Copies
of the UDO are available for public review during regular office hours in the
Office of the City Planner.  Questions concerning the UDO should be directed
to the City Planner.



(Ord. passed 8-13-07)

Bessemer City Unified Development Ordinance


BESSEMER CITY UNIFIED DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE



Current through August 2018



 



Published by:
American Legal Publishing Corporation
One West Fourth Street, Third Floor
Cincinnati, Ohio  45202
Tel: (800) 445-5588
Fax: (513) 763-3562
Internet: http://www.amlegal.com



CHAPTER 1.
PURPOSE



1.1   Title



1.2   Authority



1.3   Purpose



1.4   Jurisdiction



1.5   Severability



1.6   Reenactment and Repeal of Existing Ordinance(s)



1.7   Effective Date



1.8   Adoption Date



Section 1.1   Title



   This Ordinance shall be known as the "Unified Development Ordinance of
Bessemer City, North Carolina" and may be referred to herein as the "Unified
Development Ordinance", the “UDO”, or “this Ordinance.”



Section 1.2   Authority



   This Ordinance is adopted pursuant to the authority granted to Bessemer
City by Chapter 160A, Article 19 of the General Statutes of North Carolina
and by any special local Acts enacted by the North Carolina General Assembly
for Bessemer City in order to carry out the purposes stated therein.  The
standards, districts, and maps identified in this Ordinance shall be in
accordance with the objectives and policies of locally adopted comprehensive
plans and other such plans as may have been adopted for the physical
development of Bessemer City.



Section 1.3   Purpose



   A.   The Ordinance enables Bessemer City to respond uniformly and
consistently to development proposals and to promote the health, safety, and
general welfare of its residents. The UDO seeks to provide uniformity,
certainty, and predictability regarding land use and development issues to
the greatest degree feasible for properties located within the jurisdiction
of this Ordinance. Notwithstanding, this Ordinance also attempts to provide
flexibility in dealing with situations that may fall outside typical
processes and requirements.  The elements that make up the Ordinance are
interrelated and cannot be taken in isolation; they must be taken within the
context and intent of the entire Ordinance.



   B.   Other goals that this UDO is anticipated to serve include:



      1.   Lessen congestion on streets;



      2.   Secure safety from fire, panic and dangers;



      3.   Avoid undue concentration of population;



      4.   Facilitate the efficient and adequate provision of
transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements.



      5.   Provide a guide for the orderly growth and development of
the City;



      6.   Regulate the use of buildings, structures and land;



      7.   Control the bulk, scale and design of buildings and
structures;



      8.   Ensure adequate privacy and access to property;



      9.   Maintain orderly and compatible land use and development
patterns;



      10.   Protect the integrity of water supply watersheds;



      11.   Encourage environmentally responsible development
practices;



      12.   Maintain and develop economically vibrant commercial and
industrial areas;



      13.   Retain and expand the City’s employment base;



      14.   Provide attractive and effective signage that is
compatible with the surrounding environment;



      15.   Accommodate and promote pedestrians and pedestrian use
to the greatest degree feasible and practical;



      16.   Allow a range of housing choices and options; 



      17.   Establish clear and effective development review
procedures;



      18.   Coordinate transportation networks and utilities within
proposed subdivisions with existing or planned streets and highways and with
other public facilities;



      19.   Dedicate or reserve recreation areas serving residents
of the immediate neighborhood within a subdivision or, alternatively, for
provision of funds to be used to acquire recreation areas serving residents
of a development or subdivision or nearby developments or subdivisions;



      20.   Ensure that rights-of-way or easements for street and
utility purposes are secured;



      21.   Distribute population and traffic in a manner that will
avoid congestion and overcrowding and create conditions that substantially
promote the public health, welfare and safety.



      22.   Implement and ensure consistency with officially adopted
plans;



      23.   Provide appropriate and effective enforcement mechanisms.



Section 1.4   Jurisdiction



   A.   These regulations govern the development and use of all land
and structures only within the planning jurisdiction of Bessemer City as now
fixed and as may be amended in the future, said territory being indicated in
the Official Zoning Map of Bessemer City (hereafter referred to as "Zoning
Map", "Official Zoning Map" or "Bessemer City Zoning Map") as is on file at
the office of the Administrator.  This map and its boundaries shall be
incorporated and made part of this Ordinance.



   B.   No building, structure, or land shall be used or occupied, and
no building, structure, or part thereof shall be erected, constructed,
reconstructed, moved, enlarged, or structurally altered, unless in conformity
with all the provisions of this Ordinance for the district in which it is
located and other applicable regulations, except as otherwise provided by
this Ordinance.



   C.   Except as herein provided, the provisions of this ordinance
shall apply to all land, buildings, structures and uses thereof located
within the planning jurisdiction of this ordinance, including land owed by
municipal units of government.  To the extent allowed by law, this Ordinance
shall also apply to all land, buildings, structures and uses owned by City or
federal agencies located within the planning jurisdiction of Bessemer City. 
Where the provisions of this Ordinance do not apply to such structures and
land, such agencies are encouraged to meet the provisions of this
Ordinance.  The provisions of this Ordinance shall also be applicable to the
erection, construction and use of buildings owned by the State of North
Carolina per NCGS 160A-392; however, no land owned by the State may be
included within an overlay district or special use or conditional district
without the approval of the Council of State.



Section 1.5   Severability



   If any section or specific provision or standard of this Ordinance or
any zoning district boundary that may exist in the future is found by a court
to be invalid for any reason, the decision of the court shall not affect the
validity of any other section, provision, standard, or district boundary of
these regulations except the provision in question.  The other portions of
these regulations not affected by the decision of the court shall remain in
full force and effect.



Section 1.6   Reenactment and Repeal of Existing Ordinance (s)



   A.   This Ordinance is in part carried forward by re-enactment of
some of the provisions of the City of Bessemer City Zoning Ordinance adopted
by the City Council on June 30, 1981, as amended and the City of Bessemer
City Subdivision Ordinance, adopted by the City Council on April 11, 1988, as
amended and it is not the intention to repeal but rather to re-enact and
continue in force such existing provisions so that all rights and liabilities
that have accrued thereunder are preserved and may be enforced.  All
provisions of the City of Bessemer City Zoning Ordinance), as amended, and
the City of Bessemer City Subdivision Ordinance, as amended, which are not
re-enacted herein are hereby repealed.  All suits at law or in equity and/or
all prosecutions resulting from the violation of said Zoning Ordinance or
Subdivision Ordinance heretofore in effect, which are as of the adoption date
pending in any of the courts of this State or of the United States, shall not
be abated or abandoned by reason of the adoption of this Ordinance but shall
be prosecuted to their finality, the same as if this Ordinance had not been
adopted, and any and all violations of the existing Bessemer City Zoning
Ordinance and/or Subdivision Ordinance, prosecutions or suits for which have
not yet been instituted, may be hereafter filed and prosecuted.  Nothing in
this Ordinance shall be construed as to abandon, abate or dismiss any
litigation or prosecution now pending, and/or which may heretofore have been
instituted or prosecuted.



Section 1.7   Effective Date



   This Ordinance shall become effective on August 13, 2007.



Section 1.8   Adoption Date



   The Bessemer City Council hereby adopts this Ordinance on the 13th day
of August, 2007.



CHAPTER 2.
INTERPRETATIONS; RULES OF CONSTRUCTION; DEFINITIONS



2.1   Official Zoning Map



2.2   Interpretation of Zoning Map



2.3   Fractional Requirements



2.4   Text Controls Over Graphics



2.5   Conflicting Provisions



2.6   Interpretations of Terms and Words



2.7   Terms Defined in this Ordinance



Section 2.1   Official Zoning Map



   A.   Each lot and tract located within the territorial jurisdiction
of this Ordinance shall be located in one or more zoning districts contained
in this Ordinance.  The map identifying the location of such zoning district
boundaries shall be identified as the “Official Zoning Map.”  If the
City Council enacts subsequent zoning map changes, such changes shall be made
upon the Official Zoning Map.  No changes to any zoning district boundaries
shall be made on the Official Zoning Map except in conformance with the
procedures set forth in this Ordinance. 



   B.   The Official Zoning Map may be comprised of one or more sheets
or digital maps, properly identified as such, which shall be on file with the
Administrator.  Land within zoning districts on the Official Zoning Map
shall be classified with a zoning district designation, which shall supersede
any contrary designation on a former Official Zoning Map.  Regardless of the
existence of any alleged copy of the Official Zoning Map, the Official Zoning
Map in the UDO Administrator’s office shall be the final authority as to
the current zoning status of a piece of property.  A copy of the Official
Zoning Map shall be located with the Administrator. 



Section 2.2   Interpretation of Zoning Map



   Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of the zoning
districts shown on the Zoning Map, the following rules shall be used to
interpret the maps:



   A.   Where a map shows a boundary line located within a street or
alley right-of-way, railroad or utility line right-of-way, easement, or
navigable or non-navigable waterway, it shall be considered to be in the
center of the right-of-way, easement, or waterway. If the actual location of
such right-of-way, easement, or waterway varies slightly from the location as
shown on a map, then the actual location shall control.



   B.   Where a map shows a boundary line as being located a specific
distance from a street line or other physical feature, that distance shall
control.



   C.   Where a map shows a district boundary to approximately coincide
with a property line or city, town, or county border, the property line or
city, town, or county border shall be considered to be the district boundary,
unless otherwise indicated.



   D.   Where a map shows a district boundary not coinciding or
approximately coinciding with any street, alley, railroad, waterway, or
property line, and no dimensions are shown, the location of the boundary
shall be determined by use of the scale appearing on the map.



   E.   In instances when a zoning case file contains detailed
information regarding the boundary, that information will be used as the
correct boundary location.



   F.   If it is alleged by any party that an error exists on the
zoning maps with respect to any zoning district designation, zoning district
boundary, special use permit or conditional district boundary, historical
district boundary, the lines showing the effective dates of zoning enactment
or any other matter with respect to the provisions of this ordinance relating
to zoning information, the party may request a review of the alleged error by
the Board of Adjustment, per Section 4.5.1(A)(4).



   H.   Whenever a single lot is located within two or more different
zoning districts, each portion of that lot shall be subject to the
regulations applicable to the district in which it is located.



   Additional provisions for determining the location of boundaries of the
Water Supply Watershed Overlay District are found in Section 6.6.2.2(Q).



Section 2.3   Fractional Requirements



   Whenever any requirement of this Ordinance results in a fraction of a
unit, the fraction will be rounded up to the next whole unit.  Whenever a
density calculation for a lot of record existing prior to June 30, 1981,
results in less than one dwelling unit being permitted, the fractional
requirement will be disregarded and one dwelling unit will be permitted. 



Section 2.4   Text Controls Over Graphics



   This Ordinance contains numerous graphics, pictures, illustrations and
drawings.  However, in case of conflict between the text and a graphic,
picture, illustration or drawing or any other depiction, the text shall
control. 



Section 2.5   Conflicting Provisions



   A.   Where the provisions of this Ordinance are inconsistent with
those of the state or federal government, the more restrictive provisions
shall apply and shall be governed by the designated regulatory agency.  The
more restrictive provision is the one that imposes greater restrictions or
more stringent controls.



   B.   Where the provisions of this Ordinance are inconsistent with
one another, or are in conflict with provisions found in other adopted
ordinances or regulations adopted by Bessemer City, the more restrictive
provisions shall govern and shall be enforced by those County agency (ies). 
The more restrictive provision is the one that imposes greater restrictions
or more stringent controls



   C.   This ordinance is not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or
annul any deed restriction or other agreement between private parties. 
Bessemer City and its staff shall not enforce any such private agreements.



Section 2.6   Interpretations of Terms and Words



   A.   The following rules shall be followed in interpreting words and
terms used in this Ordinance.



      1.   Words used in the present tense include the future tense.



      2.   Words used in the singular number include the plural, and
words used in the plural number include the singular.



      3.   The word "person" includes a firm, association,
organization, partnership, corporation, trust and company as well as an
individual.



      4.   The word "lot" includes the word "plot" or "parcel”



      5.   The words “must” or "shall" are always mandatory and
not merely directory.



      6.   The word "may" is permissive in nature, except when the
context of the particular use is negative.  In such case it is mandatory.



      7.   Words used in the singular number include the plural
number and the plural number includes the singular number, unless the context
of the particular usage clearly indicates otherwise.



      8.   The words "used" or "occupied" as applied to any land or
building shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, or
designed to be used or occupied".



      9.   The word "Zoning Map", or "Bessemer City Zoning Map",
“Zoning Map”, or "Official Zoning Map" shall mean the Official Zoning Map
of Bessemer City, North Carolina.



      10.   Any word denoting gender includes the female and the
male.



      11.   The term "City Council" shall mean the "City Council of
Bessemer City, North Carolina".



      12.   The term "Planning Board" shall mean the "Planning Board
of Bessemer City, North Carolina.”



      13.   The term "Board of Adjustment" shall mean the "Board of
Adjustment of Bessemer City, North Carolina.”



      14.   The terms "Zoning Administrator", “UDO
Administrator”, “Subdivision Administrator” or “Administrator”,
shall refer the person(s) administrating said Ordinance.



      15.   The term "Street" shall mean "Road".



      16.   The term “zoning jurisdiction” shall mean
“planning jurisdiction” and shall refer to the geographical area in which
this Ordinance has applicability.



      17.   The term “City” shall refer to “Bessemer City,
North Carolina.”



      18.   The term “Bessemer City Planning Department” or
“Planning Department” shall mean the “Bessemer City Planning and
Development Services Department.”



Section 2.7   Terms Defined in This Ordinance



   A list of definitions of terms, phrases and words used in this
Ordinance follows.  Other terms that are found in this Ordinance are located
in Sections 6.6.2.1 (FH Flood Hazard Overlay District), 6.6.2.2, (WS Water
Supply Watershed Overlay District) and Section 5.10 (vested rights).  Words
used but not specifically defined in this Ordinance shall be defined by
reference to (1) the most recently adopted version of the State Building
Code; or, if not defined there, in (2) the Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary.
